Political affiliation also plays a crucial role, with Republicans consistently holding more unfavorable views of China than Democrats [6]. Currently, 83% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents have an unfavorable view, compared to 68% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [6].

![Trend of unfavorable views of China among Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats from 2005 to 2020](image5)
The partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that Republicans are more likely to have a "very unfavorable" view of China (54%) than Democrats (35%) [6].
![Unfavorable and favorable views of China across different age groups.](image1)

In summary, negative perceptions of China have significantly increased over time across all demographics, with older Americans and Republicans exhibiting the most negative views.

Unfavorable views of China have significantly increased in the United States across all demographics in recent years [2].

A Pew Research Center survey conducted in July found that 73% of Americans have an unfavorable view of China, marking the highest level of negativity recorded in 15 years and a 26-point increase since 2018 [2]. This negative sentiment has been steadily rising, with a notable 7% increase in just the four months prior to the survey [2].
![Unfavorable views of China by age group from 2005-2020](image4)
The increase in unfavorable views is evident across all age groups, but it is particularly pronounced among older Americans [9]. Americans ages 50 and older are substantially more negative (81%) than those ages 30 to 49 (71%) or those under 30 (56%) [9].

![Breakdown of unfavorable views of China by age and political affiliation](image2)

Political affiliation also plays a significant role, with Republicans consistently holding more unfavorable views than Democrats [7]. As of the July survey, 83% of Republicans and 68% of Democrats expressed an unfavorable opinion of China [7]. The gap between the parties has widened in recent months, with unfavorable views among Republicans increasing by 11 percentage points and among Democrats by 6 percentage points [3].
![Unfavorable China opinion trend lines for Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020.](image1)

The percentage of Americans with a "very unfavorable" view of China has also reached a record high of 42%, nearly doubling since spring 2019 [6].

In summary, unfavorable views of China have sharply increased in the U.S. across all age groups and political affiliations, reaching historic highs, with older Americans and Republicans expressing the most negative sentiments.

Americans' views of China are broadly negative and have become increasingly unfavorable across different age groups and political affiliations.

There are notable differences in how political affiliations influence preferences for foreign policy partners in both the U.S. and Germany.

In the U.S., Democrats are more inclined to seek greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [3]. Specifically, 66% of Democrats prefer close ties with Germany, compared to 57% of Republicans [4]. Conversely, a higher percentage of Republicans (31%) favor close relations with Russia than Democrats (21%) [4].
![Preference for close relationship with Germany or Russia, by U.S. political affiliation](image3)

When it comes to specific foreign policy partners, both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. consider the UK their most important partner. However, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [8]. Democrats, on the other hand, place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico [8].
![Top foreign policy partners for Republicans and Democrats](image4)

In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens and the SPD [3].
![Preference for close relationship with the U.S., by German political affiliation](image5)
 There is also more support for close relationship with Russia in former East Germany. [7]
German political parties, including CDU/CSU, SPD, and the Greens, all rank France as their first or second most important partner, followed by the U.S. [9].
 A significant majority of Americans (69%) want to cooperate more with Germany, while only half of Germans express the same desire about the U.S. [2].
![Attitudes toward cooperation with other countries among Americans and Germans](image2)

In summary, political affiliations in the U.S. significantly influence preferences, with Democrats favoring Germany and Republicans leaning towards Israel and Russia, while in Germany, party differences are less pronounced, with major parties prioritizing France followed by the U.S.

There are notable differences in preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China between Americans and Germans.

Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [3]. Increased cooperation with Russia is favored more by Republicans (41%) than Democrats (32%) in the U.S. [3]. In Germany, residents of former East Germany (75%) show a stronger preference for cooperation with Russia than those in former West Germany (63%) [3].
![image1](image1)

Regarding China, a similar majority in both countries want to cooperate more [7]. Specifically, 60% of Germans and 55% of Americans express this desire.
![image1](image1)

Political affiliations also play a role. In the U.S., Democrats are more inclined to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [9].
![image3](image3)

In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens and the SPD [9].

In summary, Germans are more inclined than Americans to seek greater cooperation with Russia, while similar majorities in both countries favor more cooperation with China, with political affiliations influencing these preferences differently within each country.

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly shape perspectives on international cooperation, particularly with Russia and China.

In the U.S., Democrats are more inclined to favor stronger ties with Germany than Republicans [1]. This aligns with the general trend of those on the ideological right in Germany being more favorable towards the U.S. [1].
![Political party preference and cooperation with other countries](image1)

Conversely, Republicans show a greater preference for close relations with Russia compared to Democrats [5].
When it comes to attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, Germans are almost twice as likely as  Americans to want greater collaboration [3].
![Favorability towards having more cooperation with countries](image3)

However, views diverge when considering a rising China. Germans are about  twice as likely to say they prefer  a close relationship to the U.S.  over China, while  Americans are almost equally  divided [6].
Age also plays a role, with younger Americans more likely to prefer a close relationship with China over Germany, a trend not seen in older Americans [10].
![Age and coopreation preference in the US](image2)
In Germany, there's a notable difference between the former East and West regarding Russia. East Germans show significantly more support for a close relationship with Russia than with the U.S., whereas West Germans favor the U.S. [2].
![Germany's preference to coopreate](image4)

Overall, political party preferences in the U.S. and Germany have a clear and distinct impact on attitudes toward cooperation with Russia and China, shaping foreign policy outlooks in both countries.

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia. In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor increased cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [2].

![image1](image1)

In Germany, there are similar trends.
In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are keener on greater cooperation with the U.S. than are the supporters of the Greens and the SPD [3].
Data on the international image of the U.S. indicates that those on the ideological right in Germany are generally more favorable toward the U.S. [3]. Conservative Americans and Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum are more likely than American liberals and Germans on the left to view Russia favorably [9].

In conclusion, political affiliation plays a crucial role, with right-leaning parties in both countries being more open to cooperation with Russia.

Americans and Germans have significantly different views on which country is the world's leading economic power. Half of Americans believe the U.S. is the leading economic power, while a third name China [2]. In contrast, a majority of Germans (53%) identify China as the leading economic power, with only 24% naming the U.S. [2].

![The chart displays the percentage of Americans and Germans who identify the U.S., China, Japan, or the EU as the world's leading economic power.](image4)

This divergence extends to their views on international organizations and other countries. Germans generally hold more positive views of international entities than Americans do [8]. The most significant difference is in their opinions of the EU: around 70% of Germans view the EU favorably, compared to only about half of Americans [8].
![The chart indicates that 69% of Germans have a favorable view of the EU, compared to 51% of Americans.](image5)

Ideological differences within each country also contribute to varying opinions [4].
![The chart shows the ideological breakdown of views on the UN, EU, and Russia among Americans and Germans.](image1)
Specifically, American conservatives are more likely to view Russia favorably than American liberals, while American liberals are more likely to favor the UN and EU than conservatives [4].

There are different views among age groups between the two countries.
![Shows that a higher percentage of younger Germans(18-29) than older prefer China over Germany and a lower percentage of younger Germans prefer Germany over China.](image3)

Regarding cooperation, 69% of Americans want to cooperate more with Germany, while only 50% of Germans feel the same way about the U.S. [3].

In summary, Americans are more likely to see the U.S. as the leading economic power, while Germans view China as the leader, and Germans generally have more favorable views of international organizations like the EU than Americans.

American and German views diverge significantly on international relations and economic power, influenced by political divides and historical contexts.

Americans and Germans hold differing opinions on various international organizations. Germans tend to view these organizations more positively than Americans do [10]. This difference is most evident in their views of the EU, where approximately 70% of Germans are in favor, compared to only about half of Americans [10].
![Favorability towards international organizations](image1)

A similar, though less pronounced, gap exists in perceptions of Russia [10]. While favorable opinions of Russia are less widespread in both countries, there is a notable difference. There is more agreement regarding the UN and NATO, although Germans tend to hold these organizations in higher regard than Americans. [10].

Ideology plays a significant role in these differing views [3].
![Ideological differences between americans and germans](image4)
In both countries, conservatives are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals are more likely to favor the UN and EU [3, 9]. The ideological divide is considerably wider among Americans than among Germans [3].

Perceptions of economic power also differ significantly. Half of Americans name the U.S. as the world's leading economic power, while a majority of Germans (53%) believe China holds that position [7].
![Perception of global economic power.](image2)

In Germany, regional differences also influence opinions. Germans living in former East Germany are more likely to view Russia favorably (43%) and the EU less favorably (59%) than those in the former West, where one-third favor Russia and 71% favor the EU [5].

In summary, Americans and Germans differ in their views of international organizations and economic powers due to ideological divides, historical contexts, and regional differences within Germany.

Americans and Germans have significantly different views on the necessity of military force. About eight-in-ten Americans (78%) believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain world order, whereas only about half of Germans (47%) agree with this sentiment [4, 5].
![image5](image5)

Regarding defense spending, half of Americans believe that European allies should maintain their current defense spending levels [1]. In 2017, 45% of Americans thought their European allies should increase defense spending. In 2019, 35% of American thought their European allies should increase defense spending.
![image1](image1)
Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain their current defense spending, with about 40% supporting each position [5]. Views on defense spending have shifted in both countries since 2017 [5].

Young people in both countries have more positive views of the U.S.-German relationship than older generations [2, 8].
![image4](image4)
In the U.S., 82% of 18-29 year-olds view the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those 65 and older [2]. In Germany, 40% of young people see relations with the U.S. as good, compared to only 31% of those 65 and older [2].

In summary, Americans are more likely to support the use of military force than Germans, who are divided on defense spending; however, younger people in both countries view the U.S.-German relationship more positively.

Americans and Germans have significantly differing views on military intervention and defense spending.

Americans are more likely to support the use of military force to maintain order, with about eight-in-ten holding this view [6]. In contrast, only about half of Germans believe military force is sometimes necessary [6].
![image3](image3)
There are stark differences regarding Article 5 obligations under NATO. Six-in-ten Americans believe their country should use military force to defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack [9].
![image1](image1)
However, an equal share of Germans (60%) say their country should *not* defend a NATO ally in such a scenario [9].

When it comes to defense spending, half of Americans believe European allies should maintain their current spending levels [2].
![image4](image4)
The German public is divided, with about 40% wanting to maintain current spending and another 40% favoring an increase [10]. Views on defense spending have shifted since 2017 in both countries [8, 10].
In the U.S., there's been a decline in the percentage of people who favor increased the defense budgets in Europe [7].
![image5](image5)

In summary, Americans are generally more supportive of military intervention and maintaining defense spending, while Germans are more hesitant about military intervention and divided on whether to increase or maintain defense spending.

Americans' and Germans' opinions on defense spending have shifted over the years, with internal partisan differences affecting these views.

In the U.S., there's been a notable shift in opinion regarding European allies' defense spending. Half of Americans believe that spending levels should stay the same, which is a change from 2017 when 45% felt European allies should increase spending [5]. This trend is visually represented, showing a decrease in Americans who think European allies should increase spending from 45% in 2017 to 35% in 2019, while those who think it should stay the same increased from 37% to 50% in the same period [5].
![Graph showing changing American and German views on defense spending between 2017 and 2019.](image5)

Partisan divisions exist within the U.S., where Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe, although this view has declined among Republicans by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [8].
![Defense spending trend from 2017-2019.](image2)

In Germany, the public is divided between increasing or maintaining current levels of defense spending [7]. There are partisan gaps in Germany as well. Supporters of the CDU/CSU generally favor defense spending increases, while supporters of the Greens are more skeptical, and SPD members fall in between [1].
![Defense spending by party.](image4)

In the US, 60% believe Germany *should* increase spending, compared to only 34% in Germany that believe the same.
![Discrepancy on increasing German national defense.](image1)

In conclusion, American opinion has shifted towards maintaining current defense spending levels among European allies, while German opinion is divided, with notable partisan differences in both countries influencing these views.

Americans' and Germans' views on national defense spending have shifted between 2017 and 2019, with internal partisan differences affecting these opinions.

In the U.S., there's been a notable change in how Americans view their European allies' defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans thought their European allies should increase defense spending [4]. By 2019, this number had dropped, and half of Americans believed that spending levels should remain the same [4].
![Americans and Germans views on whether their country or European Allies should increase, keep the same, or decrease spending on national defense from 2017-2019](image1)
The shift is also evident when looking at partisan lines. While Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe, this view has declined by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [3].
![Changes of American views on defense spending in Europe from 2017 to 2019.](image3)

In Germany, the population is divided on whether to increase or maintain current defense spending levels [7, 10]. In 2017, about half of Germans were content with their country's defense spending, while about a third wanted it increased [10]. By 2019, the views shifted to about four-in-ten supporting each position [10]. There are partisan gaps in Germany as well. Supporters of the CDU/CSU generally favor defense spending increases, while only 28% of Green party supporters want to raise spending, The SPD falls in the middle [9].
![Percentage of Germans who voted for CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens in the 2017 Bundestag elections who say Germany should increase its defense spending.](image5)

In summary, American views have shifted towards favoring the status quo in European defense spending, while Germans are divided between increasing and maintaining spending, with notable partisan differences in both countries.

In the U.S., there's a partisan divide regarding defense spending, with Republicans and Republican-leaning independents more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [3]. However, this support has decreased among Republicans by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019, with a smaller decline among Democrats [3].
![The chart illustrates the change of attitude among Americans and Germans from 2017-2019 regarding defense spending.](image1)

In Germany, partisan gaps also exist [5]. Supporters of the CDU/CSU generally favor increasing defense spending, while Green party supporters are more skeptical, and SPD members fall in between [5].
![The chart depicts the percentage of CDU/CSU, SPD, and Green party supporters in Germany who favor increasing defense spending.](image3)
Specifically, 51% of CDU/CSU supporters, 41% of SPD supporters, and 28% of Green party supporters say Germany should increase defense spending [5].
![The chart details the opinions of Americans and Germans on the importance of U.S. military bases for national security.](image2)

In 2019, 40% of Germans wanted to increase defense spending, 41% wanted to keep it the same and 15% wanted to decrease it [image1].

In conclusion, political affiliations significantly influence opinions on defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany, with conservatives generally more supportive of increases, although this support has declined in the U.S. over time.

There are significant differences in opinion based on age in Germany and political affiliation in the U.S. regarding the perceived importance of U.S. military bases in Germany and the choice of key foreign policy partners.

In Germany, older individuals are more likely to view U.S. military bases as important for German national security [5]. Specifically, 61% of Germans aged 65 and older believe these bases are important, whereas roughly 60% of Germans aged 18 to 29 believe they do not contribute to the country's national security [9]. This difference in perception is visually supported by a graph showing the percentage of Germans who consider U.S. military bases important or not, broken down by age group.
![Percentage of Germans, by age group, who see U.S. military bases in Germany as important or not for German national security.](image5)

In the U.S., political affiliation plays a significant role. While a majority in the US consider US military bases very important, support for the American military presence in Germany is high among both Republicans and Democrats. [10]
![A bar graph shows how Americans and Germans view the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany to German national security.](image3)
However, there are stark differences in their preference for foreign policy partners. Republicans favor Israel more (26%) than Democrats (9%) [4].
![Two bar graphs show the top five foreign policy partners of U.S. Republicans and Democrats.](image4)
Democrats, on the other hand, place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico [4]. Both Republicans and Democrats similarly ranked Germany as their fifth most important partner. [4,7]

In summary, age significantly influences German perceptions of U.S. military bases, with older Germans more likely to see them as important, while political affiliation in the U.S. shapes views on key foreign policy partners, with bipartisan support to Germany, and Republicans prioritizing Israel and Democrats favoring Canada and Mexico.

Americans' views on global engagement and handling of international issues differ significantly based on political affiliation and educational background.

Regarding political affiliation, a substantial majority of Republicans (76%) believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [5, image3]. Democrats, conversely, are more inclined to believe the U.S. should assist other countries, with over half supporting this view [8].
![A bar chart comparing views on whether the U.S. should help other countries or focus on its own problems, broken down by age, education, and political affiliation.](image3)

There are also clear differences based on educational background. A majority (60%) of postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries, college graduates are evenly split, while a majority of those with some college or less education think the U.S. should focus on internal issues [10].

Opinions of how well the U.S. is doing in dealing with the coronavirus outbreak are most divided along party lines [9].
![A bar chart comparing views on whether the U.S. did a 'only fair/poor' or 'good/excellent' job handling the coronavirus outbreak, broken down by age, education, and political affiliation.](image4)
Whereas around three-quarters of Democrats and Democratic- leaning independents are critical of the U.S.’s response  (73%)  , similar shares of Republicans  and Republican-leaning independents praise the country’s handling of the outbreak  (71%)  [9].

In summary, Republicans and those with less education tend to favor the U.S. focusing on domestic issues, while Democrats and those with higher education are more supportive of international engagement.

Americans' views on how the U.S. and China handled the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly shaped by their political affiliations and, to a lesser extent, their educational backgrounds.

A strong partisan divide exists in evaluating the U.S. response. Republicans overwhelmingly praised the U.S.'s handling of the outbreak (71%), while Democrats were largely critical (73%) [3, 10]. This partisan gap is visually represented in a chart showing a 44-point difference between Republican/Lean Republican and Democrat/Lean Democrat views on the U.S. response.
![A chart depicting the partisan divide in perceptions of various countries' handling of COVID-19, highlighting a significant 44-point difference between Democrats and Republicans regarding the U.S. response.](image2)
In contrast, perceptions of China's response were more uniformly negative across party lines, though still with a noticeable difference.
![A chart presenting data on how different demographics, including political affiliations, perceive China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.](image3)
A majority in all educational groups believe that china has not handled the pandemic well [4]. Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe China has not done a good job [6].

Education plays a more significant role in evaluating the U.S. response than China's. More educated Americans, especially those with postgraduate degrees, were far more critical of the U.S. response compared to those with a high school education or less [2]. The data is shown on the chart:
![A chart detailing public opinion on China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, segmented by various demographic factors, including age, education, and political affiliation.](image3)

In summary, political affiliation is the primary factor influencing perceptions of the U.S. response to the pandemic, with a stark divide between Republicans and Democrats, while education level plays a secondary but still notable role, and evaluations of China's response are largely negative across all groups, but there are still difference between political affiliations.

Americans' views on how the U.S. and China handled the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly influenced by their political affiliations [2].

Regarding the U.S. response, there's a stark partisan divide. A substantial majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (71%) believe the U.S. did a good or excellent job, while only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents agree [8]. This difference is visually represented in a chart.
![A chart comparing how democrats and republicans view the handling of COVID.](image2)

The perception of China's handling of the pandemic also shows partisan differences, though less extreme [9]. While majorities in both parties believe China did not handle the pandemic well, Republicans are more likely to hold this view [9]. A detailed breakdown of these views by political affiliation is shown in a graph.
![Data on the response to how China handled COVID.](image3)

In summary, political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of the U.S. and China's COVID-19 responses, with Republicans generally viewing the U.S. response more favorably and China's response more negatively than Democrats.

Americans' views on whether the U.S. can learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus outbreak, and their trust in international organizations, differ significantly based on political affiliation.

There's a broad consensus that the U.S. can learn something from other countries, but the extent of this learning varies greatly between Democrats and Republicans [5, 6]. A majority of Democrats (60%) believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal," while only 28% of Republicans agree [6]. This difference is even more pronounced between liberal Democrats (67%) and conservative Republicans (25%) [5].

This difference in perception correlates with how well people think the U.S. is handling the outbreak. Those who think the U.S. can learn from other countries tend to rate the U.S. response less positively [1, 7]. Fewer than half (44%) of those open to learning from abroad rate the U.S. response as "excellent" or "good," compared to 63% of those who don't think the U.S. can learn much [1].
![image1](image1)

Trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU also varies significantly along partisan lines [9, 10].
![image2](image2)
 A large majority of liberal Democrats (86%) trust information from the WHO, while only 27% of conservative Republicans do [10]. Similar divides, though less extreme, exist for trust in the EU [10]. Overall, majorities trust information from the EU and WHO, but are wary of information from the Chinese government [4].
![image4](image4)

In conclusion, Democrats are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries and trust international organizations like the WHO and EU, while Republicans are more skeptical of both.

Americans' views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level.

Regarding China, half of Americans believe its influence will decline post-coronavirus, with about a third expecting no change and nearly one-fifth predicting growth [6]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to foresee a decrease in China's global influence (60% vs. 40%) [1]. Age also plays a role, with older Americans (65+) being 16 percentage points more likely than younger ones (under 30) to predict a decline in China's influence [1].
![image5](image5) shows the breakdown of views on China's future influence.

For the U.S., the public is split: about 30% believe U.S. influence will increase, 30% believe it will decrease, and 40% see it remaining the same [4]. There's a clear partisan divide, Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to predict an increase in U.S. influence, and, Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to foresee a decrease in American influence [3].
![image1](image1)

Education also has an impact. Americans with higher levels of education are more prone to predict a reduction in the country's global influence [10].
![image1](image1) shows that 45% of postgraduates and 37% of college graduates anticipate less U.S. influence.

As for the EU, fewer Americans predict a decline in its influence compared to China [2].
![image3](image3) provides a comparative overview, indicating that 21% of Americans believe the EU will have less influence.

In summary, Republicans and older Americans are more likely to anticipate a decline in China's influence, while Democrats and those with higher education are more likely to predict a decrease in U.S. influence.

Americans are divided on how the coronavirus outbreak will affect the global influence of the U.S. and China, with significant differences across demographic and political groups.

Regarding the U.S., there's a clear partisan gap. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened [1]. Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken [1]. There are also internal divisions within the Democratic party, with liberal Democrats being 20 percentage points more likely than conservative and moderate Democrats to predict a decline in U.S. influence [1].
![Predictions for U.S. influence post-coronavirus, by political affiliation and education level.](image1)

Education level is a factor, too. Americans with higher levels of education are more likely to think that U.S. global influence will decrease [9]. For instance, 45% of postgraduates predict a decline, compared to only 21% of those with a high school education or less.

When it comes to China, half of Americans believe its influence will decline [3].
![Predictions for U.S., EU, and China influence post-coronavirus.](image2)
There's a large partisan divide, with roughly 60% of Republicans believing China’s international clout will diminish, while just 40% of Democrats say the same [4].
![Predictions for China's influence post-coronavirus, by demographic and political groups.](image4)
Age also plays a role, with older Americans (65+) being 16 percentage points more likely than younger ones (under 30) to say China will have less global influence [4]. These views reflect broader trends, as older Americans and Republicans are more likely to hold negative opinions of China [7].

In summary, predictions about post-coronavirus global influence vary significantly: Republicans and less-educated individuals tend to foresee a stronger U.S. and weaker China, while Democrats, more-educated individuals, and younger people are more inclined to anticipate a weakened U.S. and are less certain about a decline in China's influence.

Americans generally view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decline in its global influence, with notable differences between Republican and Democratic viewpoints.

Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe China has handled the coronavirus outbreak poorly [3]. This negative perception is even stronger among Republicans, with eight-in-ten conservative Republicans holding this view [7].

![image5](image5)

This sentiment extends to how Americans perceive China's future role on the world stage. Half of Americans believe China's influence will decline after the coronavirus outbreak [2], with a partisan divide on this, as 60% of Republicans believe China's influence will decrease, compared to only 40% of Democrats [5].

![image3](image3)

Republicans are consistently more negative in their attitudes toward China [4], which aligns with broader trends indicating a rise in unfavorable views of China among Americans [9]. The overall negative attitudes toward China reached 66% [9].
In addtion, a partisan divide on the question of trust of information provided.

![image2](image2)

The graph indicates that 84% of survey respondents answered "Not too much/not at all".

The trend of negative views has been increasing since 2018.

![image4](image4)

In conclusion, most Americans view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak unfavorably and expect its global influence to diminish, with Republicans expressing significantly more negative views than Democrats.

Americans exhibit significant partisan divisions regarding the U.S.'s role in addressing global challenges and its anticipated influence following the coronavirus outbreak [6, 7].

A considerable partisan gap exists, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to believe the U.S. does too much in helping solve global issues [5]. Specifically, 62% of Republicans believe the U.S. overextends itself in addressing global challenges, compared to only 26% of Democrats [5]. This partisan divide has widened considerably compared to previous Pew Research Center surveys dating back to 2013 [5].
![image4](image4)

The trend data from 2013 to 2020 highlights the increasing divergence in partisan views [4]. The percentage of Republicans believing the U.S. is doing "too much" has dramatically increased, while the percentage of Democrats with the same view has slightly decreased.
![image5](image5)

There is also a sharp distinction between Republicans and Democrats on how the U.S. will be affected after the coronavirus.
![image2](image2)

In conclusion, partisan views differ significantly on the U.S. role in world affairs, with Republicans more likely to favor a focus on domestic problems, while there is a division about American influence post-coronavirus with Democrats are four times more likely than Republicans to expect weaker influence .

Americans, across the political spectrum, largely believe the U.S. can learn from other countries about slowing the spread of coronavirus [1, 5, 7]. However, there are significant partisan divisions in the *degree* to which they hold this belief [8].

![A chart illustrating how much the U.S. can learn from other countries regarding coronavirus.](image1)

Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more likely to believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal" (60%) compared to Republicans and Republican leaners (28%) [8]. This partisan divide is further illustrated by the difference between liberal Democrats (67%) and conservative Republicans (25%) who believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations [4].

![A breakdown of opinions across different political affiliations.](image5)

The survey reveals broader partisan and ideological differences related to foreign policy and international affairs [6]. For example, 81% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has done a poor job handling the outbreak, compared to just 22% of conservative Republicans [6]. Additionally, liberal Democrats are far more likely (56%) to believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic, a view shared by a much smaller percentage of conservative Republicans (8%) [6]. There's also a substantial difference of opinion on whether the U.S. should help other countries, with 64% of liberal Democrats in favor, compared to significantly lower percentages among other groups [10]. Education level, in addition to partisanship, acts as a significant dividing line on these issues [2, 9].

In summary, while most Americans agree that the U.S. can learn from other countries about managing the coronavirus, Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal and are also more likely to believe the U.S. has handled the pandemic poorly and will have diminished global influence as a result.

Americans' views on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or assist other countries differ significantly based on political affiliation and educational attainment [2, 9].

In general, a majority of Americans (60%) believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries handle theirs as best they can [2].
![{A chart showing that 60% of Americans believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems.}](image1)

*   **Political Affiliation**: There's a stark contrast between Republicans and Democrats on this issue. About three-quarters of Republicans (76%) prefer the U.S. to concentrate on its own problems, while only 23% believe the U.S. should help other countries. [6, image1]
*   Among Democrats, a smaller 46% say the U.S. should deal with its problems and let other countries deal with their own problems [4,image1].
*    There are difference of opinion with in Democrats based on ideology: 64% of liberal Democrats support helping other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [4].

*   **Educational Level**: Support for helping other nations is higher among those with more education [9].
*   Postgraduates are the most likely to say the U.S. should help other countries (60%), while those with a high school diploma or less are the least likely (29%) to hold that opinion. College graduates are evenly divided, at 49% [9, image1].

In summary, Republicans and those with lower levels of education are more likely to favor the U.S. focusing on its own problems, while Democrats (especially liberal Democrats) and those with higher education levels are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other countries.

Americans' perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems differ significantly by political affiliation, with these differences becoming more pronounced over time.

A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [3]. This sentiment is visually represented in a graph showing the trend over time, where the percentage of those who think the U.S. does "too much" has risen to 62% by 2020. ![Republicans: The U.S. does too much to help solve world problems](image3)
In contrast, a plurality of Democrats (48%) believe the U.S. does too little [3].

Furthermore, a significant partisan divide exists regarding whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries. About three-quarters of Republicans prefer the U.S. to deal with its own problems [8], while over half of Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries [7]. This partisan divide is also shown.
![Partisan divide whether the U.S. should focus on its problems or help other countires](image2)
The partisan divide in these views was far less pronounced in previous years than it is today [6].

In conclusion, perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems differ significantly by political affiliation, with Republicans more likely to believe the U.S. does too much and should focus on its own problems, and Democrats more likely to believe the U.S. does too little and should help other countries, and these differences have widened over time.

There are significant partisan differences in views on U.S. global engagement and the prioritization of domestic issues.

Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [1, 3]. A majority, 62%, hold this view, compared to only 8% who say it does too little [3]. In contrast, a plurality of Democrats (48%) believe the U.S. does too little to help solve world problems [3].
![image4](image4)
This partisan divide is reflected that a significant majority of Republicans (76%) prefer the U.S. to focus on its own problems, as shown below [10].
![image1](image1)

Democrats are more divided, with a slight majority (53%) saying the U.S. should help other countries, and 46% saying the U.S. should focus on its own problems. Among Democrats, there's an ideological split. 64% of liberal Democrats favor helping other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [5].

Educational attainment also plays a role. Those with higher levels of education are more supportive of helping other nations [6]. Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries with their problems. There is less support, and more preference to focusing on own problems, among those with some or no college education [6].
![image1](image1)

In summary, Republicans are more likely to favor the U.S. focusing on domestic issues and believe it does too much globally, while Democrats, especially liberal Democrats and those with higher education, are more inclined to support international engagement.

Americans generally express more concern about specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship than they express confidence in Biden's ability to handle them.

Around half of Americans (53%) have confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China [2]. This is the lowest confidence level among six tested foreign policy issues.
![Americans’ confidence in Biden’s ability to deal with various foreign policy issues.](image1)
However, when asked about specific problems in the U.S.-China relationship, higher percentages of Americans rate these as "very serious":
*   Cyberattacks from China: 65% [10, ![{Americans’ view on the seriousness of specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship.}](image4)]
*   China's growing military power: 52%[10, ![{Americans’ view on the seriousness of specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship.}](image4)]
*    The loss of U.S. jobs to China: 53%[10,![{Americans’ view on the seriousness of specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship.}](image4)]
*   China's policies on human rights: 50% [10, ![{Americans’ view on the seriousness of specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship.}](image4)]

Americans view specific problems with China as very serious, at rates that exceed the percentage expressing confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China.

Americans express a variety of concerns regarding China, and confidence in President Biden's ability to effectively address these concerns varies significantly across demographic groups.

A majority of Americans (53%) have confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China. [2] This confidence, however, is the lowest among six issues tested, including improving relationships with allies and dealing with terrorism. [2]

![Confidence in Biden's Ability to Deal Effectively with China by Demographic](image2)

Confidence levels differ considerably based on demographics such as gender, race, age, education, and political affiliation:
*   **Gender**: Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%) in Biden's ability to deal with China. [10, ![Confidence in Biden's Ability to Deal Effectively with China by Demographic](image2)]
*   **Race**: Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express significantly more confidence than White adults (43%). [10, ![Confidence in Biden's Ability to Deal Effectively with China by Demographic](image2)]
*   **Education**: College graduates (60%) show higher confidence levels than those without a college degree (50%).[10, ![Confidence in Biden's Ability to Deal Effectively with China by Demographic](image2)]
*   **Political Affiliation**: There's a stark partisan divide, with 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents having confidence in Biden on China, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents. [3, ![Confidence in Biden's Ability to Deal Effectively with China by Demographic](image2)]

Americans have substantial concerns about eight specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship. [5]

![Americans' Concerns Regarding China](image3)

The most pressing concerns, considered "very serious" by half or more of the respondents, are:
*   Cyberattacks from China. [5]
*   The loss of U.S. jobs to China. [5]
*   China's growing military power. [5]
*   China's human rights policies. [5]

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies significantly across demographic groups, with women, Black and Hispanic adults, college graduates, and Democrats expressing higher confidence, while major concerns regarding China include cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Americans express significant concerns about various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship, with certain issues standing out as particularly serious. These include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [5].
The share of Americans who see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem has increased since 2020 [7].

![The most serious concerns are cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.](image4)

Confidence in President Biden's ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic and political groups. There is a large partisan divide, with 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents expressing confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [4, 8].

![Confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China shows a significant partisan divide.](image3)

Within the Republican party, conservative Republicans (10%) have even less confidence than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [4]. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%) [6]. Individuals with a college degree also show higher confidence in Biden's ability compared to those with less education (60% vs. 50%, respectively) [6].

In summary, confidence in Biden's handling of China is high among Democrats, women, Black and Hispanic adults, and college-educated individuals, while concerns about cyberattacks, job losses, China's military power, and human rights are considered the most serious issues.

Americans express substantial concern regarding various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship, with confidence in President Biden's ability to handle the situation varying significantly across demographic groups [10].

Key concerns include cyberattacks from China, job losses to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [10].
  *  Cyberattacks are the top concern, with roughly two-thirds of Americans viewing them as a "very serious" problem [7].
  *  Job losses to China and China's increasing military strength are also major worries [8].
  *  About half the respondants regard China's human rights policies very serious problem [10].
  *  ![Major concerns for Americans regarding China](image2)

Confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China effectively is marked by significant partisan divisions [2, 3].
  *  A large majority of Democrats (83%) have confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, compared to only 19% of Republicans [3].
  *   Among Republicans, conservatives express even less confidence (10%) than moderates or liberals (30%) [3].

![Confidence levels in Biden regarding China, broken down by demographic groups](image1)

Other demographic differences also shape views [6]:
*   Older Americans (65+) are at least 20 percentage points more likely to see most China-related issues as "very serious problems".
*   Americans with less than a college degree are more concerned about the trade deficit with China and the loss of U.S. jobs to China than those with a college degree or higher [5].

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies significantly by political affiliation and other demographics, with major concerns centered on cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Americans hold negative views of China's actions in several key areas. Regarding the COVID-19 pandemic, over half of Americans believe China has done a bad job handling the outbreak (54%) [7]. This negative perception extends to China's respect for personal freedoms, with a significant majority (90%) of Americans believing that the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [6].

![90% of American think China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people.](image1)

This view is consistent across various demographics, including age, education, and political affiliation [6].

![More Americans think China has done a bad job than a good job in dealing with the pandemic.](image2)

In terms of priorities in the U.S.-China relationship, a substantial majority of Americans (70%) believe that the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations.
![70% of American think US should promote human rights, even if it harms economic relations.](image3)
Only 26% think economic relations should be prioritized [].

In summary, Americans view China's handling of COVID-19 negatively, overwhelmingly believe China does not respect personal freedoms, and prioritize human rights over economic relations in the bilateral relationship.

Americans across the political spectrum prioritize human rights over economic ties with China, though there are nuances in this view based on political affiliation [3].

A significant majority of Americans (70%) believe that the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [3].
![image3](image3)

This sentiment is largely shared by both Democrats and Republicans [6].
Among Republicans, conservative Republicans (77%) are more likely than moderate or liberal Republicans (66%) to prioritize human rights [![image3](image3)].
Among Democrats, liberal Democrats (76%) are the most likely to emphasize human rights over economic dealings [!,[image3](image3)].

When it comes to economic and trade policies, more Americans prefer the U.S. to get tougher with China rather than build a stronger relationship [9].
![image2](image2)

This view is particularly strong among Republicans (72%), especially conservative Republicans (81%) [9]. In contrast, about 60% of Democrats prefer building stronger ties with China [9].

In summary, most Americans, regardless of political affiliation, prioritize human rights over economic relations with China, with conservative Republicans being the most likely to support this stance and Democrats more inclined towards building stronger economic ties.

Americans, regardless of political affiliation, largely prioritize human rights over economic ties with China, though views on how to approach trade issues differ significantly between parties.

A significant majority of Americans (70%) believe the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [7]. This sentiment is shared by both Democrats and Republicans [10].

![image1](image1)

The breakdown by political affiliation is as follows: 72% of Republicans/Lean Republican and 69% of Democrats/Lean Democrat prioritize human rights. Even when broken down further, conservative Republicans (77%), moderate/liberal Republicans (66%), conservative/moderate Democrats (64%), and liberal Democrats (76%) all show a strong majority in favor of human rights [!\[image1](image1)].

However, when it comes to economic and trade policy towards China, opinions diverge along party lines [6]. A majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (72%) want the U.S. to "get tougher" with China on economic issues, while about 60% of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents would rather focus on "building stronger ties" [6].

![image5](image5)

Specifically, 81% of Conservative Republicans, 58% of Mod/Lib Rep,37% of Cons/Mod,38% of Liberal. prefer a tougher stance [!\[image5](image5)].
These numbers reflect a clear partisan divide on whether to prioritize confrontation or cooperation with China on trade, despite broad agreement on prioritizing human rights.

In conclusion, while both Democrats and Republicans in the U.S. prioritize human rights over economic relations with China, Republicans are significantly more likely to favor a tougher stance on trade issues compared to Democrats.

Americans' views on trade policies with China and their preferred approach (getting tougher vs. building stronger relationships) vary significantly based on political affiliation.

Republicans and Republican-leaning independents overwhelmingly favor a tougher stance on China. [1] Specifically, 72% want the U.S. to get tougher on China, with this sentiment being even stronger among conservative Republicans (81%). [1]
![image1](image1)
In terms of tariffs ,about half of Republicans believe that increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products were beneficial for the U.S. [2]
![image5](image5)

On the other hand, Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents generally prefer building stronger ties with China. [1] About 60% express this preference, and this view is relatively consistent across the liberal and moderate/conservative wings of the Democratic Party. [1] Democrats tend to view tariffs negatively. [2]
![image5](image5)

Overall, While President Biden has described China as America’s “most serious competitor” , A majority of Americans (64%) believe current economic relations between the U.S. and China are bad. [3, 6]
![image2](image2)
There are clear partisan divisions regarding U.S. trade policy with China.

Americans from different political affiliations have varying perspectives on the impacts of tariffs and international students.

Regarding tariffs, Republicans generally view tariffs on Chinese and other foreign goods positively [1]. About half of Republicans believe these tariffs are good for the U.S., with conservative Republicans holding this view more strongly [10].
![image3](image3)
In contrast, Democrats mostly believe that tariffs are bad for the U.S. [10].

When it comes to international students, a large majority of Americans (80%) believe it is good for U.S. colleges and universities to accept international students [9].
![image1](image1)
However, there's a partisan divide: 92% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents view international students positively, compared to 67% of Republicans and Republican leaners [2]. A majority of Americans (55%) support limiting the number of Chinese students studying in the U.S., showing more division on this specific issue [8].
![image5](image5)

In summary, Republicans tend to view tariffs positively and are more divided on international students, while Democrats largely view tariffs negatively but strongly support the presence of international students in the U.S.

Americans' views on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations [3, 7]. A majority of Americans (55%) support limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S [6]. This sentiment is particularly strong among older Americans and Republicans [3].

![Support and opposition to limiting Chinese students in the U.S. by age, education, and political affiliation.](image4)

Specifically, roughly 70% of Americans aged 50 and older favor limitations, while nearly two-thirds of those aged 18-29 oppose the idea [3]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor these restrictions [3].

This division also correlates with confidence levels in Chinese President Xi Jinping. Older Americans, who are more likely to support limiting Chinese students, also express greater distrust in Xi [10].

![Confidence levels in Chinese President Xi Jinping across various demographics.](image1)

For instance, 53% of those 65 and older have no confidence at all in Xi, compared to 35% of those aged 18-29 [10]. There are also some differences across partisan group [4]. Democrats have slightly more confidence in Xi; only a third say they have no confidence at all in the Chinese president [5].

In summary, older Americans and Republicans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities and express lower confidence in Chinese leadership, while younger Americans and Democrats tend to oppose such limitations and have relatively more confidence in Xi.

American perceptions of China have become significantly more negative from 2018 to 2021, driven by concerns over human rights, economic issues, and China's growing power and influence.

A majority of Americans (67%) reported feeling "cold" toward China in 2021, a substantial increase from 46% in 2018 [8]. This negative trend is evident across party lines, although it is more pronounced among Republicans [7].
![Graph showing increase in negative views towards China from 2018-2021](image2)

Specific concerns include:

*   **Human Rights:** Half of Americans view China's human rights policies as a "very serious problem" for the U.S., a 7-point increase since 2020 [1, 6]. One-in-five Americans specifically mention human rights concerns when asked about China [10].
![what comes to mind about china.](image3)
*    **Economic Relations:** Around two-thirds (64%) of Americans describe the economic relationship between the U.S. and China as "somewhat or very bad" [9].
*    **China's Power and Influence:** 48% of Americans believe limiting China's power and influence should be a top foreign policy priority, a 16 percentage point increase since 2018 [4].
*   **Prioritizing human rights**: A large share of American think US should prioritize human rights even it harms the economy.
![Americans want to prioritize Human rights.](image1)

In summary, American perceptions of China have worsened considerably between 2018 and 2021, fueled by a combination of human rights concerns, economic anxieties, and worries about China's increasing global influence.

Americans have several key concerns regarding China, and some of these concerns have intensified over time [10].

The most prominent issues, identified as "very serious" by at least half of Americans, include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights [9].

![Chart showing increasing concerns from 2020 to 2021 about China](image1)

As illustrated in the chart, concern has grown from 2020 to 2021. For instance, the percentage of Americans who view cyberattacks from China as a very serious problem increased from 58% to 65% [image1]. Similarly, those concerned about China's human rights policies rose from 43% to 50%, and the percentage worried about the loss of U.S. jobs to China increased from 47% to 53% [image1]. China's growing technological power is another major concern, which has increased over the past year [10].

![Top concerns of Americans regarding China include human rights and economy](image4)

When thinking of China, human rights and the economy are top of mind for American [2, image4].

In summary, Americans' main concerns about China include cyberattacks, job losses, military and technological growth, and human rights, with several of these concerns intensifying over the past year.

Financial optimism among Latinos has significantly increased since 2008, with variations across different subgroups.

Since 2008, most Latino subgroups have become more optimistic about their finances [1]. Optimism among Latinos has risen faster than in the general population. Specifically, 81% of Latinos expect their family finances to improve in the coming year, marking a 14-percentage point increase since 2008. In contrast, 61% of all Americans share this view, a 6-percentage point rise during the same period [9].

![Financial Optimism Among Hispanic Subgroups](image1)

The increase in financial optimism from 2008 to 2015 is evident across various demographic groups. For instance, optimism rose by 18 percentage points among Latino men and 11 percentage points among Latina women [6]. Both U.S.-born and immigrant Hispanics saw an increase of 14 percentage points in those expecting financial improvement [6].

![Financial Optimism Comparison: Hispanics vs. General Population](image3)

Economic optimism has grown roughly twice as fast since 2008 among Latinos who had completed some college (+20 percentage points) than among those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [2].
The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve “a lot” or “some” in the coming year is up 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 – during the Great Recession – and in 2011 to 81% in 2015 [9].

In conclusion, from 2008 to 2015, financial optimism among different Hispanic subgroups has significantly increased, surpassing the growth rate observed in the general population.

Hispanics are generally optimistic about their children's financial futures [7]. A significant majority (72%) believe their children will be better off financially than they are [2, 6]. This optimism is prevalent across different groups, including immigrants (75%) and U.S.-born adults (70%) [6].

However, current financial situations and educational levels do influence these expectations. Hispanics with a positive view of their current finances are more likely to believe their family's finances will improve in the next year [3].
![Expectations of financial improvement among Hispanics based on their current financial condition.](image2)

Educational attainment also plays a role. While the majority across all educational levels expect their children to be better off, high school graduates (79%) are more optimistic than those with some college experience (69%) or less than a high school education (71%) [5].
![Data table showing how financial expectations for children vary among Hispanics based on educational attainment and other demographics.](image5)

In conclusion, while most Hispanics are optimistic about their children's financial future, those with better current financial situations and those who are high school graduates tend to be the most optimistic.

Latinos have shown a significant increase in optimism regarding their financial well-being, particularly since 2011. The share of Latinos who expected their finances to improve rose from 67% in 2011 to 81% in 2015 [2, 7]. This increasing optimism is reflected visually:

![The graph shows the percentage of Hispanics who expect their family finances to improve, increasing from 67% in 2011 to 81% in 2015.](image4)

In contrast, the share of all Americans sharing this optimistic view increased by a smaller margin during the same period [7].

However, the actual economic data presents a mixed picture. While the unemployment rate for Latinos has improved since the Great Recession, it hasn't returned to its pre-recession lows [6].

![The graph shows the quarterly unemployment rate for Hispanics and non-Hispanics, indicating that Hispanic unemployment, while decreasing, remains higher than for non-Hispanics.](image5)

The Hispanic unemployment rate peaked at 12.8% in 2010 and decreased to 6.4% by the end of 2015, but it still remained above the 5% low of 2006 [6].
In 2014 the median household income for Hispanics was $42,491 [1].
![The graph shows that the median household income of Hispanics was \$42,500 in 2014.](image1)

In summary, while perceptions of financial well-being among Latinos have significantly improved, with a large majority expecting improvement, the unemployment trends, though improved, still show a gap compared to pre-recession levels and non-Hispanic workers.

Here's an analysis of the trends in unemployment, economic perceptions, income, and wealth disparities between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations:

**Unemployment Rate Trends:**

*   The Hispanic unemployment rate has significantly improved since the Great Recession, dropping from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [6].
*   However, it remains above its pre-recession low of 5% (fourth quarter of 2006) and is still higher than that of non-Hispanic workers [6].
*    The detailed quarterly unemployment rates are shown here:
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image5)

**Economic Perceptions:**

*   Hispanics are more optimistic about national economic conditions than whites. 35% of Hispanics reported that economic conditions were good or excellent, compared to 25% of whites [9].
*    A higher share of Hispanic people think current economic situation is excellent or good compared to the general public.
![% saying current economic situation is excellent/good](image1)
*   One-third (34%) of Hispanics expect U.S. economic conditions to improve in the coming year, about double the share of other groups of Americans [9].
*   Fully 72% expect their children will be better off financially than they are [5].
![% of Latinos who say, in their lifetime, their  children will be ... financially than they  themselves are now](image3)

**Income and Wealth Disparities:**

*   Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, at $42,491 in 2014 [3].
*   The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, lower than the 2010 peak of 26.5%, but still above pre-recession levels [3].

*   The income and poverty of hispanic compared to all households can be described as below:

![Median household income, Poverty rate, Median household wealth](image2)
*   Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 and, unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [3].
*   There are notable differences in financial ratings among Hispanic subgroups,. Latinos with some college experience or who are U.S.-born gave higher ratings to their personal financial situation [4].
*   81% of Hispanic think their personal finance will be improved, which is higher than the general public.
![% saying personal finances will improve in next year](image4)

**Impact:**
The impacts are complex. Hispanics show a larger decline on wealth and stagnated income [3], but more optimism [9] might reflect the significant job growth within the community and the expectation of upward mobility for their children [5].

In conclusion, while Hispanics have experienced improvements in unemployment, income stagnation and wealth disparities persist, though they remain more optimistic about future economic conditions compared to non-Hispanics.

The economic challenges faced by Hispanic households present a mixed picture when compared to all U.S. households, with some areas showing improvement and others stagnation or decline.

In terms of unemployment, the Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, dropping from 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [1].

![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image5)

However, it remains higher than the rate for non-Hispanic workers and above its 2006 low of 5% [1].
In 2014, the median household income for Hispanics was $42,491, which was essentially unchanged since the Great Recession, similar to the trend for the U.S. public as a whole [7].

![Median household income, poverty rate, and median household wealth for Hispanic and all households from 2000 to 2014.](image2)

The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, lower than the peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels, mirroring the situation for all Americans [7].
Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in their net worth through 2009, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [7].
Although about half of all Hispanic adults said they were falling behind financially, as did the U.S. public overall [5].
![How the cost of living compares by family income and race or ethnicity between 2014 and 2015.](image3)

Latinos are more optimistic compared with 2004.
![Ratings of personal finances among Hispanics and the general public between 2004 and 2015.](image1)

In conclusion, Hispanic households face greater economic challenges than U.S. households overall, with higher unemployment and poverty rates, and a lower median household income, despite showing some improvements since the Great Recession.

From 2008 to 2015, Latino groups generally experienced a positive shift in their perceptions of personal financial situations, with significant gains across various demographics [1, 7, 8].

In 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos reported that their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living, while 37% said their income was staying about even, and 10% reported it was going up faster than the cost of living [3]. This distribution of views remained relatively unchanged between 2014 and 2015 [4].

![Hispanic family income relative to the cost of living was reported nearly identically in 2014 and 2015.](image1)

However, there's a marked improvement when looking at the broader period from before the recession. Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004 [9].
![The chart shows that since 2008, Hispanics have a more positive outlook on their financial situation than general public.](image2)

The data indicates a substantial increase in positive financial ratings among most Latino demographic subgroups [10]. For instance, among Latinos aged 18 to 29, 48% reported being in excellent or good financial shape in 2015, a 27 percentage point increase from 2008 [6].
![From 2008 to 2015, the all Latinos group saw their financial ratings increase by 17 percentage points](image3)

In Summary, Perceptions of personal financial situations among Latino groups have generally improved from 2008 to 2015, although a significant portion still felt their income was not keeping up with the cost of living.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ significantly from the general adult population, with notable trends in their daily internet habits.

Seniors are less likely to own smartphones and tablets or e-readers compared to the general adult population. Specifically, while 55% of all adults own a smartphone, only 18% of seniors (65+) do. Similarly, for tablets or e-readers, the ownership rate is 43% for all adults compared to 27% for seniors [10].
![Smartphone and tablet ownership rates differ significantly between all adults and seniors (65+).](image3)

Broadband and internet usage also show marked differences. Among all adults, 70% use broadband and 86% use the internet, whereas for seniors, the figures are 47% and 59% respectively.
![Broadband and internet usage rates are notably lower for seniors (65+) compared to all adults.](image5)

Internet use and broadband adoption among seniors decreases significantly starting at approximately age 75 [5].
![Internet and broadband adoption rates decline sharply for seniors aged 75 and older.](image2)

Despite lower overall adoption rates, seniors who do use the internet tend to incorporate it into their daily routines. Among older adults who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [4].
![Frequency of internet usage among different age groups, with seniors (65+) showing a high daily usage rate.](image1)
About 27% of the total older adult population uses social networking sites, such as Facebook [3, 9].
![27% of seniors use social networking sites (SNS), while 32% go online but do not use SNS, and 41% do not go online at all.](image4)

In summary, seniors have lower rates of internet usage and device ownership compared to the general adult population, but those seniors who do go online tend to use the internet very frequently.

Older adults' device ownership significantly impacts their internet usage patterns, with variations in adoption rates and usage frequency.

While a majority of older adults (77%) own a cell phone, these are generally basic devices, and only 18% own smartphones [5]. This contrasts with the general population, where smartphone ownership is much higher [5]. However, the ownership of tablets and e-book readers among older adults is on par with smartphone ownership, at 18% [7]. In fact, a larger proportion of older adults (27%) own either a tablet or an e-book reader, or both, compared to those owning a smartphone [7].
![Smartphone vs tablet or e-reader adoption among older adults vs all adults](image4)

Internet usage among older adults has been steadily increasing, with 59% reporting using the internet [3]. This is a significant increase from previous years but still trails the general population's usage rate [3].
![Internet use over time, 2000-2012](image1)

Among older adults who do use the internet, a large majority (71%) go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [10].
![Frequency of internet use by age group.](image2)

In summary, although smartphone ownership is relatively low among older adults compared to the general population, their adoption of tablets and e-readers is comparable to their smartphone usage, and those who use the Internet do so regularly.

Internet and technology usage among seniors (adults aged 65 and older) differs significantly from the general adult population, although trends show increasing adoption over time for both groups.

In terms of overall internet usage, 59% of seniors report using the internet [4], compared to 86% of all U.S. adults [4]. This disparity is visually represented by a graph showing internet adoption over time, with seniors consistently lagging behind the general adult population.
![Internet adoption trends over time for seniors vs. all adults.](image4)
Broadband adoption at home shows 47% for all aged 65+ [image1]

Smartphone adoption is notably lower among seniors. Only 18% of seniors are smartphone adopters, significantly below the national average of 55% [1].
![Smartphone and tablet/e-reader adoption rates for adults and seniors.](image3)
Tablet and e-reader ownership is also lower among seniors. 27% of older adults own a tablet, an e-book reader, or both [5].

A pie chart illustrates the breakdown of seniors' online activity:
![A pie chart showing the percentage of seniors using SNS, going online without SNS, and not going online.](image2)
27% use social networking sites (SNS) [2], 32% go online but do not use SNS, and 41% do not go online at all.

However, certain subgroups of seniors show high rates of internet and broadband adoption [6].
![Data table on seniors' online and broadband usage based on age, education, and income.](image1)
For example, 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, and 65% have broadband at home [image1]. Seniors with higher education and income levels also exhibit higher adoption rates, with 87% of college graduates and 90% of those with an annual household income of $75,000+ going online [image1].

In summary, device ownership and online activity are generally lower among seniors compared to the general adult population, but internet adoption rates for both groups, including seniors, have steadily increased over time.

Device ownership and online social networking habits among seniors show distinct trends. While a significant portion of seniors do not go online, a notable percentage utilizes social networking sites (SNS) [2].

Specifically, 27% of older adults use social networking sites [7]. This is further illustrated by a pie chart showing the breakdown of online and social media usage among seniors:

![A pie chart shows that 27% of seniors use social networking sites.](image2)

Regarding device ownership, seniors are more likely to own a tablet or e-book reader than a smartphone [9]. The data shows that 27% of seniors own a tablet or e-reader, compared to 18% who own a smartphone:

![A bar graph shows that 27% of seniors own a tablet or e-reader, while 18% own a smartphone.](image1)

Although internet usage among seniors is lower than the national average, a significant minority uses social media [1, 2].

In summary, while a smaller percentage of seniors own smartphones compared to tablets or e-readers, a notable portion of them actively engage in social networking.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income, and generally, these rates are lower than those of the general adult population [5].

Age is a major factor, with usage dropping dramatically around age 75 [3]. For example, 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, but this number decreases to 37% for those 80 and older [!["Go online" and "Broadband at home" percentages vary significantly based on age, education, and household income.](image5)]. A similar trend is observed with broadband adoption, with 65% of 65-69 year-olds having broadband at home compared to only 21% of those 80 and older [!["Go online" and "Broadband at home" percentages vary significantly based on age, education, and household income.](image5)].

Education also plays a significant role. Seniors with higher educational attainment have much higher adoption rates [3]. Among college graduates, 87% go online, and 76% have broadband at home [!["Go online" and "Broadband at home" percentages vary significantly based on age, education, and household income.](image5)]. In contrast, only 40% of seniors with a high school education or less use the internet, and just 27% have broadband [!["Go online" and "Broadband at home" percentages vary significantly based on age, education, and household income.](image5)].

Income is another key factor. Seniors in higher income brackets have higher adoption rates [3, 8]. For instance, 90% of seniors with a household income of $75,000 or more use the internet, and 82% have broadband [!["Go online" and "Broadband at home" percentages vary significantly based on age, education, and household income.](image5)]. Among those earning less than $30,000, only 39% use the internet, and 25% have broadband [!["Go online" and "Broadband at home" percentages vary significantly based on age, education, and household income.](image5)].

![Internet use among seniors has been steadily increasing, but it still lags behind the general adult population.](image4)

Although internet usage among seniors has been rising, it's still much less than the overall population [2, 5].
