The data shows that 59% of seniors were using the internet, in comparison with the national average, which at 86% of the adult population, significantly exceeding the usage among older adults [2].

In summary, internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are significantly lower than the general population and vary greatly depending on age, education, and income, with younger, more educated, and wealthier seniors having the highest adoption rates.

Internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors show significant variations based on income and education levels.

High-income seniors have markedly higher adoption rates. For instance, 90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, and 82% have broadband at home [9]. In stark contrast, among seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, only 39% go online, and a mere 25% have broadband at home [9].

![Internet and broadband adoption by income and education.](image3)

Education level also plays a crucial role. A substantial 87% of seniors with a college degree use the internet, and 76% have broadband [7, 9]. However, among seniors who have not attended college, only 40% go online, and just 27% have broadband at home [9].

![Cell phone and smartphone adoption by income and education.](image5)

Cell phone ownership is generally high among seniors, with 77% owning one [4]. This ownership varies significantly across different demographics, income and educational backgrounds. For example, 92% of the seniors earning $75,000+ anually own cell phone, while only 67% of those making less than $30,000 do. Similarly, 87% of college graduates own cell phones, compared to only 70% of those with high school grad or less. [![Cell phone and smartphone adoption by income and education.](image5)] Smartphone adoption, however, is lower among seniors at just 18% [10]. For example, 42% of the seniors earning $75,000+ annually own smartphone, while only 8% of those making less than $30,000 do. 35% of the seniors with college graduate own a smartphone, while only 10% of those with high school grad or less do. [![Cell phone and smartphone adoption by income and education.](image5)]

The trend clearly shows that higher income and education levels correlate with higher adoption rates of internet-related technologies among seniors, while lower income and education levels correlate with lower adoption rates.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults (65+) show significant variation based on income and education levels, and these rates differ considerably from overall trends in device ownership.

Affluent and well-educated seniors tend to adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower incomes and educational attainment [1]. Seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, and those who are college graduates, show the highest adoption rates.
![image5](image5)
For those with annual household income of $75,000+, 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home. For college graduates, 87% go online, and 76% have broadband [1], as shown in image5.

In contrast, subgroups of older adults, particularly those 80 years of age or older, those with low household incomes, and those who have not attended college, are much less connected to online life [3].
![image5](image5)
Specifically, among seniors with an annual household income of less than $30,000, only 39% go online, and just 25% have broadband. Similarly, among seniors who have not attended college, only 40% go online, and 27% have broadband [3].

Smartphone ownership also varies significantly by income and education among older adults.
![image4](image4)
Smartphone ownership is 42% for senior with an annual household income of $75,000+, and 35% of college graduates [6, 7], as shown in image4.

Smartphone adoption rates among seniors are generally low across the entire age spectrum but decrease substantially for those in their mid-70s and become nearly non-existent among those in their 80s and beyond [8].
![image4](image4)
Only 10% of 75-79-year-olds and 5% of those 80 and older own a smartphone[8].

In comparison, the national average for cell phone ownership is 91%, while 77% of seniors own a cell phone [4]. However, smartphone ownership among seniors is only 18%, well below the national adoption rate [10].

In summary, internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are significantly higher for those with higher income and education levels, but these rates are still lower than the national averages for all adults.

Internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors varies significantly based on educational background.

Seniors with higher educational attainment use the internet and own smartphones at much higher rates than those with lower educational levels [7]. Specifically, college graduates have the highest rates: 87% go online, and 76% have broadband at home. Seniors with some college education follow, with 69% using the internet and 57% having broadband. In stark contrast, only 40% of seniors with a high school education or less go online, and just 27% have broadband [4].

![Internet and broadband adoption rates vary significantly among seniors based on their education levels.](image2)

Smartphone ownership shows a similar trend. Among college graduates aged 65 and older, 35% own a smartphone. For those with some college, the rate is 19%, while only 10% of seniors with a high school education or less own a smartphone.

![Smartphone ownership among seniors is also influenced by education, with college graduates having the highest rates.](image5)

Overall, higher educational attainment among seniors is strongly correlated with greater internet usage and smartphone ownership.

Internet and broadband adoption rates, along with cell phone and smartphone ownership among seniors, vary significantly based on education and income levels.

Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online, and 82% have broadband at home [3].
![image3](image3)
In contrast, for seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, only 39% go online, and 25% have broadband at home [3].
![image3](image3)
This indicates a substantial disparity in internet and broadband adoption based on income.

Similarly, education plays a crucial role. 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% are broadband adopters [3].
![image3](image3)
Among seniors who have not attended college, only 40% go online, and just 27% have broadband at home [3].
![image3](image3)

Regarding cell phone ownership, a substantial majority of seniors (77%) own cell phones [6, 7].
![image2](image2)
Smartphone ownership is much lower, with only 18% of seniors being smartphone adopters [9].
![image2](image2)
Cell phone ownership is prevalent across all demographic categories, but there is a large variance among different incomes and education levels when it comes to smartphone adoption [7]. For example, 87% of college graduate seniors own cell phones, and 35% own smartphones, While among seniors earning less than $30,000 67% own cell phones, and 8% own smartphones.
![image2](image2)

Smartphone ownership among seniors increases with higher income and education levels, mirroring the trends seen in internet and broadband adoption [10].

In conclusion, internet and broadband adoption, as well as smartphone ownership, are significantly higher among seniors with higher education and income levels, while cell phone ownership is widespread across all demographics.

Broadband adoption at home among seniors varies significantly based on educational attainment and household income.

Seniors with higher education levels are much more likely to have broadband at home. For instance, 76% of seniors with a college degree are broadband adopters, compared to just 27% of those who have not attended college [2, 10].
![Broadband adoption by education and income](image2)
Income also plays a crucial role. Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 82% have broadband at home [10]. This contrasts sharply with seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, where only 25% have a broadband connection at home [10]. The image above shows a clear trend: as income increases, broadband adoption increases. The same applies to education; higher educational attainment correlates with higher broadband adoption rates.

In summary, broadband adoption among seniors is much higher for those with a college education and those in higher income brackets.

Education level significantly impacts the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors. Seniors with higher educational attainment are much more likely to own these devices. College graduates are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to seniors who have not attended college [4].

This trend is visually represented in a table, which shows that 30% of senior college graduates own e-book readers and 31% own tablet computers, compared to just 12% and 11% respectively for seniors with a high school education or less.
![Table showing e-book reader and tablet computer adoption among seniors by age, education, and income.](image3)

The adoption of technology, specifically social networking sites, shows an increasing trend across all age groups over time. However, the rate of adoption varies significantly with age.

![Graph showing the trend of social networking site usage across all age groups from 2005 to 2013.](image4)

The adoption of technology is increasing in all age groups over time, but seniors with higher education levels adopt technology at a greater rate than those with lower education levels.

Workers with higher educational attainment generally view workforce technologies more positively than those with less education. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement [10]. A significant majority of college graduates (64%) believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less [7]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, versus 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [7, 10].

![The impact of technology on job interest and advancement opportunities varies by educational attainment.](image1)

In terms of future expectations, a large majority of Americans are aware of driverless vehicle technology, and a substantial portion anticipates their widespread adoption within the next 50 years [2].

![A majority of Americans anticipate the prevalence of driverless vehicles within 50 years.](image2)

In conclusion, educational attainment significantly impacts how workers perceive the benefits of technology in the workplace, and a substantial portion of the population foresees driverless vehicles becoming the norm.

Workers with different educational backgrounds have significantly different views on how workplace technology has impacted their careers [8]. College graduates tend to have a more positive outlook compared to those with a high school diploma or less [4, 10].

For example, there is a 45-percentage point difference in the share of workers with college degrees (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%) who feel that word processing or spreadsheet software have had a positive impact on them professionally [4]. Similar trends are observed for other technologies like smartphones, email, social media, and scheduling software[4].
![image3](image3)

In terms of overall impact, a majority of workers (53%) feel technology has made their work more interesting, while 46% believe it has increased their opportunities for career advancement[9].
![image1](image1)
![image4](image4)
Moreover, workers' opinions on the impact of specific technologies like word processing software, smartphones, and email vary.
![image2](image2)

Regarding the adoption of driverless cars, a significant majority of Americans (94%) are aware of their development [1]. A large portion of the public, around two-thirds, expects that most vehicles will be driverless within the next 50 years, with 9% anticipating this within the next 10 years [1].
![image5](image5)

In summary, college graduates generally perceive workplace technologies more positively than those with less education, and a large majority of Americans expect widespread adoption of driverless cars within the next 50 years.

The perceptions of automation and workforce technology impacts differ significantly between future expectations and current experiences.

Americans anticipate widespread adoption of driverless vehicles in the future [6].
![When Americans think most vehicles on the road will be driverless](image2)

However, workers' current experiences with various technologies are mixed, with some viewing them positively and others negatively [2]. Many workers believe technologies like word processing software, smartphones, and email/social media have positively impacted their careers [4].
![Workers' views on the impact of various technologies on their careers.](image1)

Specifically, 70% of workers reported a positive impact from word processing or spreadsheet software, 67% from smartphones, and 60% from email or social media [4]. In contrast, only 27% reported a positive impact from industrial robots, with 58% saying they had no impact either way [!["Workers' views on the impact of various technologies on their careers."](image1)].
When asked about the overall impact, roughly half (53%) felt technology made their work more interesting [7].
![Workers reporting whether technology has made their work more or less interesting.](image5)

Additionally, 46% felt technology increased their career advancement opportunities [7].
![Workers reporting whether technology has increased or decreased their career opportunities.](image4)
Moreover, 39% of the workers believe that the technology made their work more demanding.
![Workers' responses on whether technology has made their work more or less demanding.](image3)

In summary, while Americans expect significant changes from future automation like driverless vehicles, current experiences with technologies vary widely, with many workers reporting positive impacts from common workplace tools, but a considerable proportion expressing neutral or negative views, particularly regarding industrial robots.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of workplace technologies and their impact on job interest and career opportunities [1, 3, 7].

College graduates are significantly more likely than those with high school diplomas or less to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) [2].
![image3](image3)
This difference in perception is further highlighted by the broader statistics, which show that 53% of all workers believe technology has made their work more interesting, while only 12% say it has made their work less interesting [5].
![image2](image2)
Additionally, college graduates are more likely to believe that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [2].
![image3](image3)
In general, 46% of workers feel that technology has enhanced their career advancement opportunities, compared to 13% who feel it has decreased them [5].
![image1](image1)

The survey measured the impact of six common workforce technologies and showed that college graduates have more positive views compared with those with high school diplomas or less. [9]
![image4](image4)

In summary, perceptions of workplace technologies differ significantly by education level, with college-educated workers more likely to view these technologies as beneficial for job interest and career advancement compared to those with a high school education or less.

Workers with varying levels of educational attainment have significantly different views on workplace technology [3]. College graduates are substantially more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement, compared to workers with high school diplomas or less [1, 7, 8].

Specifically, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [1].
![image5](image5)
And 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, versus 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [1]. Furthermore, the survey indicates that these differences extend to specific technologies in image3.
![image3](image3)
For example, 90% of college graduates reported a positive impact from word processing or spreadsheet software, compared to only 45% of workers with high school diplomas or less [9]. This shows a 45-percentage point difference [9]. Similar disparities are observed for other technologies like smartphones, email/social media, and software that manages daily schedules [9].

In summary, educational attainment significantly affects the perceived impact of technology on work, with higher education levels correlating with more positive views on technology's role in making work more interesting and increasing advancement opportunities.

Workers' views on how technology impacts their careers, specifically regarding job opportunities and work interest, vary significantly based on their educational attainment [5, 6, 8].

College graduates are much more likely to report that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with a high school diploma or less (53% vs. 32%) [9].
![image3](image3)
This trend is consistent across various technologies, with a particularly large difference in perception regarding office productivity tools like word processing and spreadsheet software [10].
![image1](image1)

In terms of work interest, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, while only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less share this view [9].

Americans' awareness of automation influences their views on machines taking over human jobs, with varying degrees of enthusiasm and worry.

Among those who have heard a lot about this concept, 48% believe it is extremely realistic, compared to 14% of those who have heard a little and 4% of those who have heard nothing [7].
![Concept realism based on awareness levels](image3)
A similar trend is observed in enthusiasm levels: 47% of those with high awareness express some enthusiasm, a figure substantially higher than those with lower familiarity [7].
However, worry remains consistently high across all awareness levels. Roughly three-quarters of those who have heard a lot (76%) express some worry, comparable to those who have heard a little (72%) and those who have heard nothing (69%) [9].
![Worry levels across different awareness groups](image1)

Americans generally expect more negative outcomes than positive ones from widespread automation [5]. A significant majority (76%) anticipate increased economic inequality [8, 10], and 64% expect people will have a hard time finding things to do with their lives.
![Expected outcomes of automation](image4)
Only 25% believe the economy will create many new, better-paying jobs for humans [1, 8].

In summary, while higher awareness of automation leads to a greater belief in its feasibility and slightly increased enthusiasm, worry remains high across all groups, with most Americans anticipating negative outcomes like increased inequality and job displacement.

Americans show widespread support for limiting robots and computers to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with some differences in opinion between Democrats and Republicans on other policies related to workforce automation.

A significant majority, 85% of Americans, favor limiting robots and computers to performing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans. [6] This sentiment is largely shared across party lines. ![Support for policies related to automation, by political party.](image3)

However, Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of a universal basic income (77% favor) and a national service program (66% favor) compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (38% and 46% favor, respectively). [2, 9]
![Support for various policies related to job automation, broken down by political affiliation.](image3)

Despite these differences, a majority of both Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) believe there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines. [4, 9]

In general, the public strongly supports restricting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs, while other policy solutions like universal basic income and national service programs receive majority support but show a partisan divide.

Americans' views on government obligations and automation limits in the context of job displacement are significantly influenced by both political affiliation and educational attainment.

Political Affiliation:

Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more supportive of government intervention than Republicans and Republican-leaning independents. A significant majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government has an obligation to care for workers displaced by automation, even if it means higher taxes [3]. In stark contrast, 68% of Republicans believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [3]. This difference in opinion is further reflected in the support for a universal basic income (77% of Democrats vs. 38% of Republicans) and a national service program (66% of Democrats vs. 46% of Republicans) [1].
![image2](image2)

However, partisan opinions are more aligned regarding limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines. A slight majority of Republicans (54%) and a larger percentage of Democrats (60%) believe there should be such limits [7].

Educational Attainment:

While views on government obligation to displaced workers do not vary substantially across different education levels [10], there is a clear difference on support to set limit for automation. A considerably number of those with high school diplomas or less (70%) favor limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate [10]. Support for limiting automation decreases to 41% among those with four-year college degrees [10].
![image4](image4)

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences views on the government's role in supporting displaced workers, with Democrats favoring more intervention, while educational attainment primarily affects opinions on limiting job automation, with less educated individuals being more supportive of restrictions.

Americans' views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement are significantly influenced by their political affiliations [1].

Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents show much stronger support for a universal basic income (77%) compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (38%) [1].
![A graph showing the percentage of Democrats and Republicans who support certain policies](image4)
Similarly, Democrats are more supportive of a national service program (66% vs. 46%) [1].

However, there is more agreement between the parties on other issues. For instance, there are no major partisan differences in support for limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs [1].
![Support for policies in the event of job automation.](image2)
Moreover, similar proportions of Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) believe there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with robots or computers [6, 10].
![Support for policies, and the belief in the government's obligation to displaced workers.](image3)
Attitudes towards the government's obligation to care for workers displaced by automation also vary strongly by partisan affiliation [4]. A majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government should take care of displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes, while a nearly identical share of Republicans (68%) believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [4].

In summary, political affiliation significantly affects American views on policies related to workforce automation, with Democrats generally favoring government intervention and support programs more than Republicans.

Attitudes toward workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly across different age groups and educational levels.

Younger workers, particularly those aged 18-24, are more likely to report having been personally impacted by workforce automation, through job loss or reduction in pay/hours [2].
![image3](image3)
Workers with higher levels of education tend to view workplace technologies more positively [3]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement, compared to those with a high school diploma or less [8].
![image4](image4)

In contrast, workers who have not attended college are less likely to view current workforce technologies positively [5, 7]. Only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less believe technology has made their jobs more interesting, and 32% feel it has increased their career advancement opportunities [10].

The data indicates that higher educational attainment correlates with a more positive perception of technology's impact on careers, while younger workers are more vulnerable to the negative impacts of automation.

Workers' perceptions of technology's impact in the workplace are mixed and heavily influenced by their level of education [3, 4]. Many workers view these technologies favorably, but a significant portion sees them as harmful or neutral to their careers [4].

A key finding is that the benefits of technology in the workplace are more likely to be experienced by workers with higher levels of formal education [4, 5].
![The impact of technology on work by education level.](image4)
College graduates are significantly more likely than those with a high school diploma or less to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their career advancement opportunities (53% vs. 32%) [1]. A similar trend is observed across various technologies, with college-educated workers reporting a more positive impact [7].

![Impact of technologies on workers' jobs and careers.](image5)
In contrast, workers without a college education are less likely to express positive attitudes towards current workforce technologies [2]. Only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less believe technology has made their jobs more interesting, and only 32% feel it has increased their career opportunities [9].

In summary, perceptions of technology's impact on the workforce vary significantly based on educational attainment, with college-educated workers reporting more positive effects than those with lower levels of education.

Workers' perceptions of how technology impacts their jobs, in terms of interest and career advancement, vary significantly based on their education levels and the specific technologies involved.

Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to report that technology has increased their opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [6]. Specifically, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [7].
![image2](image2)
In addtion, 53% college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities for advancement, compared to 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [7].

A substantial share of workers indicate that technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) have had a positive impact on their own careers [9].
![image4](image4)

Moreover, 53% feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting [2].
![image1](image1)

However, 46% feel that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement [2].
![image3](image3)
These statistics highlight that while a significant portion of workers view technology positively, the benefits are more pronounced for those with higher educational attainment.

In conclusion, education level significantly influences workers' perceptions of technology's impact, with more educated workers reporting more positive effects, and specific technologies like word processing software and smartphones are widely seen as beneficial.

Social media content evokes a range of emotions, with notable differences across age groups [9, 10].

Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report frequently feeling amused by social media content (54%) than older adults aged 65 and older (30%) [1].
![A graph showing the percentage of social media users in different age groups who frequently experience specific emotions.](image2)
However, younger adults are also more prone to frequently feeling lonely (15%) compared to older adults (4% for those 50 and older) [5]. Older adults, aged 65 and above, experience amusement (30%) and anger (24%) with more comparable frequency [1, 5].

Across all age groups, amusement is the most commonly cited emotion.
![Frequency of emotions experienced by social media users](image3)
The largest share of users (88% in total) say they see content on these sites that makes them feel amused, and 44% frequently experience this emotion [7]. Other frequently reported emotions include anger (25% frequently) [6]. Users also frequently encounter content that is overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts (59%) [2].
![Frequency of encountering certain types of content on social media](image1)

In summary, while amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion on social media across all age groups, younger users report higher rates of loneliness, and older users experience amusement and anger with similar frequencies.

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media, with some notable variations. Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to frequently encounter content that makes them feel amused (54%) compared to older adults aged 65 and older (30%) [7]. However, younger adults are also more likely to frequently feel lonely (15%) compared to older adults (4%) [1].
![Different emotions experienced on social media by age group.](image1)

Across age groups, anger is a commonly experienced emotion [1].
![Frequency of emotions experienced on social media.](image2)

Users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [5].
![Types of content frequently seen on social media.](image4)

In summary, different age groups experience varying emotions on social media, with younger adults feeling amused more often but also experiencing more loneliness, while all age groups frequently encounter angry content and dramatic or argumentative posts.

Different age groups exhibit varying emotional responses to social media content. Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to feel lonely (15%) compared to older adults aged 30-49 (7%) and those 50 and older (4%) [7]. Conversely, older adults (65+) report feeling amused (30%) and angry (24%) at similar rates [7].

![Feelings by age group on social media.](image2)

In terms of gender differences, men (29%) are more likely than women (19%) to encounter mean or bullying content [2]. Women are slightly more inclined to see kind or supportive behavior [2]. However, the majority of both men (52%) and women (56%) report seeing a mix of both supportive and bullying behaviors [2]. Men are also twice as likely as women to say they more often seeing people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [10].

![Breakdown of social media behavior by gender and attempts to spread misinformation.](image4)

As for common content, a majority of social media users frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [4].
![Common content seen on social media.](image5)

In conclusion, younger adults report more loneliness, while older adults experience amusement and anger at comparable levels; men encounter more bullying, while women see slightly more kindness, and commonly, users encounter dramatic content and arguments without factual basis.

Social media users' comfort levels with how their data is used are context-dependent [1]. A majority find it acceptable for sites to use their data for local event recommendations, but not for political campaign ads [2].

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media.
![image4](image4)
illustrates the percentage of social media users in each age group who say they frequently see content on social media that makes them feel amused, angry, connected, inspired, depressed, or lonely [5]. Younger users (18-29) report higher frequencies of feeling amused (54%), connected (25%), and lonely (15%) compared to older users (65+) who report 30%, 15%, and 2% for these emotions, respectively. The rates for feeling angry are similar across all age groups, ranging from 23% to 27% [5].

Experiences with behaviors on social media also vary by gender.
![image3](image3)
Men are more likely than women to report seeing mean or bullying behavior (29% vs. 19%), while women are slightly more likely to report seeing kind or supportive behavior (24% vs. 17%). However, the majority of both genders report seeing an equal mix of both supportive and bullying behaviors (52% of men and 56% of women) [10].

Users frequently encounter specific types of content.
![image5](image5)
shows the percentage of users who frequently or sometimes see certain types of posts [3]. The most common types of posts encountered are those that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58% frequently, 88% net) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59% frequently, 87% net) [9].

In summary, younger users report higher frequencies of both positive and negative emotions on social media compared to older users, men are more likely to see bullying behavior while women are more likely to see supportive behavior, and the most common types of posts encountered are overly dramatic ones and those with unfounded accusations.

The survey data reveals distinct differences between men's and women's perceptions of online behaviors. Men are more likely than women to report seeing people being mean or bullying on social media platforms [9, 10]. Specifically, 29% of men, compared to 19% of women, say they more often observe mean or bullying content [10]. This is visually represented in a chart showing these percentages.

![Percentages of men and women reporting online behaviors.](image1)

Furthermore, men are about twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [5]. However, majorities of both genders report seeing a mix of both deceptive behavior and attempts to correct misinformation [5].

Regarding the frequency of encountering certain types of content, a majority of social media users report frequently seeing posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) [3, 7].
![Frequency of different content types.](image4)
The related chart shows that 58% frequently, and 31% sometimes see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, making up 88% in total [4].

In conclusion, men are more likely to report encountering bullying and deceptive behaviors online than women, while both genders commonly encounter dramatic or exaggerated posts.

Users' comfort with social media companies using their personal data is highly dependent on the context [1, 2].

A majority of social media users are okay with platforms using their data to recommend local events, A smaller majority (57%) find it acceptable for recommending potential friends [3].

![image2](image2)

However, there are notable differences between men's and women's experiences on social media:

*   **Bullying vs. Kindness**: Men (29%) are more likely than women (19%) to report seeing mean or bullying behavior on social media [4]. Conversely, women are more likely to see kind or supportive behavior [4]. However, the largest shares of both men (52%) and women (56%) say they see an equal mix of both [4].
*    **Deception vs. Correction of Misinformation**: Men (24%) are about twice as likely as women (13%) to report seeing people trying to be deceptive [10]. Majorities of both genders, though, see a mix of deceptive behavior and attempts to correct it [10].

![image1](image1)

Age also plays a significant role in acceptance of data usage. Younger users (18-49) are generally more accepting of data being used to recommend people they might know (66% to 33%), while older users (65+) are not (63% to 36%) [9].

In conclusion, perceptions of social media content differ between men and women, with men reporting more negative experiences and women reporting slightly more positive ones, with age being a significant factor in how comfortable different groups are.

User comfort with social media platforms' use of personal data is highly dependent on the context and purpose of data usage [7, 8]. There are notable differences across age groups in their acceptance of these practices [9].

A significant majority (75%) of social media users are comfortable with their data being used to recommend events they might like to attend [1]. This acceptance is consistent across various age groups [3].
![Acceptability of data usage by age group](image1)

However, older users (65+) are much less accepting of their data being used for other reasons, especially for recommending potential connections [10]. While 66% of users aged 18-49 find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend other people they might know, 63% of users aged 65 and older find this unacceptable [10].

There is also a general wariness about data being used for political messaging, with a substantial majority across all age groups finding it unacceptable for social media platforms to deliver messages from political campaigns [3, 5].

![Acceptability levels for different uses of data](image2)

Moreover, user comfort levels decrease when it comes to using data for advertisements. Only about half (52%) of users think it's acceptable for sites to use their data to show advertisements for products or services, with a similar share (47%) finding it unacceptable [5].

In summary, different age groups vary in their acceptance of social media data usage, with older users being generally less comfortable, particularly with friend recommendations, and most users are wary of data use for political messaging.

Americans express significant reservations about the fairness of automated decision-making systems. Public perceptions of algorithmic decision-making are highly contextual, varying based on the specific circumstances and tasks assigned to these technologies [6].

A key finding is the contrast in attitudes toward different applications of algorithms. For example, while a majority (54%) believe that personal finance score algorithms are effective at identifying good customers, only 32% consider them fair to consumers [1]. This discrepancy is visually represented in data showing a 22-percentage point difference between effectiveness and fairness perceptions for personal finance scores, the largest among the scenarios presented [8].
![The effective-fair difference of automated personal finance score is +22](image3)

Further details show that the public is split on effectiveness, with 54% finding personal finance scores effective and around half approving of parole rating (49%) and resume screening (47%) algorithms [5]. However, regarding fairness, clear majorities do not view any of the systems as fair [7].
![The automated personal finance score's not fair at all percentage is 33 and not very fair is 33.](image4)
Racial and ethnic differences also influence perceptions, with blacks and Hispanics more likely than whites to find consumer finance scores fair, whereas blacks express greater concern about parole scoring algorithms [3].
![68% of U.S. adults think it is not acceptable for companies to use automated personal finance scores.](image2)
The data suggest a broad skepticism towards these systems, rooted in concerns about human bias, privacy, and the nuanced capture of complex situations [6, 9].

In summary, perceptions of fairness and effectiveness in automated decision-making systems vary significantly, with a general trend of higher perceived effectiveness than fairness, indicating underlying issues of public trust in these systems.

Public views on the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are at record lows compared to previous administrations [1]. A majority of the public $(58\%)$ says they trust what Trump says less than what previous presidents said while in office [9].

These perceptions are deeply divided along partisan lines:
*   **Democrats:** The vast majority of Democrats and Democratic leaners $(94\%)$ trust Trump's statements less than those of previous presidents [2].  $90\%$ of Democrats believe the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are not good or poor [10].
*   **Republicans:**  Most Republicans and Republican leaners $(58\%)$ trust what Trump says more than previous presidents [6]. A significant majority $(76\%)$ rate the ethical standards of top administration officials as excellent or good [10].
*    **Overall Comparison:** The data shows a consistent trend of lower ratings for Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness compared to his predecessors.
![{Ratings of top officials' ethical standards across presidencies.}](image1)
*   Another image shows how, overall, 26% trust Trump more than previous presidents, 14% about the same, and 58% less than previous presidents. For Republicans, the breakdown is 58% more, 25% same, 15% less.
![{Comparison of trust in Trump's statements versus previous presidents, by political affiliation.}](image4)

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are significantly lower compared to previous presidents, with a stark divide between Democrats, who overwhelmingly distrust Trump and disapprove of his administration's ethics, and Republicans, who mostly trust him more and approve of his administration's ethical standards.

Public perceptions of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness differ significantly from those of previous presidents, with notable partisan divisions.

A majority of the public (64%) believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [3]. This sentiment is overwhelmingly supported by Democrats (91%), while only 32% of Republicans agree [3].
![{Public opinion on whether Trump should release his tax returns}](image1)

A majority of the public (58%) trusts what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents [10]. This distrust is particularly pronounced among Democrats, with 94% expressing less trust in Trump compared to previous presidents [5, 9].
![{Comparison of trust levels in Trump versus previous presidents}](image3)
In contrast, 58% of Republicans say they trust Trump's statements more than those of previous presidents [8].

The public also views the ethical standards of Trump administration officials lower than those of officials in previous administrations [4].
The data indicates that there is considerably less perception that it is too early to determine if Trump will have a successful presidency than there was for previous presidents at comparable points in their terms. [6]
![{Comparison of the public's view on whether it is too early to tell if the president would be successful.}](image2)

In summary, the public perceives Trump as having a responsibility to release his tax returns, trusts his statements less than those of previous presidents, a phenomenon largely driven by Democratic views, and views to believe it is too early to determine a successful presidency are less.

Public perceptions of President Trump's presidency differ significantly among political affiliations and, in many aspects, are more negative than those of previous presidents.

**Ethical Standards:**

Views of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are at record lows compared to previous administrations [1, 7]. Partisans are deeply divided: 76% of Republicans rate the ethical standards as excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats rate them as not good or poor [10].

**Economic Impact:**

*   Overall, 40% believe Trump's policies have improved economic conditions, 28% say they have worsened them, and 29% see no significant effect [4].
*   Partisan views are polarized. 79% of Republicans believe his policies have improved the economy. [9].
     Democrats, have grown more negative , with 46% saying his policies have worsened conditions[9].
*   This partisan divide has widened since 2017 [9].
*   The detailed breakdown of views on Trump's economic policies in January 2019. ![Perception of Trump's economic policies impact in January 2019.](image4)

**Long-Term Success:**

*   47% predict Trump will be an unsuccessful president, 29% foresee success, and 23% say it's too early to tell [5].
*   These ratings are more negative than those for Obama and George W. Bush at similar points in their presidencies [5].
*   Republicans (65%) are optimistic, believing Trump will be successful [3].
*   This is similar to Republican views of Bush in his third year (69%)[6]
*    A comparison of success predictions for different presidents, showing Trump's lower expected success rate. ![Presidential success outlook comparison.](image3)

**Overall Comparison to Previous Presidents:**

Fewer people say it's "too early to tell" about Trump's success compared to his three most recent predecessors [5].
Public views of Trump's success compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton.
![Public views on presidential success over time.](image3)

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's presidency are highly polarized along party lines, with Republicans generally positive and Democrats overwhelmingly negative, and overall, his ratings on ethics and long-term success are lower compared to several previous presidents.

Public opinion on whether a president will be successful in the long run is highly partisan and differs significantly between Republicans/Republican-leaning and Democrats/Democrat-leaning individuals.

For President Trump, there is a significant partisan divide: 65% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe he will be a successful president, while 80% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe he will be unsuccessful [1, 5]. A smaller percentage (25% of Republicans vs. 16% of Democrats) believe it is too early to tell [2]. This contrasts with previous presidents, where larger shares of the public, at comparable points in their presidencies, stated it was too early to determine their success [4].
![Party Affiliates' Views on Presidential Success](image1)

The data reveals stark differences compared to past administrations. For Obama in January 2011, 47% of Democrats and 7% of Republicans thought he would be successful. For Bush in December 2003, the figures were 69% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats. For Clinton in February 1995, 32% of Democrats and 8% of Republicans saw him as successful. In all cases, the percentage saying "too early to tell" was much higher than with Trump [6].
![Overall views on how successful will the presidents be](image3)

Overall, a larger share of the public believes Trump will be unsuccessful (47%) compared to those who believe he will be successful (29%) [6]. This negative balance is greater than that for Obama and Bush at similar points but similar to Clinton, where more people believed that Clinton would be unsuccessful (34%) than successful (18%) [6].

The trend shows a more polarized view of Trump's potential success, with fewer people willing to say it's too early to tell compared to his predecessors [4].

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's presidency are more deeply divided along party lines than those of Obama, Bush, and Clinton at comparable points in their terms, with a significantly smaller proportion of the public remaining undecided.

Partisan divisions characterize perceptions of both Trump's potential success and the Mueller investigation.

A majority of Republicans, 65%, believe Trump will be a successful president [6]. ![Perceptions of presidential success for Clinton, Bush, Obama, and Trump.](image1) This aligns with the 69% of Republicans in 2003 who believed Bush would be successful [2]. In contrast, a large majority of Democrats, 80%, think Trump will be unsuccessful [3]. ![Breakdown of views on Trump's potential success by party affiliation in January 2019.](image3)

These differing views on Trump's success correlate with confidence levels in the Mueller investigation. A significant majority of Democrats (72%) are at least somewhat confident in the fairness of Mueller's investigation [7].
![Confidence levels in Trump's handling of the investigation, broken down by party affiliation.](image2)
 Conversely, a majority of Republicans (58%) express a lack of confidence in Mueller [7].
![Confidence in Mueller investigation.](image4)
Overall, public confidence in Mueller's investigation remains divided, with 55% expressing at least some confidence and 41% expressing little or no confidence [8].

In summary, Republicans are far more likely to believe Trump will be successful than Democrats, and these views are linked to contrasting levels of confidence in the Mueller investigation, with Democrats generally expressing confidence and Republicans expressing doubt.

Public perception of local job availability has become the most positive in decades, with a notable partisan divide in these views [9].

A majority of adults (60%) report that there are plenty of jobs available in their communities, the highest share recorded since 2001 [3].
![A graph showing an increase in the perception of job availability and a decrease in the perception that jobs are difficult to find.](image1)
However, there's a distinction between "jobs" and "good jobs," with the latter seen as less widely available [4, 8].

There is a significant partisan gap in views of job availability [2, 6]. Republicans are more optimistic than Democrats: 71% of Republicans believe there are plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats [2, 6].
![Data showing that 71% of Republicans and 53% of Democrats believe plenty of jobs are available.](image3)
This partisan gap extends to personal financial situations, with Republicans rating their finances more positively than Democrats (62% vs. 44%) [7].

Over time, perceptions in both parties have become more positive, reaching levels not seen in the last two decades [5].
![Trend data showing Republican and Democratic views on job availability over time, with both groups showing increased optimism.](image5)
Perceptions of job availability have generally tracked with more positive views of the economy [10].

In conclusion, perceptions of economic conditions and job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally holding more positive views, and overall trends show increasing optimism over time in both parties.

Perceptions of job availability are divided along partisan lines, with a majority of Republicans (71%) and Democrats (53%) believing there are plenty of jobs available locally [2]. These views are among the most positive in the last two decades for both parties [3].

The trend since 2001 shows an increasing positive perception, particularly among Republicans, during the Trump administration.  
![Perceptions of Job Availability by Political Affiliation Over Time](image1)

A sizable partisan gap exists in views of job availability, with 71% of Republicans saying there are plenty of jobs available, compared with 53% of Democrats [10].
![Current Perceptions of Job Availability by Political Affiliation](image2)

In October 2017, 58% of Republicans and 47% of Democrats viewed jobs as widely available locally [10]. The overall trend indicates a significant rise in positive views about job availability.
![Historical Trend of Job Availability Perceptions](image3)

In conclusion, perceptions of job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally holding more positive views, and these perceptions have become increasingly positive over time, especially during the Trump administration.

Public opinions on Wall Street's impact on the economy are significantly divided along partisan lines. Republicans are more likely to believe that Wall Street helps the economy. [1, 8] A majority, 55%, of Republicans and Republican leaners believe Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts it, compared to 31% who believe the opposite. [1, ![{image3}](image3)]

Democrats, on the other hand, are more divided on the issue. [7, 8] About an equal percentage, 46%, say Wall Street hurts the economy as say it helps (41%).[7, ![{image3}](image3)]

General satisfaction levels with national conditions have fluctuated over the years. In 2019, a significant majority (70%) of Americans reported dissatisfaction with the way things were going in the country, while only 26% expressed satisfaction. [3, ![{image1}](image1)]

Satisfaction levels also differ significantly by political affiliation. During Trump's presidency, no more than 16% of Democrats expressed satisfaction with national conditions at any point. In 2019, only 8% of Democrats were satisfied, while 90% were dissatisfied. [2, 10, ![{image2}](image2)] Republican satisfaction, while higher than Democrats, also experienced a drop, with 47% expressing satisfaction and an equal percentage expressing dissatisfaction in 2019. [9, ![{image2}](image2)]

In summary, Republicans generally view Wall Street positively, while Democrats are divided, and overall national satisfaction was low in 2019, with a significant partisan divide in satisfaction levels.

Public satisfaction levels have significantly fluctuated from 1990 to 2019, with a notable decline in recent years. Overall, 70% of Americans report being dissatisfied with the country's direction, while only 26% express satisfaction [1]. This dissatisfaction has increased by 9 percentage points since September [10].

Political affiliations have also seen shifts, impacting views on Wall Street's influence on the economy.
![image2](image2)
The graph displays the trends in public satisfaction, clearly indicating a downward trajectory in recent years. Satisfaction levels are lowest in 2019 [2].

Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are currently split, with 47% satisfied and 47% dissatisfied, marking a 12-percentage-point drop in satisfaction since September [5].
![image5](image5)
This graph illustrates the divergence in satisfaction levels between Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats from 1990 to 2019.

In contrast, only 8% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents express satisfaction, with 90% dissatisfied [6]. Democrats are divided on Wall Street’s impact, with 46% say Wall Street does more to hurt the economy, almost the same percentage as those who say it does more to help (41%) [3]. More Republicans say that on balance, Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts it (55% vs. 31%) [7].
![image4](image4)
The survey conducted in 2019 shows that opinions about Wall Street are divided along party lines, with Republicans being more inclined to believe that Wall Street helps the American economy.

In summary, public satisfaction has decreased significantly in recent years, with a growing partisan divide, particularly regarding views on Wall Street's economic impact.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts differs significantly between Republicans and Democrats. A large majority of Republicans (88%) express at least some confidence in Trump's ability in this area, with 64% saying they are "very" confident and 24% "somewhat" confident. In stark contrast, only a small fraction of Democrats (12%) hold similar views, with 2% being "very" confident and 10% "somewhat" confident. ![Public confidence in Trump's ability, divided by party.](image3)

This level of confidence among Republicans is relatively high but slightly lower than their confidence in Trump's ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements (89%) and make good decisions about economic policy (89%) [1, 4]. However, It is higher than their confidence in his ability to manage the executive branch effectively (83%) [!["very" and "somewhat" confidence of Republican and Democrats in Trump](image3)].

Overall, while Republicans show strong confidence in Trump's ability to make good federal court appointments, this is slightly less than their peak confidence levels in his economic and trade abilities, and it is notably higher than their confidence in his management of executive branch. Democrats, show very little confidence in Trump across all these areas.

The public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal court is significantly higher among Republicans than Democrats, mirroring a similar partisan divide across other issues.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions varies significantly across political affiliations. A majority of Republicans express confidence in this separation [10], while a substantial majority of Democrats do not [2].

Specifically, 55% of Republicans are very confident, and 23% are somewhat confident that Trump keeps his business interests separate [10]. Conservative Republicans (66%) are more likely to be very confident than moderate and liberal Republicans (39%) [10].
![Confidence levels in Trump's ability to separate business interests from presidential decisions, by political affiliation.](image3)
In stark contrast, 69% of Democrats are not at all confident, and 20% are not too confident that Trump keeps his business interests separate [2]. This skepticism is even more pronounced among liberal Democrats, with 83% being not at all confident [2]. The data reflects this, showing that only 5% of Democrats are very confident, and 20% being somewhat confident. [9]

Regarding the perception of Trump's responsibility to release his tax returns, a majority of Americans (64%) believe he has this responsibility [8].
![The percentage of people who think Trump should release tax returns.](image4)
However, there's a significant partisan divide. Most Republicans (64%) say Trump does not have a responsibility to release his tax returns, while only 32% believe he does [3].

In conclusion, there is a sharp contrast between Republicans and Democrats regarding confidence in Trump's separation of business and presidential interests, and his tax return.

Partisan divides significantly influence perceptions of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions.

Republicans and Democrats have widely divergent opinions on nearly every aspect of the coronavirus outbreak [1]. Democrats overwhelmingly view the U.S. response as less effective compared to other wealthy countries (87%), while Republicans are more divided, with a smaller percentage (22%) saying the U.S. has been more effective [1].
![A survey showing how Republicans and Democrats view the U.S. COVID-19 response.](image1)

There are wide partisan differences in the views of how public health officials are responding to the outbreak [10].
Positive ratings for public health officials, such as those at the CDC, are much higher among Democrats (72%) than Republicans (53%) [4, 10].
![A chart indicating ratings for various officials and institutions by party affiliation.](image2)

This shift has come almost entirely among Republicans; only about half of Republicans (53%) give the CDC officials and other public health officials positive ratings for their response to the outbreak, 31 points lower than in late March (84%) [4].
Republicans living in less hard-hit parts of the country are slightly less likely to attribute the increase in cases to more infections rather than just more testing (30% compared with 39%) [8].
![A graph representing views on reducing COVID-19 infections by party affiliation and the severity of the outbreak in the county.](image3)

Partisan differences are far wider than differences based on geographical location concerning the virus's impact. [6].
The approval for Donald Trump's job has been fluctuating, with the disapproval rates relatively steady [New item].
![A graph showcasing the trend of approval and disapproval ratings over time.](image4)
Democrats are more likely than Republicans to give positive ratings to their state and local government officials [9].
![A line chart that shows the percentage of people who approve or disapprove of public health officials, local officials, state officials, and Donald Trump.](image5)

In conclusion, partisan divides significantly affect perceptions of the COVID-19 response, with Democrats generally being more critical of the U.S. response and having more trust in public health officials compared to Republicans.

The perception of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak by public health officials and Donald Trump is significantly impacted by partisan differences, with a notable decline in positive views among Republicans between March and August [1, 2, 3].

A survey conducted reveals a substantial drop in positive ratings for public health officials among Republicans, decreasing by 31 percentage points from 84% to 53% [2]. Democrats' views remained relatively stable, with 74% in March and 72% in the later survey giving positive ratings to public health officials [2].
![Public health officials such as those at the CDC](image3)
This shift has come almost entirely among Republicans [10].
![Views of officials response to coronavirus outbreak](image5)
For example, current survey indicates that only about half of Republicans (53%) give CDC officials and other public health officials positive ratings, a 31-point decrease from late March (84%) [10].

In contrast, Democrats' views of public health officials have remained largely unchanged, with about 72% rating them positively, consistent with 74% in March [10]. Regarding Donald Trump, his ratings for the response to the outbreak are lower than in March [7]. The share of Democrats rating Trump's response as "poor" increased significantly from 56% in March to 82% [9].
![Donald Trump](image3)
These trends indicate that partisan affiliation significantly influences the perception of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak, with Republicans showing decreased approval of public health officials and Democrats maintaining relatively stable, positive views.

In summary, partisan differences have a significant impact on the perception of the COVID-19 response, with a large decline in positive views among Republicans for public health officials, and a rise in negative views of Donald Trump among Democrats.

Public approval of health officials and Donald Trump has changed significantly between March and August, with notable partisan differences.

Positive views of public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have declined from 79% in March to 63% in August [1]. This decline is primarily among Republicans [4]. In March, 84% of Republicans gave positive ratings to public health officials, but this dropped to 53% by August [9]. Democrats' views remained relatively stable, with 74% positive ratings in March and 72% in August [5, 9].
![Public health officials approval ratings](image4)

Trump's approval ratings for handling the coronavirus outbreak have also fallen since March [6]. In August, only 37% of respondents said he was doing an excellent or good job, while 63% rated his performance as fair or poor [6].
![Approval of Donald Trump's job performance](image2)
Partisan divisions are stark in views of Trump's performance. 77% of Republicans approve of his performance, compared to only 5% of Democrats [2]. The share of Democrats rating Trump's response as "poor" increased from 56% in March to 82% in August [8].
![Approval ratings split across party lines](image1)

In summary, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have decreased from March to August, with a significant drop in approval among Republicans for public health officials and a widening partisan divide in views of Trump's performance.

Americans' views on their state government's COVID-19 response are more positive than their views on Donald Trump's handling of the pandemic [9].

Positive evaluations of state government officials have declined since March, but still, a majority (56%) rate their response as excellent or good [10]. In contrast, nearly half of Americans (48%) rate Trump's response as "poor" [4, 6].
![Americans’ views on the COVID-19 response indicate higher positive ratings for state governments compared to Donald Trump’s handling.](image1)

A significant majority of U.S. adults (69%) believe that state governments lifted restrictions too quickly [2].
![A majority of U.S. adults believe state governments lifted restrictions too quickly.](image5)
This suggests a greater concern about the speed of reopening at the state level than about restrictions not being lifted quickly enough.

In summary, American perceptions of state governments' COVID-19 response are more favorable than those of Donald Trump's response, with a majority expressing positive views of state actions, despite a decline, while a significant portion criticizes Trump's handling as "poor."

Americans have differing perceptions of the effectiveness of elected officials versus public health officials in handling the COVID-19 pandemic, and several factors are seen as contributing to its continuation.

The public generally views public health officials, such as those at the CDC, more favorably than elected officials, though positive views of public health officials have declined since March [2]. A majority (63%) still rate public health officials' response as excellent or good [2], compared to lower ratings for state (56%) and local (60%) elected officials [5].
![Public rating for handling COVID-19](image4)
However, this perception varies significantly between Republicans and Democrats. Republicans' positive ratings of public health officials have dropped considerably since March, while Democrats' views have remained relatively stable [3].

Several factors are perceived as major reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak. These include:
*   Not enough people following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines (75%) [8].
![Factors contributing to the continued outbreak](image1)
*   Restrictions being lifted too quickly in some places (58%) [8].
*   Inadequate response from the federal government (53%) [!["Factors contributing to the continued outbreak".](image1)].

The survey finds "broadly negative assessments of the overall U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak" [1]. Americans perceive the response of elected officials as less effective than that of public health officials, and factors such as insufficient adherence to guidelines and premature lifting of restrictions contribute to the continued outbreak.

Americans' views on government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly influenced by their political affiliations, with notable differences between Republicans and Democrats [4].

A majority of Republicans (68%) believe that state and local governments should be primarily responsible for developing and implementing policies to limit the spread of the coronavirus [9]. ![A bar chart showing that 68% of Republicans believe state and local governments should be responsible, compared to 30% who believe the federal government should be responsible.](image4)

Conversely, 64% of Democrats believe that the federal government should bear most of the responsibility [9].
![A bar chart showing that 64% of Democrats believe the federal government should be responsible, compared to 35% who believe state and local governments should be responsible.](image4)

Regarding the major reasons cited for the continuation of the outbreak, the insufficient practice of social distancing and mask-wearing is the most prominent [1]. A significant majority of Americans (75%) believe that not enough people are adhering to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [7].
![A bar chart showing that 75% of Americans consider insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing a major reason for the continued outbreak.](image1)
This view is shared by a majority in both parties, although it is more pronounced among Democrats (89%) than Republicans (57%) [3, 5].
![A bar chart comparing the views of Republicans and Democrats on various reasons for the continued outbreak, with the largest difference on the issue of social distancing and mask-wearing.](image5)
Other significant reasons include restrictions being lifted too quickly in some places and inadequate response from the federal government, though opinions on these factors vary significantly between the two political groups [5, 7].

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans favoring state and local government responsibility and Democrats favoring federal government responsibility, and insufficient social distancing is the most cited reason for the continuation of the outbreak.

Americans across the political spectrum exhibit differing views on why the COVID-19 outbreak continued, particularly regarding government response and social distancing.

A significant majority of Americans (75%) cite insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason for the continued outbreak [6, 8]. This view is shared by both Democrats and Republicans, though with varying intensity: 89% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe this is a major reason, compared to 57% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [7].
![Major reasons for the continuation of COVID-19 outbreak.](image4)

There's a wide partisan divide on the role of the federal government's response. While 82% of Democrats consider the federal government's response inadequate, only 21% of Republicans share this view [5, 9].
![Major reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, split by political affiliation.](image5)

Furthermore, Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to attribute the continued spread to restrictions being lifted too quickly (82% of Democrats vs. 31% of Republicans) [5]. Democrats are also more likely to cite inadequate federal response (82% vs 21%) [5]. A majority of Republicans (68%) believe that the state and local government bears more responsibility for the response to the pandemic, and only 30% of the republicans point to federal government.
![The graph shows that Democrats are more likely to blame the federal government, while Republicans are more likely to blame state and local governments.](image2)

In summary, Democrats are more likely to attribute the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak to inadequate federal government response and premature lifting of restrictions, while Republicans are more likely to emphasize individual responsibility and point to state and local government, though both parties acknowledge insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a significant factor.

There's a significant partisan divide in the perception of the federal government's response to the COVID-19 outbreak [1, 3, 4]. A large majority of Democrats (82%) believe the inadequate federal response is a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak, while only 21% of Republicans share this view [3, 4].

The chart provides a visual breakdown of these differing viewpoints:

![A chart comparing Republican and Democratic views on reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak.](image1)

It shows that, besides the federal response, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to cite other factors as a major reason of the outbreak's continuation, like "not enough timely testing" (67% of Democrats vs 30% of Republicans) and lifting restrictions too quickly (82% of Democrats vs. 31% of Republicans) [2, 3, 4].

As for the general public, a majority (53%) cite an inadequate federal government response as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak [5]. Other frequently cited reasons include insufficient social distancing, lifting restrictions too quickly in some places, and lack of timely testing [5, 10].

In summary, perceptions of the federal government's response to COVID-19 differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with the majority of the general public viewing the response as inadequate and a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak.

There are significant partisan differences in beliefs about why the COVID-19 outbreak has continued and the effectiveness of the measures taken.

Democrats are more inclined than Republicans to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to several factors. The most notable differences are in the views on the federal government's response and the pace of lifting restrictions [7]. A substantial majority of Democrats (82%) see an inadequate federal response as a major reason, compared to only 21% of Republicans [7]. Similarly, 82% of Democrats believe restrictions were lifted too quickly in some places, while just 31% of Republicans agree with this view [7].

![Major reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak in the U.S.](image3)

Furthermore, Democrats are more likely to cite "not enough timely testing" as a major reason (67% of Democrats vs. 30% of Republicans) [9]. Overall, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say most of the factors are major reasons why the outbreak has continued [7].

Republicans, on the other hand, are more likely to believe that the increase in confirmed cases is primarily due to increased testing [6]. A majority of Republicans (62%) hold this view, compared to a small minority of Democrats(19%) [6, ![Attribution of the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases to rising infections versus a rise in testing](image4)].

There's also a difference in the perceived ability to control the spread, with 35% of Republicans versus 20% of Democrats saying it's not possible to do much to control the spread [3].

In summary, Democrats primarily attribute the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak to inadequate federal response and premature lifting of restrictions, while Republicans are more likely to attribute it to increased testing and an inherent inability to control the spread.

There are significant differences in perspectives between Republicans and Democrats regarding the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions.

Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in coronavirus cases primarily to more infections, not just more testing [7].  $80\%$ of Democrats say the rise in cases is due to more new infections [7]. ![image1](image1) shows the breakdown within the Democratic party:  $90\%$ of liberal Democrats and $73\%$ of conservative/moderate Democrats believe the increase is due to new infections.
On lifting restrictions,  $93\%$ of liberal Democrats and $88\%$ of conservative and moderate Democrats believe states have been lifted too quickly [1]. ![image2](image2)

Republicans are more divided in their opinions. A majority (62%) of Republicans say that the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily a result of more people being tested [6, 7]. ![image1](image1) However, this view is more strongly held among conservative Republicans (68%) than moderate/liberal Republicans (53%) [image1]. Regarding the lifting of restrictions, Republicans are relatively divided, with a slight majority (53%) saying their greater concern is that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough [8].

There is a wide partisan divide, most American attribute the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases more to rising infections than to a rise in testing [10].

In summary, Democrats overwhelmingly believe rising cases are due to increased infections and that restrictions were lifted too quickly, while Republicans are more likely to attribute rising cases to increased testing and are divided on whether restrictions were lifted too quickly or not quickly enough.

There's a strong correlation between views on the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and opinions on lifting restrictions, with significant differences between political groups.

Democrats overwhelmingly believe that the rise in coronavirus cases is primarily due to more infections, not just more testing (80% say this) [9], and they are more likely to say that lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly is the reason why outbreak has continued. [6].
![image3](image3)
A large majority of Democrats believe that restrictions have been lifted too quickly. [2]. Specifically, 93% of liberal Democrats and 88% of conservative and moderate Democrats share this concern [2].
![image4](image4)

Republicans, on the other hand, are more likely to attribute the increase in confirmed cases to increased testing [9]. A majority of Republicans (62%) say that the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily a result of more people being tested [5].
![image5](image5)
Republicans are relatively divided on whether restrictions have been lifted too quickly or not quickly enough, though a slight majority (53%) believe restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough [1].

In summary, Democrats largely believe increased cases are due to new infections and support slower lifting of restrictions, while Republicans attribute increased cases to more testing and are more divided on the pace of lifting restrictions.

There are notable differences in voting policy preferences regarding the requirement of government-issued photo identification, with variations across racial groups and political affiliations.

Republicans overwhelmingly support requiring photo ID to vote [3]. Democrats are less unified on this issue, with differences based on race and ethnicity [2]. A majority of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian (71%) Democrats favor requiring photo ID, while White Democrats are less supportive (54%) [2].

![Democrats and Republicans Differ on Voter ID Requirements by Race](image2)

A significant majority of all adults (76%) strongly or somewhat favor requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification [9].
Support is also very high among Republicans.
![Republican Support for Voter ID Requirements](image3)

However, Black adults show lower levels of support for this policy compared to other racial groups [8].

In summary, while a majority of Americans support requiring government-issued photo ID to vote, there are significant differences based on political affiliation, with Republicans overwhelmingly in favor, and variations among Democrats based on race, with Black Democrats showing less support than other racial groups within the Democratic Party.
