Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for various voting policies. While majorities across racial groups support some expansive policies, there are notable distinctions.

For example, Black adults are more likely to favor "no excuse" early and absentee voting compared to White, Hispanic, and Asian adults [1]. However, when it comes to requiring government-issued photo identification, a majority of White Democrats (54%) are less supportive compared to Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) [2].
![image5](image5)

In general, White Democrats are more supportive of policies that make voting easier compared with Black, Hispanic and Asian Democrats [9].
![image2](image2)

In contrast, Hispanic Republicans are more supportive (51%) of policies like automatic voter registration compared to White Republicans (35%) [7].
![image1](image1)

Black adults show lower support for restrictive policies, such as removing inactive voters from registration lists and requiring photo ID [4]. However, they show distinctively high support (85%) for allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentence, compared to about 70% of White, Hispanic, and Asian Americans [6].
![image4](image4)

Overall, 63% of all adults favor allowing any voter to vote early or absentee, but there are significant racial differences, especially among Democrats, where White Democrats show higher support for this option compared to Democrats of other races and ethnicities [10].
![image3](image3)

Racial and ethnic background significantly shapes opinions on both expansive and restrictive voting policies, with notable differences within partisan groups.

There are significant differences in perspectives on voter ID requirements based on racial and political affiliations.

Majorities across racial groups among Democrats favor requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification: 65% of Black, 72% of Hispanic, and 71% of Asian Democrats support this, compared to 54% of White Democrats [6].
![Among Democrats, percentage of each race that favors photo ID requirements](image1)
However, Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to *strongly* favor photo identification requirements (81% compared with 30%) [9].

In contrast to the support for photo ID requirements, Black Americans show distinct preferences for more expansive voting policies [7]. For example, 85% of Black Americans favor allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after serving their sentences, compared to about 70% of White, Hispanic, and Asian Americans [7]. Black adults are also more likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday and automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [4].

White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee than are Democrats of other races and ethnicities, and about half of Hispanic Republicans (51%) favor automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, compared with 35% of White Republicans [2, 3].
![Among all adults, percentage that favors each voting policy change, by race](image5)

In summary, while majorities across racial and political groups favor requiring government-issued photo identification, there are notable differences in the strength of that support and in views on other voting policies, with Black Americans generally favoring more expansive voting access and Republicans showing stronger support for photo ID requirements.

Americans' views on early or absentee voting and independent redistricting vary significantly across political and demographic lines.

Generally, a majority of Americans (63%) believe any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee. [6].
![image1](image1)
However, this support is not uniform. Democrats and Democratic leaners are far more supportive (84%) of no-excuse early voting than Republicans and Republican leaners (38%) [7].

The support among republicans who voted absentee is much higher (52%) [10].
![image4](image4)

Within the Republican party, there's a divide between moderates/liberals (51% support) and conservatives (30% support) [9].

Regarding independent redistricting, a proposal to require states to use commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans to draw congressional maps garners mixed reactions [8].
![image2](image2)

Different political and demographic groups exhibit significant variations in their support for independent redistricting commissions and no-excuse early or absentee voting, with Democrats generally more supportive than Republicans.

The data indicates significant differences in how various political affiliations view voting methods and redistricting.

There's a clear partisan divide in how people voted in the 2020 presidential election, with a larger share of Democrats (58%) voting absentee or by mail compared to Republicans (34%) [4]. This difference in voting behavior influences opinions on voting policies. Republicans who voted absentee or by mail in 2020 are more likely to favor no-excuse absentee or early voting (52%) than those who voted in person on Election Day (22%) [7].

![Support for no-excuse absentee voting among Republicans based on 2020 voting method.](image3)

Furthermore, conservative Republicans are more likely (70%) to say voters should be required to provide documented reasons for voting absentee or early, compared to moderate/liberal Republicans (49%) [9].

Regarding redistricting, nearly half of U.S. adults approve of a proposal for redistricting commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans [3]. A breakdown shows that 49% of all adults approve that proposal [5].
![Public opinion on a proposal for redistricting commissions with equal representation.](image5)

Republicans are more likely to disapprove (19%) or be unsure (42%) of these non-legislative commissions compared to Democrats (8% disapprove, 32% unsure) [8].

In summary, Democrats generally favor no-excuse absentee voting and independent redistricting commissions, while Republicans, especially those who voted in person on Election Day and conservatives, are more likely to oppose no-excuse absentee voting and are less supportive or unsure about independent redistricting commissions.

There's a significant partisan divide in opinions about early and absentee voting, and automatic voter registration.

Republicans have become less supportive of "no excuse" absentee voting. In 2018, 57% of Republicans favored allowing any voter to vote early or absentee without a documented reason, but that number dropped to 38% by 2021 [3, 5]. In contrast, Democrats' views have remained consistently high, with 84% supporting no-excuse early voting in 2021 [5].

![Republican support for no-excuse absentee voting has declined since 2018, while Democratic support remains high.](image2)

Similarly, Republican support for automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote has decreased. In 2018, 49% of Republicans supported automatic voter registration, a figure that declined to 38% by 2021 [7]. Democratic support remains high, at 82% in 2021, which is nearly unchanged in recent years [5].

![Support for automatic voter registration among Republicans decreased while remaining high and constant among Democrats from 2018 to 2021.](image3)

In summary, from 2018 to 2021, Republican support for 'no excuse' early or absentee voting and automatic voter registration decreased, while Democratic support for both remained consistently high.

There are notable differences in how Democrats and Republicans view making Election Day a national holiday and requiring photo identification for voting, with shifts in these views between 2018 and 2021.

Regarding making Election Day a national holiday, Democrats are more likely to favor this policy in 2021 compared to 2018, with a 7 percentage point increase [1]. Republicans' support, however, has remained relatively stable [1].
![Making Election Day a national holiday was favored more in 2021 than 2018.](image2)
In terms of requiring photo ID to vote, Republicans overwhelmingly support this policy, and this support has remained consistently high since 2018 [6].
![Requiring photo ID from all voters has not changed much from 2018 to 2021.](image2)
While majorities in both parties favor requiring photo ID, Republicans are considerably more likely to *strongly* favor it (81% of Republicans compared to 30% of Democrats) [4]. A significant partisan gap is also evident, 93% of Republicans support this policy [6]. Democrats' support has remained stable [6].

In summary, between 2018 and 2021, Democratic support for making Election Day a national holiday increased, while Republican support remained stable; support for requiring photo ID to vote remained overwhelmingly high among Republicans and stable among Democrats.

Latino voters' party affiliations have remained relatively stable from 2019 to 2022, with a consistent preference for the Democratic Party. ![Party Affiliation of Latino Voters from 2019 to 2022](image2) In 2022, 64% of Latino registered voters identified with or leaned toward the Democratic Party, compared to 33% for the Republican Party [2]. This nearly two-to-one margin has shifted little over the past few years [2].

Key issues for Latino voters in the 2022 congressional elections include the economy (80%), health care (71%), violent crime and education (70% each), and gun policy (66%) [10]. Abortion has risen significantly in importance, from 42% in March to 57% in August 2022 [8].
![Key Issues for Latino Voters in the 2022 Congressional Elections](image3)

Demographic factors influence preferences:
-   **Strength of Hispanic Identity**: 60% of those who say being Hispanic is extremely or very important to their identity would vote for the Democratic candidate [7].
-   **Religious Affiliation**: 59% of Catholic and 60% of Latino voters with no religious affiliation would vote for democratic candidate, compared with 32% of Evangelical Protestants. ![Preferences Based on Demographic Factors](image4)
In summary, Latino voters have maintained a strong preference for the Democratic Party from 2019 to 2022, with the economy, health care, violent crime, education, and gun policy as top issues, and abortion significantly rising in importance.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans hold significantly different views on both Trump's future political role and the perception of racial discrimination.

Regarding Trump's future, a large majority (94%) of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners believe he should not remain a national political figure [7]. In stark contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners want Trump to remain a national political figure, with 41% even suggesting he should run for president in 2024 [7]. This divide is visually represented. ![{conclusion}](image4)

On the issue of racial discrimination, the views are also sharply divided. 73% of Latino Democrats and leaners believe that the bigger problem is people *not* seeing racial discrimination where it exists [1]. Conversely, 62% of Latino Republicans and leaners believe the bigger problem is people seeing racial discrimination where it does *not* exist[1].
![{conclusion}](image5)

In summary, Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly oppose Trump's continued political involvement and are concerned about the denial of racial discrimination, while Hispanic Republicans largely support Trump's continued influence and are concerned about false accusations of racial discrimination.

Hispanic registered voters' views on Donald Trump's political future are strongly correlated with their party affiliation and views on other key issues like racial discrimination and gun control [3].

A significant majority (73%) of Hispanic registered voters do not want Trump to remain a national political figure [6, 8]. This sentiment is overwhelmingly strong among Latino Democrats (94%) [6, 8].
![Hispanic registered voters largely disapprove of President Joe Biden’s handling of the U.S.-Mexico border situation.](image4)
In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans want Trump to remain a national political figure, with 41% of them wanting him to run for president in 2024 [6].

On gun policy, there's a clear partisan divide, about seven-in-ten Hispanics (73%) prioritize gun control, with Hispanic Democrats about twice as likely as Hispanic Republicans to hold this view (85% vs. 45%) [7].
![Among all Hispanics, 73% support gun control, 85% of Democrat/Lean Democrat, and 45% of Republican/Lean Republican.](image3)

Views on racial discrimination also diverge along party lines [9]. More Latino Democrats than Republicans believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists is a significant problem [9, 10].
![Among all Latinos, 61% state that people not seeing racial discrimination is a problem while 35% state people seeing racial discrimination is the issue.](image5)

The views of Latino registered voters on Trump's political future are related to and divided by political affiliation along with their views on the importance of controlling gun ownership and whether people not seeing racial discrimination is a major concern.

Hispanic Republicans and Democrats hold distinctly different views on both Donald Trump's future political role and the perception of racial discrimination.

A majority of Hispanic Republicans (63%) want Trump to remain a national political figure, with 41% of them even suggesting he should run for president in 2024 [6]. In stark contrast, nearly all Latino Democrats (94%) believe Trump should not remain a national political figure [6]. This division is visually represented in a chart showing the breakdown of opinions within each party [5].
![A breakdown of Hispanic registered voters' views on whether Trump should remain a national political figure.](image5)

Regarding racial discrimination, the views are similarly polarized. About six-in-ten Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (62%) believe that people seeing racial discrimination where it does not exist is a bigger problem [10]. The data find visual support, illustrating the difference among all Latinos, Democrats/Lean Democrats, and Republicans/Lean Republicans [2].
![A breakdown of opinions among Latinos on the issue of people seeing or not seeing racial discrimination.](image2)

Conversely, nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (73%) say that people not seeing racial discrimination where it does exist is the bigger problem [10].

In summary, Hispanic Republicans largely favor Trump's continued political involvement and are more concerned about perceived overstatements of racial discrimination, while Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly oppose Trump's return and are more concerned about the under-recognition of racial discrimination.

Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism vary significantly based on political affiliation and age.

Among Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners, a substantial majority (68%) view capitalism positively [1]. In contrast, Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are more divided, with 50% viewing capitalism positively and a near-equal split on socialism (50% positive vs. 48% negative) [1, 8].
![image3](image3)
This image shows that 68% of Hispanic Republicans view Capitalism positively, while that number is 50% among Democrats. [1,8]

Age also plays a crucial role in these perceptions. Younger Hispanics (18-29) are more evenly divided on socialism, with 46% having a positive impression [5, 6].
![image5](image5)
The image shows, for those ages 18-29 years old, the net positive and negative percentage is the same. [5,6]

Older Hispanics, particularly those aged 50 and older, show a majority negative view of socialism [5, 6].

Overall, Hispanic Republicans have a more favorable view of capitalism, while Hispanic Democrats are more divided on both capitalism and socialism, and younger Hispanics are more open to socialism than older generations.

Hispanics' views on socialism and capitalism vary significantly across political affiliations.

A larger share of Hispanics have a negative impression of socialism (53%) than a positive one (41%) [5]. In contrast, a majority of Hispanics (54%) have a positive view of capitalism, compared to 41% who have a negative view [5].

![Hispanics' views of capitalism across political affiliations](image1)

Political affiliation plays a significant role in these views. Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split on their views of socialism, with 50% viewing it positively and 48% negatively [4].
![Hispanics' views of socialism across political affiliations](image3)

About two-thirds of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (68%) have a positive view of capitalism, which is a greater share than among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (50%) [6].

In summary, Hispanic Republicans are more likely to have a positive view of capitalism and a negative view of socialism, while Hispanic Democrats are more divided in their opinions on both economic systems.

The perceptions of political parties' efforts to earn Latino votes vary significantly across different demographic groups.

Many Latinos believe the Democratic Party works hard to earn their votes [2]. Specifically, immigrants, Spanish-dominant Latinos, Catholics, and evangelical Protestants hold this view [9].  For example, 48% of Spanish-dominant Latinos and 44% of foreign-born Latinos believe the Democratic party works hard to earn their votes. ![{Perceptions of Political Parties' Efforts to Earn Latino Votes by Demographics}](image1)

In contrast, far fewer Latinos believe the Republican Party works hard to earn their votes [3, 6]. The data indicates that only 19% of all Latinos strongly or somewhat agree with this statement. ![{Perceptions of Republicans' Efforts to Earn Latino Votes}](image4)

Furthermore, there's a notable difference in opinion between those who identify as or lean towards Democrats versus Republicans. Among Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners, a majority, including 70% of liberals and 61% of conservatives and moderates, do *not* believe Republicans work hard to earn Latino votes [7]. A significant 51% of Latino Democrats believe that the Democratic party is working hard to earn the votes of Latinos. ![{Perceptions of Democrats' Efforts to Earn Latino Votes}](image5)

There is a great deal of perceived difference between the two major U.S. political parties [10]. A significant portion of Hispanic Democrats (54%) and Republicans (57%) acknowledge a substantial difference between the parties [1]. ![{Perceptions of Differences Between Political Parties}](image2) This perception is less strong among independent Hispanics who lean towards either party [1].

Overall, these findings suggest a political landscape where the Democratic Party is generally seen as making more of an effort to engage Latino voters, while the Republican Party is perceived as less engaged, creating a significant challenge for the GOP in attracting this growing demographic.

The perceptions suggest a political landscape where the Democratic Party is viewed more favorably by specific Latino demographics, creating both opportunities and challenges for both parties in engaging this diverse electorate.

Latino voters' views on how well the Democratic and Republican parties engage with them vary significantly based on political affiliation, and these views are somewhat reflected in the relatively stable party affiliation trends.

About  $56\%$  of Hispanic Republicans believe the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes [1]. The perception is supported by the data.  ![Perception of Democratic and Republican efforts by political affiliations.](image5)
About  $35\%$  of Hispanic Democrats say that the Republican Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes [1].

In terms of caring about Latinos,   $36\%$  of Latino Republicans believe the Democratic Party cares, while only  $21\%$  of Latino Democrats believe the Republican Party cares [8]. These perceptions align with the broader trend where Latino registered voters lean towards the Democratic Party by a nearly two-to-one margin ( $64\%$  vs.  $33\%$) [2].

![Latino party affiliation trends from 2019 to 2022.](image2)

This trend has remained relatively stable over the past few years [2]. While substantial shares of Latino partisans have at least a somewhat favorable view of the opposing party [6], a significant percentage ( $45\%$) see a great deal of difference between the parties [5].

The data suggests that, the perceptions of party efforts differ significantly among Hispanic Republicans and Democrats, with party affiliation remaining relatively stable over recent years.

The perceptions of party differences and support among Hispanics have remained relatively stable in recent years, with notable distinctions based on political affiliation [10].

A significant portion of Hispanics do not perceive a substantial difference between the Democratic and Republican parties [1]. About half of Hispanics report not seeing a great deal of difference between the two major parties, with 36% saying there is a fair amount of difference and 16% stating there is hardly any difference [6]. However, 45% do see a great deal of difference [6]. These perceptions are nearly identical between Hispanic Democrats and Republicans, with 47% of Democrats and 48% of Republicans seeing a great deal of difference [6].
![A chart shows how Hispanic Democrats and Republicans differ in their perceptions of the two parties.](image5)

Despite the mixed views on party differences, Hispanics generally favor the Democratic Party [5]. Latino registered voters prefer the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by nearly a two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [8].

![The graph shows the preference to Democtratic Party or Republican Party from 2019 to 2022.](image2)

Majorities of Latino adults express positive views of the Democratic Party, with 71% saying it works hard for Latinos' votes, 63% saying it really cares about Latinos, and 60% saying it represents their interests [9]. In contrast, fewer Hispanics hold these views about the Republican Party, though 45% say the GOP works hard to earn their votes [9].

![A comparative chart showing Hispanics' views on whether each party works hard for their votes, cares about them, and represents their interests.](image4)

In summary, while about half of Hispanics see little difference between the two major parties, a strong majority consistently lean towards the Democratic Party, and this preference has remained stable over the past few years.

The views of Latino voters on the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties have been mixed, with a significant portion not perceiving substantial distinctions.

About half of Hispanics do not see much difference between the Democratic and Republican parties [1]. Specifically, 36% believe there is a fair amount of difference, and 16% see hardly any difference at all [1]. However, 45% of Hispanics believe there is a great deal of difference between the parties [1]. This perception is nearly evenly split among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (47%) and Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (48%) [1].

![A chart showing the percentage of Hispanics who perceive differences between the Democratic and Republican parties.](image1)

Despite these mixed views, Latino registered voters predominantly favor the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a nearly two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [6]. This preference has remained relatively stable over the past few years, indicating little change in party identification [2, 6].
![The graph shows the party affiliation of Latino registered voters from 2019 to 2022.](image2)

Latino voters’ future party affiliation remains uncertain [10].

In summary, while about half of Latino voters do not perceive significant differences between the Democratic and Republican parties, a substantial majority still favor the Democratic Party, and this affiliation has remained relatively stable in recent years.

Americans generally perceive STEM jobs as offering higher compensation than jobs in other industries [1, 3, 8]. A majority of Americans (71%) believe STEM jobs offer better compensation [3, 4].

However, perceptions of specific job characteristics within STEM vary between men and women.
![image1](image1)
Men in STEM are more likely than women in STEM to value higher pay (59% vs 48%) and opportunities for promotion (57% vs 46%) [9, image1]. Women in STEM, on the other hand, are more inclined to value a job focused on helping others, with 59% considering it important, compared to 31% of men [9, image1]. While both genders value the flexibility to balance work and family, there is no significant difference between their views on this characteristic [image1].

In summary, while a large majority of Americans recognize STEM jobs for their higher pay, within the STEM field, men prioritize pay and promotion more than women, while women place a higher value on jobs that focus on helping others.

Men and women in STEM value some job characteristics similarly, but they also differ significantly in other areas. Both groups highly value flexibility in balancing work and family obligations [1, 7, 9]. ![Both men and women in STEM value flexibility to balance work/family at 71% and 76% respectively.](image4)

However, women in STEM are much more likely than men to prioritize jobs focused on helping others. 59% of women value jobs that help others, compared to 31% of men [1, 7]. ![59% of women in STEM value having a job focused on helping others, while only 31% of men in STEM share the same value.](image4)

Conversely, men tend to place a higher premium on high pay and opportunities for promotion than women do [7]. ![Men in STEM value having opportunities for promotion and a high-paying job more than women in STEM, by 11% and 9% respectively.](image4)

These differing values relate to the challenges women face in STEM. A significant portion of the public, and an even larger percentage of women in STEM, believe that a lack of encouragement for girls from an early age is a major reason for their underrepresentation [5]. Many also point to gender discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions as a significant barrier [3, 10].

One proposed solution is improving K-8 education to make STEM subjects more appealing to girls and emphasize the need for more women in these fields [4, 8].

The differences job characteristics is that women place greater importance on work that helps others, while men tend to focus more on pay and advancement.

Americans see a range of explanations for why women and minorities are underrepresented in STEM fields [10].

One major reason cited for the underrepresentation of women in STEM is discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions, with 39% of Americans identifying this as a significant factor [!, image1]. Another prominent reason is the lack of encouragement for girls to pursue STEM from an early age, also at 39% [!, image1].

![image1](image1) shows the percentages of perceived reasons for underrepresentation of women vs. Black and Hispanic individuals in STEM.

For blacks and Hispanics, the leading perceived reason is the lack of access to quality education to prepare them for STEM fields (42%) [!, image1]. Similar to women, not being encouraged to pursue STEM from an early age is also a significant factor (41%) [!, image1]. While discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotion is considered a major reason, it is cited less frequently (31%) compared to the lack of educational access and early encouragement [!, image1].

There are notable differences in the perceived reasons. Discrimination is cited more often as a reason for the underrepresentation of women (39%) than for blacks and Hispanics (31%) [!, image1]. A lack of access to quality education is highlighted more for blacks and Hispanics (42%) than for women, while early encouragement is almost equally important for both groups [9, !, image1].

The main reasons for underrepresentation in STEM jobs differ, with discrimination and early encouragement being prominent for women, and educational access and early encouragement for blacks and Hispanics.

STEM workers generally have higher levels of education compared to non-STEM workers [7]. Specifically, 65% of STEM workers have at least a bachelor's degree, compared to 32% of non-STEM workers [7].

The breakdown of education levels for STEM-employed individuals is as follows:
*   **High school or less:** 7%
*   **Some college:** 28%
*  **Bachelor's degree:** 36%
*   **Postgraduate degree:** 29%

![Education levels of STEM and non-STEM workers](image2)

In contrast, the education levels for non-STEM employed individuals are:

*   **High school or less:** 37%
*   **Some college:** 31%
*   **Bachelor's degree:** 21%
*   **Postgraduate degree:** 12% [7]

![Education levels of STEM and non-STEM workers](image2)

Most STEM workers (66%) are employed in the private, for-profit sector, a figure substantively identical to that of all employed adults [8].
Engineers and architects (82%) and computer workers (77%) are among the most likely to work for a private employer [8].

![Employer types for all employed, STEM, and non-STEM workers](image4)

STEM workers are much less likely to be self-employed (6%) compared to other workers (11%) [10].

In conclusion, STEM-employed individuals have higher education levels than non-STEM-employed individuals, with a majority working in the private, for-profit sector, similar to the general employed population.

STEM workers generally have higher levels of education compared to non-STEM workers [6]. They are about twice as likely to have earned at least a bachelor's degree (65% vs. 32%) [6]. Additionally, 29% of STEM workers have a master's, doctorate, or professional degree, compared to only 12% of non-STEM workers [6].

![Educational attainment of STEM and non-STEM workers](image2)

The share of those who work for private, for-profit employers are substantively identical between all employed adults, STEM and non-STEM workers, each is 66%[4]. The long-term trend shows little change in the proportion of the sector working for private, for-profit in STEM jobs and non-STEM jobs [4].
![Employment sectors for all employed, STEM jobs, and non-STEM jobs.](image3)

In conclusion, STEM workers have significantly higher educational attainment than non-STEM workers, and the share of STEM and non-STEM workers working in private, for-profit companies has remained the same.

Experiences of discrimination in STEM jobs differ significantly among racial groups and between genders.

Black STEM employees report the highest rates of discrimination. A majority (62%) of Black STEM workers report experiencing discrimination at work due to their race or ethnicity [3, 5, 8]. This is substantially higher than the rates reported by Asians (44%), Hispanics (42%), and whites (13%) in STEM jobs [5, 7].
![Discrimination experiences by race in STEM jobs.](image5)

In terms of gender-based discrimination, half (50%) of women in STEM jobs report experiencing gender discrimination in the workplace [6]. The types of discrimination experienced include earning less than a man doing the same job (29%), being treated as if they were not competent (29%), experiencing repeated, small slights (20%), and receiving less support from senior leaders (18%) [6].
![Gender discrimination in STEM jobs.](image2)

Women in STEM, especially those in computer jobs or majority-male workplaces, are significantly more likely to experience workplace discrimination due to their gender [2].
![Experiences of women in computer jobs vs. men.](image3)

In summary, Black STEM workers are the most likely to report racial discrimination, while women in STEM are significantly more likely than men to experience gender-based discrimination.

Women in STEM who work in majority-male workplaces report significantly higher rates of gender discrimination and feelings of inequity compared to those in majority-female or mixed-gender environments [6, 8].

A substantial 78% of women in STEM working in majority-male settings report experiencing gender discrimination, compared to 44% of women in other STEM work settings [6].

![image4](image4)

Forms of discrimination commonly experienced by women in STEM include earning less than men for the same job, being treated as incompetent, experiencing repeated small slights, and receiving less support from senior leaders [9]. Women in majority-male environments often feel they need to work harder to prove themselves [10]. Specifically, 79% of women in mostly male workplaces feel the need to prove themselves, compared to 52% in more gender-balanced settings and, although not in the text, the graph shows that it affects 60% of Men in STEM jobs.

![image1](image1)

In workplaces where most employees are men, about half of women in STEM feel that their gender has hindered their success [4]. Specifically, 48% of women in mostly-male workplaces believe their gender made it harder to succeed, versus only 14% in workplaces with a more even gender mix [8].

In conclusion, women in STEM in male-dominated workplaces experience more discrimination and feel their gender is a greater impediment to success than women in more gender-balanced environments.

Several factors influence the self-identification of Hispanics in the U.S. across different generations. These include generational distance from immigrant roots, cultural links, upbringing, and personal experiences.

Generational distance plays a significant role. The share of individuals self-identifying as Hispanic decreases with each subsequent generation [1].
![Generational Differences in Hispanic Identity](image1)

Experiences related to a Hispanic background vary across generations [2]. For example, the reasons why some individuals with Hispanic ancestry don't identify as Hispanic are linked to mixed backgrounds, limited contact with Hispanic relatives, and few cultural links [10].
![Reasons for Not Identifying as Hispanic](image2)

Furthermore, The vast majority (84%) of self-identified Hispanics say having a Spanish last name is not necessary to be considered Hispanic [4]. A majority (58%) of immigrant Latinos, 84% of second-generation Latinos, and 92% of third or higher generation Latinos believe that speaking Spanish does not make someone Latino [6].

![Spanish Language and Hispanic Identity](image5)

In summary, self-identification as Hispanic in the U.S. is influenced by generational distance from immigrant roots, upbringing, cultural links, and personal experiences, with identification decreasing in later generations.

The experiences of attending cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions vary significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics and differ even more for non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry.

For self-identified Hispanics, the likelihood of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations decreases across generations.  A majority, 59%, of immigrant self-identified Hispanics reported that their parents often took them to such celebrations [9]. This percentage drops to 49% for the second generation and further declines to 35% for the third or higher generation [6].
![image3](image3)

A similar trend is observed in parental discussions about pride in their country of origin. While 57% of immigrant and 50% of second-generation self-identified Hispanics reported their parents often talked about their pride in their roots, this number drops to 33% for the third generation [7].
![image4](image4)

In stark contrast, only 9% of self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry reported their parents took them to Latino cultural celebrations [1], with 60% saying it never happened [1].
![image3](image3)

Also, only 9% of those same self-identified non-Hispanics reported that their parents encouraged spanish language, highlighting the distance they have from their immigrant history. [3].

Experiences with Hispanic cultural activities and parental pride discussions fade significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics, with non-Hispanics having minimal exposure.

The frequency of attending Latino cultural celebrations and engaging in parental pride discussions varies significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics.

Among self-identified Hispanics, the likelihood of attending cultural celebrations decreases across generations. Immigrant self-identified Hispanics report the highest frequency, with 59% saying their parents often took them to such celebrations [9]. This number drops to 49% for the second generation [4] and further to 35% for the third or higher generation [4].
![image5](image5)
This trend is visualized in image5, which shows the frequency of parents taking their children to Hispanic/Latino cultural celebrations.

Parental discussions about pride in their country of origin show a similar pattern. 57% of immigrant and 50% of second-generation self-identified Hispanics report their parents often talked about their pride [10]. This percentage significantly decreases to 33% by the third generation [10].
![image3](image3)

For self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, the experiences are markedly different. Only 9% report that their parents often took them to Latino cultural celebrations [5], and a similar percentage (9%) say their parents often encouraged them to speak Spanish [6]. The majority (60%) say their parents never took them to these celebrations [5].

In summary, attendance at Latino cultural celebrations and discussions of parental pride decrease across generations of self-identified Hispanics, while remaining very low for non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry.

The experiences and cultural practices of self-identified Hispanics differ significantly across generations.

Language dominance shifts dramatically across generations. Among foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics, 61% are Spanish dominant [9]. This drops sharply to only 6% in the second generation and virtually none in the third generation [9]. English dominance rises across generations. Only 7% of foreign-born self-identified Hispanics mostly use English. This percentage increases to 43% in the second generation [5].
![Language dominance among Hispanic groups](image5)

Parental encouragement to speak Spanish also declines across generations. While 85% of foreign-born self-identified Hispanics reported that their parents often encouraged them to speak Spanish, this share decreases to 68% among the U.S.-born second generation and further to 26% of the third or higher generation [6].
![Parents often encouraged them to speak Spanish](image1)

In terms of participation in Hispanic cultural celebrations, 59% of immigrant self-identified Hispanics say that their parents often took them to such celebrations when they were growing up [1]. This percentage is similar (49%) for the second generation [3], the share is smaller (35%) of third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics [3].
![Took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations](image3)

In summary, language dominance shifts from Spanish to English, parental encouragement to speak Spanish decreases, and participation in cultural celebrations declines across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

The connection to Hispanic heritage and language proficiency changes significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

Among self-identified Hispanics, connections with ancestral origins decline as immigrant roots become more distant [7].
![How connected people feel to their countries of origin](image1)
First-generation immigrants feel the strongest connection to their country of origin (82%), which decreases in the second generation (69%) and further reduces by the third or higher generation (44%) [7].

Language proficiency also shifts across generations. Spanish dominance is high among first-generation immigrants (61%), but sharply declines in the second generation (6%), with almost none of the third generation being Spanish dominant [2].
![Language dominance across generations.](image5)
English dominance increases across the generations. Among foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics, only 7% are English dominant. The second generation sees this rise to 43% [5]. By the third or higher generation, English dominance reaches 75%, and bilingualism decreases to 24% [10].

Although Spanish usage declines, many Hispanics, including 88% of self-identified Hispanics and 64% of self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, support the importance of future generations speaking Spanish [9].

In summary, connection to Hispanic heritage and Spanish language proficiency decreases across generations, while English dominance increases, yet there's strong support for maintaining Spanish in future generations.

The language dominance and sense of connection to Hispanic heritage significantly vary across different generations of self-identified Hispanics.

Among self-identified Hispanics, connections with ancestral national origins decline as immigrant roots become more distant [1].
The connection to their country of origin is reported as very or somewhat connected by 82% of Hispanic immigrants. This feeling decreases to 69% in the second generation and further reduces to 44% by the third generation [1].
![Feelings of connection to the country of origin among Hispanic generations.](image2)

Spanish dominance significantly decreases across generations. 61% of Hispanic immigrants are Spanish dominant [3]. This dominance drops to only 6% in the second generation and nearly none in the third generation [3].
![Language dominance among Hispanic generations.](image3)

English dominance, conversely, increases across the generations [5].
Bilingualism is prevalent among second-generation self-identified Latinos, with about 51% being bilingual, which decreases to 24% in the third or higher generation [4].

In summary, as the generations of self-identified Hispanics become further removed from their immigrant roots, their connection to their ancestral country and Spanish language dominance decrease, while English dominance increases.

Language dominance shifts significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics, with a marked increase in English dominance and a decrease in Spanish dominance. Among first-generation (immigrant) Hispanics, a large majority (61%) are Spanish dominant [9]. This drastically reduces to only 6% in the second generation [9], and essentially none in the third generation [9].

![Language dominance among Hispanics by generation.](image2)

Concurrently, English dominance rises across generations. While only 7% of foreign-born Hispanics are English dominant, this figure increases to 43% in the second generation and further to 75% by the third or higher generation [10]. The second generation shows a high level of bilingualism (51%) [2].

![How connected people feel to Hispanic heritage.](image5)

The sense of connection to their family's country of origin also diminishes across generations. While 82% of first-generation Hispanics feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin, this drops to 69% for the second generation and further to 44% for the third or higher generation[4].

In summary, language dominance shifts from Spanish to English, and the sense of connection to ancestral origin weakens across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

The perception of connection to Hispanic heritage and its advantages differ significantly among generations.

Foreign-born Hispanics and second-generation Hispanics tend to feel a stronger bond with their family’s country of origin [4]. 82% of foreign-born and 69% of second-generation Hispanics report feeling very or somewhat connected [10]. However, this connection diminishes in the third or higher generations, with only 44% feeling connected [10].
![How connected people feel to their Hispanic heritage, divided by generations.](image3)

In terms of the perceived advantages of being Hispanic, second-generation Hispanics report the highest advantage. Half (52%) believe their background has positively impacted their lives [2]. This contrasts with immigrant Hispanics (28%) and third or higher-generation Hispanics (24%) [2].
![Perceived advantages of being Hispanic across different generations.](image1)

These generational differences can be attributed to factors such as declining immigration and high intermarriage rates, which may influence the experiences and cultural identities of U.S.-born Hispanics [5, 6].

In summary, the connection to Hispanic heritage and perceived advantages decreases from foreign-born to third or higher-generation Hispanics, with second-generation Hispanics experiencing the most advantages.

Experiences and connections to Hispanic heritage, including perceived advantages, vary significantly across generations among self-identified Hispanics [4].

Regarding connections to their family's country of origin, there's a clear generational decline. Eight-in-ten Hispanic immigrants (82%) report feeling very or somewhat connected to their country of origin. This connection remains relatively strong among second-generation Hispanics (69%) but drops significantly by the third generation, with only 44% feeling connected [7].
![Generational differences in connection to the family's country of origin among Hispanics.](image4)

The perceived impact of Hispanic heritage on their lives also changes across generations. Second-generation Hispanics are the most likely to view their Hispanic background as an advantage (52%) [8].
![How Hispanic heritage affects an individual's life, as perceived by different generations.](image5)
In contrast, the percentages are considerably lower for immigrant Hispanics (28%) and third or higher generation Hispanics (24%) [8].

Overall, connections to Hispanic heritage and its perceived advantages decrease across generations among self-identified Hispanics.

The perception of racial identity and the impact of Hispanic heritage vary significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics in the U.S.

Experiences with discrimination are reported less frequently among higher generations of adults with Hispanic ancestry [8]. While 39% of self-identified Hispanics report feeling discriminated against due to their background, this sentiment decreases across generations [8].
![image4](image4) shows the percentages of self-identified Hispanics, categorized by generation, who have experienced discrimination.

A key aspect of this shift is how individuals perceive they are viewed by others. The majority of Hispanics believe that passersby would perceive them as Hispanic; however, this belief diminishes across generations [9]. Among self-identified Hispanics, 78% of immigrants believe strangers would see them as Hispanic, which decreases to two-thirds among the second generation and 46% among the third or higher generation [10].
![image5](image5) shows how self-identified Hispanics of different generations perceive their racial or ethnic identity would be viewed by others.

Moreover, the impact of Hispanic heritage on their lives is perceived differently across generations. Half (52%) of second-generation Hispanics report their Hispanic background as an advantage, compared to only 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of third or higher generation Hispanics [2].
![image2](image2) further details how different generations of Hispanics perceive the impact of their heritage.

The connection to Hispanic identity also weakens across generations.
![image1](image1) illustrates the declining connection to Hispanic identity across generations.

Additionally, the composition of friendship networks varies significantly, with 77% of immigrant Latinos having mostly Latino friends, which drops to 37% among third or higher generation self-identified Latinos [6].
![image3](image3) displays the proportion of friends who are Hispanic or Latino across generations.

In summary, perceptions of racial identity among self-identified Hispanics in the U.S. shift across generations, with later generations experiencing less discrimination, feeling less impact from their Hispanic heritage, and having a weaker connection to their Hispanic identity.

Generational differences significantly impact both the perception of discrimination and racial identification among Hispanics.

Experiences with discrimination are more common among self-identified Latinos [4]. The share of those who feel discriminated against decreases across generations [7]. Among self-identified Hispanics, 78% of immigrants believe strangers would perceive them as Hispanic or Latino, a figure that drops to two-thirds for the second generation and 46% for the third or higher generation [5].

![How often U.S. adults with Hispanic ancestry have felt discriminated against.](image5)

As shown in the figure, the frequency of experiencing discrimination decreases across generations, with 39% (7% often and 32% sometimes) of self-identified Hispanics reporting discrimination, compared to only 7% (2% often and 5% sometimes) of self-identified non-Hispanics [image5]. First-generation, foreign-born Hispanics are more likely to report discrimination, with 42% feeling discriminated against either often or sometimes [6].

![How different generations see their race.](image4)

Moreover, perceptions of racial identity vary significantly across generations. A majority of self-identified non-Hispanics (59%) say they are seen as white, demonstrating a generational shift in racial identification [8, image4]. In contrast, among self-identified Hispanics, the perception of being seen as Hispanic or Latino decreases from 78% for the foreign-born to 46% for the third or higher generation [image4].

In conclusion, generational differences among Hispanics significantly influence the perception of discrimination, with higher experiences reported among earlier generations, and racial identification, with a notable shift towards identifying as white in later generations.

Generational differences significantly impact how Hispanics self-identify and use language. As immigrant roots become more distant, connections with ancestral national origins decline [1].

The share of Hispanics who primarily use "American" to describe themselves increases across generations [3]. While 65% of foreign-born Hispanics most often describe themselves by their country of origin/heritage, this drops to 26% in the third or higher generation. Concurrently, the percentage identifying as "American" rises from 7% among immigrants to 56% among the third generation or higher [3].
![Self-identification of Hispanics across generations](image1)

Spanish language dominance decreases sharply across generations. While 61% of Hispanic immigrants are Spanish-dominant, this falls to just 6% in the second generation, and nearly none in the third generation are Spanish-dominant [10]. The vast majority of second-generation (84%) and third or higher generation (92%) Latinos say speaking Spanish does not make someone Latino [8].
![Percentage of respondents indicating whether speaking Spanish is required for Latino identity.](image4)

Overall, generational differences significantly affect self-identification and language use of Hispanics, as connections to ancestral origins decrease and identification as "American" increases across generations.

There's a noticeable trend of Arab youth increasingly embracing modern values, while still being significantly influenced by traditional sources like family, friends, and religion [8].

The data indicates a shift over time. In 2011, a significantly higher percentage (83%) believed traditional values were important. This percentage decreased in subsequent years, with 65% in 2012, 60% in 2013, and 54% in 2014 holding that view. Concurrently, the percentage of those who believe traditional values are outdated and prefer modern values increased from 17% in 2011 to 46% in 2014.
![Chart showing a decreasing trend for traditional values and an increasing trend for modern values from 2011 to 2014.](image1)

It's important to remember that many still hold traditional values dear [1, 7].

![Data from 2014, broken down by country, revealing the percentage in each country who believe traditional values are outdated.](image3)
The views on traditional versus modern values differ significantly by country in 2014. For instance, in Oman, 60% think that 'Traditional values are outdated and belong in the past', compared to 40% who think 'Traditional values mean a lot to me and ought to be preserved'. While in Egypt, the split is closer to 50/50 [9, image3].

In summary, there's a growing trend towards embracing modern values among Arab youth, but the degree of this shift varies considerably across different countries.

In summary, The growth in ridership at Mountain View and Palo Alto stations, as key hubs along the Caltrain line, is a major factor contributing to current train overcrowding.

Over the past 24 months, Europe has experienced significant growth in venture-backed liquidity events, totaling $15 billion. ![Venture-backed liquidity events in the last 24 months were $15 Billion.](image4)

European venture capital (VC) has shown strong fundamentals in an inefficient market, with higher capital efficiency than the US. [5] The scarcity of VC money in Europe has led to lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency, approximately 70 percent higher than in the US. [7]

A comparison of key metrics reveals that while Europe produces smaller average exit values, the lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency compensate for this difference. [10] Specifically, the median multiple of cash invested is 7.2 in Europe, compared to 4.5 in the USA. ![The median multiple of cash invested is 7.2 in Europe, compared to 4.5 in the USA.](image3) Although the median exit valuation in Europe is $173 million, compared to $236 million in the USA, a higher percentage of European exits have a multiple of cash greater than or equal to 5, at 57.26%, versus 47.27% in the USA.
![Venture capital comparison between Europe and USA, including total capital invested and exit numbers.](image1)

In terms of venture capital investments across different European countries, Germany had $0.8 billion invested and $4.4 billion in venture exits. ![Venture investments and exits in billions of dollars for Germany, UK, France, and other European countries.](image2) The UK followed with $1.4 billion invested and $3.9 billion in exits, while France had $1.1 billion invested and $3 billion in exits.

European VC is driving the best exit multiples globally. [2] More checks to LPs are being written in Europe than ever before. [4]

In summary, over the last 24 months, Europe has demonstrated robust venture-backed liquidity events and higher capital efficiency compared to the USA, despite smaller average exit values.

European venture capital (VC) is outperforming the US VC in terms of investment multiples, even though the average exit values are about 25% smaller [1]. This is largely due to lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency, which more than compensate for the smaller exit values [1]. European VC is producing higher exit multiples proportionally [1].

![image2](image2)

The median multiple of cash invested is 7.2 in Europe, compared to 4.5 in the USA. Although the median exit valuation is lower in Europe ($173 million) than in the USA ($236 million), a higher percentage of European exits have a multiple of cash greater than or equal to 5 (57.26% in Europe vs. 47.27% in the USA) [image2].
![image1](image1)

European VC-backed IPO performance also matches or exceeds US performance, both pre- and post-IPO [6]. The graph illustrates that the European IPO index value has generally outperformed the U.S. IPO index value over a certain period [image1].
European VC has a greater share of successful exits. [2]

In summary, European VC demonstrates better performance with higher investment multiples compared to the USA, despite smaller average exit values.

In-store Wi-Fi serves multiple purposes, benefiting both businesses and customers. Key uses include integrating Wi-Fi data with POS, CRM, and loyalty systems [2, 5, 7]. In-store Wi-Fi can be used for promotions delivered directly to customers [4]. Also, in-store Wi-Fi analytics give a full understanding of bandwidth usage [10].

The prevalence of Wi-Fi usage, especially for customer access, varies across sectors.
![Wi-Fi usage across different sectors](image2)

Overall, 42% of businesses offer Wi-Fi just for customer use, while 54% use it for both company and customer access. In sectors like Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass, customer-only Wi-Fi access is predominant (78%). However, in General Merchandise & Specialty, a mix of company and customer use is more common (51% for both, 46% for just customer use). In the Hospitality sector, Wi-Fi is predominantly for both company and customer use (85%), with a small percentage for customer-only use (8%).

In summary, the primary purposes of in-store Wi-Fi are to enhance customer experience, integrate with business systems, and deliver targeted promotions, with its prevalence for customer access varying significantly across different business sectors.

In-store Wi-Fi utilization varies across different sectors, with a focus on customer engagement and promotions [1, 4, 8].

Overall, a significant portion of businesses use Wi-Fi for both company and customer use.
![Wi-Fi usage distribution across different sectors, showing percentages for combined company and customer use, company use only, and customer use only.](image5)

However, the distribution changes across sectors:
*   **Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass Retail:** These sectors predominantly use Wi-Fi just for company use (78%) [image5].
*    **General Merchandise & Specialty:** These sectors showcase a more balanced approach, with 51% using it for both company and customer purposes, and 46% solely for company use. [image5].
*   **Hospitality:**  The hospitality sector predominantly utilizes Wi-Fi for both company and customer use, at 85% [image5].

Many companies are doing promotions to customers over Wi-Fi [1]. Wi-Fi information can also integrate with POS, CRM, and loyalty systems [3]. Stores utilize various analytics to assess Wi-Fi usage.
![Key Wi-Fi usage analytics, including traffic counting, session duration, device types, and customer behavior patterns.](image3)

The data show top in usage are traffic counting (56%), guest Wi-Fi session duration and what devices customer use are both 49%.[image3]

In summary, different sectors utilize in-store Wi-Fi differently, the main analytics used by stores to assess Wi-Fi usage are traffic counting, guest Wi-Fi session duration, and what devices customers use.

The impact of customer and employee Wi-Fi on loyalty and sales varies significantly across different sectors.

Regarding customer Wi-Fi, the hospitality sector sees the most substantial impact, with 61% of respondents saying it increases customer loyalty, resulting in a 2.7% increase in sales [4]. General merchandise stores also report a positive effect, with 22% indicating increased loyalty and a 2.2% rise in sales [4]. However, the food, drug, convenience, and mass merchant sector reports no impact on customer loyalty (0%) and only a marginal 0.3% increase in sales [4].
![Customer Wi-Fi impact on loyalty and sales by segment](image4)

When considering employee Wi-Fi access, the differences are also pronounced [5]. Overall, 48% of respondents believe employee Wi-Fi access increases customer loyalty, leading to a 3.4% increase in sales [5]. Once again, hospitality is high, 61% reporting improved customer loyalty and a 2.5% sales increase [5]. General merchandise stores show a stronger correlation with employee Wi-Fi, with 53% reporting increased loyalty and a 4.3% sales increase [5]. The food, drug, convenience, and mass merchant sector reports the lowest impact, with only 11% indicating increased loyalty and a 0.6% increase in sales [5].

![Employee Wi-Fi impact on loyalty and sales by segment.](image5)

Overall, providing both customer and employee Wi-Fi access can increase sales, and customer loyalty, the effect is significantly greater in the hospitality and general merchandise sectors.

Employee Wi-Fi access significantly impacts customer loyalty and sales, with varying degrees across different sectors [4, 7].

For the General Merchandise sector, 53% of respondents indicated that employee Wi-Fi access positively impacted customer loyalty, leading to a 4.3% increase in sales [image2]. The financial benefits are illustrated by an average sales increase of \$55.2 million for this sector, with an increase in EBITA of $21.4 million after WiFi/Mobile implementation.
![image2](image2)
The Food, Drug, Convenience, and Mass sector reported a modest 11% impact on customer loyalty, with a corresponding 0.6% increase in sales [image2]. This sector experienced an average sales increase of \$72.0 million and a \$26.1 million increase in EBITA [image4].
![image4](image4)
In the Hospitality sector, a substantial 61% of respondents noted a positive impact on customer loyalty from employee Wi-Fi access, resulting in a 2.5% increase in sales. This translates to an average sales increase of \$57.2 million and a \$15.8 million increase in EBITA for the Hospitality sector [image2, image4].
![image5](image5)
Overall, across all sectors, 48% of respondents say employee access to Wi-Fi increase customer loyalty, result in an average increase in sales of 3.4% [image2].

In summary, employee Wi-Fi access enhances customer loyalty and boosts sales across various sectors, leading to considerable financial benefits, especially in the General Merchandise and Hospitality sectors.

The impact of WiFi access on customer loyalty and sales differs significantly between the General Merchandise and Hospitality sectors [1], [8].

In the General Merchandise sector, 53% of respondents indicated that employee access to WiFi increases customer loyalty, with a corresponding sales increase of 4.3% [image2].  In contrast, the Hospitality sector saw a higher percentage (61%) reporting an impact on customer loyalty, but a lower sales increase of 2.5% [image2].
![image2](image2)

When examining the average increases after both customer and associate WiFi were added, General Merchandise experienced a 6.5% increase in sales.  ![image1](image1) shows, Hospitality had a slightly smaller sales increase of 5.2% [image1].

![image1](image1)

In summary, while a higher percentage of the Hospitality sector reports that WiFi access positively impacts customer loyalty, the General Merchandise sector sees a greater percentage increase in sales due to Wi-Fi.

Employee access to Wi-Fi increases customer loyalty and sales across various retail segments [1].

Overall, adding Wi-Fi capabilities leads to a 3.4% increase in sales and a 17.3% increase in EBITA [!,image3]. The impact varies significantly across different retail sectors:

*   **General Merchandise:** This sector sees the most substantial benefit, with a 6.5% increase in sales and a 32.1% increase in EBITA after adding Wi-Fi [!,image3].
* **Hospitality:** There is a 5.2% increase in sales, with EBITA rising by 17.4% [!,image3].

![image3](image3)

*   **Food, Drug, Convenience, Mass:** This sector experiences the smallest impact, with only a 0.9% increase in sales and a 5.8% increase in EBITA [!,image3].

![image1](image1)

The research indicates employee access to Wi-Fi influences upselling, offers, and information delivery to customers [8].

The increase in sales and profitability is different.

![image5](image5)

In conclusion, adding Wi-Fi results in increased sales and profitability (measured by EBITA) across all retail sectors, with the most significant gains seen in General Merchandise.

The growth in digital media and e-commerce significantly impacted the landscape for digital advertising and online sales between 2014 and 2018.

E-commerce sales saw a substantial increase. In 2014, total e-commerce sales were at $11 billion, with $3 billion from product e-commerce and $8 billion from travel and other services. By 2018, this figure had surged to $43 billion, with $13 billion from product e-commerce and $30 billion from travel and others.
![E-commerce sales projection, comparing 2014 to 2018.](image1)

This growth is further supported by infrastructure development, increased smartphone penetration, and advancements in online payment systems [3]. Digital payments, including debit cards and third-party wallets, played a crucial role, with projections indicating that by 2016, half of Indians would have debit cards [6].
![Comparison of payment methods in 2013 and projections for 2016.](image4)

Digital advertising also experienced a notable increase. Digital advertising spend in 2014 which include digital is 34.
![Digital advertising spend data from 2012 to 2016, with a CAGR of 29.9%.](image5)
It also indicated a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 29.9% in digital ad spend, making it the fastest-growing sector [8].
![Digital is the fastest growing sector with a 30% CAGR.](image3)

The e-commerce landscape is undergoing significant evolution, driven by factors such as infrastructure, demand, payments, investment, and talent.
![Current stage of e-commerce development.](image2)

In summary, between 2014 and 2018, the growth in digital media and e-commerce led to a substantial increase in both e-commerce sales and digital advertising spend, driven by technological advancements and increased digital penetration.

The primary factors driving the growth in eCommerce are infrastructure development, smartphone penetration, and advancements in payment systems [9]. The convenience and best prices available online are the value proposition for customers [8].

![The e-commerce evolution in India, showing initial growth with train, airline, and movie tickets, expanding into books, electronics, coupons, lifestyle, and eventually into furniture, jewellery, and homes.](image1)

E-commerce sales has significantly increased.
![eCommerce sales growth, showing an increase from $11 billion in 2014 to a projected $43 billion in 2018.](image4)

This chart divides the 2014 total into $8 billion for "Travel and Others" and $3 billion for "Product eCommerce," and the 2018 projection into $30 billion for "Travel and Others" and $13 billion for "Product eCommerce".

The age distribution of online shoppers shows that the majority are younger individuals.
![Age distribution of online buyers, showing that 55% are aged 26-35 years, 35% are 18-25 years, 8% are 36-45 years, and 2% are 45+ years.](image5)

The primary factors driving eCommerce growth from 2014 to 2018 are infrastructure and smartphone penetration, payments, online convenience, and competitive pricing, with the majority of online buyers(55%) aged between 26-35 years [8, 9].

The growth of eCommerce sales is driven by several key factors, including infrastructure development, smartphone penetration, the availability of online payment options, competitive pricing, and the convenience offered to customers [4]. These drivers align with the stages of market evolution.

Initially, the focus is on customer acquisition, with an emphasis on gross merchandise volume (GMV) [3]. As the market matures, there's a shift towards profitability, customer retention, and improving customer experience [3]. This progression is illustrated as:

![The graph shows the market share and GMV of women-influenced eCommerce from 2012 to 2016.](image1)

This graph highlights the significant growth in market share and GMV, demonstrating the increasing influence of women on eCommerce.

Mobile commerce also plays a critical role in this evolution:

![This image highlights mobile eCommerce transactions.](image2)

The image shows that over 50% of transactions for the top three eCommerce companies occur via mobile, underscoring the importance of mobile platforms in the market's development.

The stages in market is also related to
![This image shows the percentage of eCommerce users by age group.](image3)

The largest age group, 26-35 year-olds, makes up 55% of users.

The current stage of development also involves:

![A hockey stick graph depicting stages like inventory-led marketplace, acquisitions, and current trends.](image4)

Which highlights current trends such as acquisitions and the transition from inventory-led models to marketplaces.

This chart details the projected growth of product eCommerce and travel-related eCommerce.

![This chart compares eCommerce growth projections for 2014 and 2018, separating product eCommerce from travel.](image5)

It shows substantial growth from $11 billion in 2014 to a projected $43 billion in 2018, emphasizing the rapid expansion of the eCommerce market.

There is a strong emphasis on improving infrastructure and leveraging digital advancements [1], [10]. This is coupled with a strategic shift towards consolidation and profitability, with niche players finding unique positions in the market [3]. The dominant age group (26-35 year-olds), plays a significant role by representing the largest segment of users [3].

The drivers of growth in eCommerce sales, such as infrastructure development and smartphone penetration, align with the market's evolution from customer acquisition to retention and profitability, heavily influenced by the 26-35 age group.

The evolution of payment methods and consumer demographics significantly influences e-commerce opportunities in India by increasing accessibility and transaction volumes.

As digital payment penetration rises, the share of Cash on Delivery (COD) shipments is decreasing [6]. There's an uptick in EMI payments with increasing order values, and third-party wallets are expected to become popular, similar to China [6]. ![image4](image4) further shows the anticipated changes, with COD dropping from 60% in 2013 to a projected 50% in 2016, while debit card usage increases from 12% to 15% and 3rd party wallets from 0% to 7%. This shift towards digital payments expands the reach of e-commerce to a broader consumer base.

![image1](image1) shows Women Influenced GMV (Gross Merchandise Volume) growth.

Consumer demographics also play a crucial role. Data indicates that the majority of online shoppers are young, with 55% aged 26-35 years and 35% aged 18-25 years, with smaller percentages in older age groups.

![image5](image5)

In summary, the move towards diverse digital payment options, coupled with a young and growing online consumer base, is driving e-commerce growth in India.

The distribution of online retail payment methods in India saw a shift between 2013 and 2016. Cash on Delivery (COD) remained the most popular method, but its share decreased from 60% to 50% [6]. Credit card usage also dropped from 16% to 12%, while debit card usage increased from 12% to 15%. Net banking stayed relatively stable, decreasing slightly from 12% to 11%. EMI usage saw a significant increase, rising from 1% to 5%. Usage of third-party wallets are predicted to grow to 7%, indicating their growing popularity [6].

![Payment methods in 2013 and 2016](image4)

In terms of online retail categories by transaction volume in India, fashion, footwear, and accessories constituted the largest share at 35% [10]. Books came in second at 21%, followed by computers, cameras, electronics, and appliances at 10%. Mobile, tablets, and accessories accounted for 9% of transactions, as did babycare products at 8% each.
![Online Retail category by transaction distribution](image5)
There is no information regarding the impact on gross margin contributions.

In summary, COD decreased, debit cards and EMI payments increased, and third-party wallets' popularity is predicted to rise in online retail payment between 2013 to 2016, while fashion, footwear, and accessories, then books, were the largest categories.

The shift in online retail payment methods in India from 2013 to 2016 shows a significant decrease in Cash on Delivery (COD) and an increase in the use of digital payment options.

In 2013, COD was the dominant payment method, accounting for 60% of transactions. However, this is projected to decrease to 50% by 2016 [10]. ![Projected changes in online retail payment methods in India from 2013 to 2016.](image1) Concurrently, credit card usage is expected to decrease from 16% to 12%, debit card usage to increase from 12% to 15%, and net banking to remain relatively stable, decreasing by just 1%.[10]. Notably, EMI payments are projected to increase from 1% to 5%, and 3rd party wallets are expected to rise significantly from 0% to 7% [10].

This transition indicates that e-commerce platforms will need to adapt by integrating a wider variety of digital payment options. The rise of 3rd party wallets, in particular, suggests a growing demand for these services, similar to the trend in China [10]. E-commerce businesses will likely need to incorporate these wallets, as well as support EMI payments, to cater to the changing preferences of consumers.
![The two-sided e-commerce business model includes payment integration as a critical element.](image2)

The increasing digital payments penetration are reducing in the share of COD shipments [10].

In summary, the projected shift in online retail payment methods in India from 2013 to 2016 is expected to drive e-commerce platforms to diversify their payment integrations, with a particular focus on 3rd party wallets and EMI options, and reduce reliance on COD.

Let's analyze the relationship between transaction volumes and gross margin contributions in online retail, and consider the implications for the e-commerce supply and demand model.

First, let's examine the category-wise breakdown of online retail transactions:

![Online retail categories by percentage of transactions.](image3)

This pie chart shows the percentage of transactions for different product categories. Fashion, Footwear & Accessories lead with 35%, followed by Books (21%), and Computers, Cameras, Electronics & Appliances(10%) [image3].

Now, let's compare this with the category-wise gross margin:
![Online retail category breakdown, showing the percentage split of different product types.](image1)

This pie chart displays the gross margin contribution of various product categories. Mobile, Tablets & Accessories contribute the most at 35%, followed by Fashion, Footwear & Accessories at 28%, and then Computers, Cameras, Electronics & Appliances at 18% [image1].

Comparing the two, we can draw inferences:
*   **High Transaction Volume, High Gross Margin:** Fashion, Footwear & Accessories have a high transaction volume (35%) and a significant gross margin contribution (28%) [image1, image3]. This suggests a strong and profitable category.
*   **Low Transaction Volume, High Gross Margin:** Mobile, Tablets & Accessories show the highest gross margin (35%) but a relatively moderate transaction volume (9%) [image1, image3]. This indicates a category with high-value items and good profitability per transaction.
*    **Implication to Supply and Demand Model**.
![Two-sided business model for e-commerce.](image4)
And the two-sided business model depicts an e-commerce platform, is influenced by supply-side factors (like warehousing and logistics) and demand-side factors (customer preferences and purchasing power) [image4].

Key implications for the e-commerce supply and demand model are that high-volume, high-margin categories like Fashion require efficient supply chains, high-margin, low-volume categories like Mobiles, Tablets & Accessories indicate a focus on value and customer experience [2],and the overall shift towards profitability means that e-retailers are focusing on customer retention and experience [2].

In conclusion, the relationship between transaction volumes and gross margin contributions varies across categories, impacting inventory management, pricing strategies, and the balance of supply and demand in the e-commerce model.

Consumer expectations in online retail are directly tied to the critical success factors of an e-commerce platform. Consumers expect a seamless experience across all channels [4]. This all-to-all experience [4] expectation aligns with several key success factors.

Firstly, consumers research online using smartphones, check product reviews on social media, and engage in comparison shopping.

![Consumer behavior in e-commerce involves researching online, checking reviews, comparison shopping, and buying online or in-store.](image2)

This behavior highlights the need for a "wide selection" and "great shopping experience,".
![E-commerce critical success factors include wide selection, great shopping experience, and good pricing.](image1)
Pricing is also a factor, but it's not solely about discounts [image1]. Consumers seek the best prices online and appreciate the convenience and value proposition that e-commerce provides [2].

![Consumer behavior in e-commerce involves researching online, checking reviews, comparison shopping, and buying online or in-store.](image2)
The whole process will be completed in an e-commerce platform.
![The e-commerce model involves an online platform connecting supply and demand, with key success factors.](image1)

The critical success factors of an e-commerce platform, such as widest selection, a great shopping experience and competitive pricing, directly address consumer expectations of convenience, value, and a comprehensive online retail experience.

The number of smartphone users tripled, growing from 120 million in 2014 to 380 million in 2016 [image3].

The digital sector experienced the most substantial growth from 2012 to 2016, with a 29.9% CAGR, largely driven by a tripling in smartphone users.

Smartphone user base is increased. [3]

The growth of digital platforms and social media significantly impacted advertising and eCommerce in India between 2014 and 2018.

One major impact was the shift in advertising spending towards digital platforms.
