Public concerns underwent a significant shift between December 2014 and December 2015.

In December 2015, 29% of Americans cited terrorism, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem facing the country, a substantial increase from just 4% the year before [2, 8].
![Table shows the change of public concerns from December 2014 to December 2015](image4)
Specifically, concerns about terrorism increased by 17 percentage points, and concerns over ISIS/War in Iraq/War in Syria rose by 5 percentage points [2]. Concerns about the economy decreased during this period [1]. The share of the public naming an economic issue decreased from 34% to 23% [1].
![Table data of the most important problem by party identification](image3)
Republicans were more likely to identify terrorism as the key problem [9].

In summary, from December 2014 to December 2015, public concern shifted dramatically from economic issues to terrorism.

Voters are divided on whether Trump will prioritize the needs of his supporters over all Americans [6]. Trump voters overwhelmingly believe he will give equal priority to all Americans (84%) [2], while a significant majority of Clinton voters (75%) think he will prioritize his supporters [2].

![Voter opinions on whether Trump will prioritize supporters or all Americans.](image4)

Overall, 51% of voters believe Trump will give equal priority to all, while 46% think he will prioritize his supporters [6].

In summary, Trump voters largely believe he will prioritize all Americans, whereas Clinton voters predominantly believe he will prioritize his supporters.

Racial identification varies significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics. Among foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics, a large majority (78%) identify as Hispanic or Latino. [9, 5]

This percentage decreases in subsequent generations:
*   **Second Generation:** 66% of second-generation Hispanics identify as Hispanic or Latino, while 15% identify as white. [5]
*    **Third or Higher Generation:** This trend continues, with the share in this group identify as Hispanic or Latino down to 46%, and 25% identify as white. [5]

This can also be seen on how they think the passersby would describe them:
*   **Foreign-born:** 78% say strangers on the street would think they were Hispanic or Latino. [9]
*   **Second-generation:** 66% say strangers on the street would think they were Hispanic or Latino. [9]
*   **Third or Higher Generation:** 46% say strangers on the street would think they were Hispanic or Latino. [9]

![How self-identified Hispanics believe passersby on the street would describe them, by generation.](image5)

The closer they are to their immigrant roots, the more likely Americans with Hispanic ancestry are to identify as Hispanic [7].

In conclusion, racial identification as Hispanic or Latino decreases significantly from foreign-born to third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics, with a corresponding increase in identification as white.

There are significant differences in how racial and ethnic groups in STEM jobs perceive workplace discrimination and fairness.

Black STEM workers are far more likely than their White, Asian, or Hispanic counterparts to report experiencing discrimination. A majority (62%) of Black employees in STEM report having experienced discrimination at work due to their race or ethnicity [7, 2]. This contrasts sharply with White STEM workers, only 13% of whom report such experiences [7]. Asians (44%) and Hispanics (42%) fall in between [7, 6].

![Perceptions of racial discrimination in STEM jobs, with 62% of Black employees reporting experiences of discrimination.](image3)

This disparity extends to perceptions of fairness in hiring and promotions. Only 43% of Black STEM workers believe Black employees are treated fairly during recruitment, and 37% believe this is the case for promotion and advancement [5]. In stark contrast, most White STEM workers believe Black employees are treated fairly in these processes (78% in hiring, 75% in advancement) [5].

There's also wide disagreement on how much discrimination contributes to the underrepresentation of Blacks and Hispanics in STEM. 72% of Black STEM workers believe that discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for this underrepresentation [4, 10]. However, only 27% of White and 28% of Asian STEM workers share this view [4, 10]. Among Hispanic STEM employees, 43% consider discrimination a major factor [4].

In summary, Black STEM workers are significantly more likely to perceive and report racial discrimination and a lack of fairness in the workplace compared to White, Asian, and Hispanic STEM workers.

Voters gave Trump lower grades than they have for any winning candidate in recent decades [10]. Just 30% of voters gave Trump an A or B, which is the lowest for any victorious candidate in 28 years [8]. Post-election evaluations of the way that the winning candidate conducted themselves during the campaign were far more negative than after any election dating back to 1988 [5].

![Percentage of voters giving an A or B grade to winning and losing candidates from 1988 to 2016.](image2)

In comparison, the percentage of voters who gave an A or B grade to previous winning candidates were all significantly higher: Bush (49% in 1988), Clinton (64% in 1992), Clinton (57% in 1996), Bush (52% in 2000), Bush (55% in 2004), Obama (75% in 2008) and Obama (57% in 2012) [image2].

In conclusion, Trump received significantly worse grades from voters in 2016 compared to any other winning candidate since 1988.

Americans give high marks to South Korea and Germany when asked how well different countries have responded to the COVID-19 outbreak [9].

The belief that the U.S. can learn from other countries about ways to slow the spread of the coronavirus is shared by a large percentage of respondents.
![Americans' views on what the U.S. can learn from other countries regarding slowing the spread of coronavirus, broken down by age and education level.](image1)
In total, 60% of the survey respondents believe the US can learn either a great deal (20%) or a fair amount (40%) from other countries [10]. The breakdown across age and education levels is also presented. For example, the percentage of respondents who believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries is highest among postgraduates (31%) and those ages 18-29 (25%) [4].
![Survey results detailing the percentage of respondents who believe the U.S. can learn from the EU, WHO, and the Chinese government.](image2)
The EU has the greatest support with 62% believing the US can learn either a great deal or a fair amount, followed by the WHO at 59% [9].

In conclusion, South Korea and Germany, followed by the EU and WHO, are viewed the most favorably by Americans regarding the potential for the U.S. to learn from their COVID-19 responses.

There is a significant partisan divide in how Republicans and Democrats view Trump's conduct as president.

Democrats are overwhelmingly critical of Trump's conduct, with 85% saying they don't like the way he conducts himself in office [1, 6]. This sentiment is illustrated by data showing that a large majority of Democrats and Democratic leaners disapprove of his conduct. ![Democrats and Republicans differ greatly on Trump.](image5)

Conversely, Republicans are more divided. While a substantial portion expresses criticism or mixed feelings, a notable percentage still approves of his conduct [6, 7]. Specifically, 38% of Republicans and Republican leaners say they like the way Trump conducts himself, 45% have mixed feelings, and 16% do not like it [7].

There are internal divisions within both parties as well. Conservative Republicans are more likely to approve of Trump's conduct compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [2]. Among Democrats, there are modest differences along ideological lines regarding the ethical standards of the Trump administration [3].

In summary, Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct, while Republicans are more divided, with a significant minority expressing approval.

Americans' views on the government's responsibility to care for workers displaced by automation are strongly divided along political lines [1].

*   **Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents** largely believe that the government has an obligation to take care of these workers, even if it means higher taxes [1].
*   **Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** generally believe that individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even in the face of widespread job automation [1].

These partisan divisions are evident in the data:

*   65% of Democrats believe the government should care for displaced workers [1].
*  68% of Republicans believe individuals should care for themselves [1].
![Opinions on Government Responsibility for Displaced Workers](image5)

The public is evenly split on this issue, with 50% believing the government has an obligation and 49% believing individuals are responsible [8].

In conclusion, opinions on government responsibility for workers displaced by automation differ significantly, with Democrats favoring government intervention and Republicans favoring individual responsibility.

Democrats and Republicans hold starkly contrasting views on expanding the U.S.-Mexico border wall.

A significant majority of Republicans (87%) favor substantially expanding the wall, while only a small fraction (11%) oppose it [2].
![image4](image4) shows the detailed breakdown, with 87% of Republicans favoring expansion and only 11% opposing. In sharp contrast, the vast majority of Democrats (92%) oppose the wall's expansion, with a mere 6% in favor [4]. This is also visually confirmed in the graphic representation.

Democratic-leaning independents overwhelmingly oppose the border wall (95% disapprove), aligning closely with Democratic identifiers (92% disapprove) [4].
Independents, as a whole, also oppose the expansion by a wide margin (62% to 36%) [4].

In conclusion, Republicans overwhelmingly support expanding the border wall, while Democrats overwhelmingly oppose it.

There's a significant partisan divide in how Democrats and Republicans view public health officials' response to the COVID-19 pandemic [9].

Democrats have largely maintained a positive view of public health officials' response, with 72% saying they have done an excellent or good job, a figure that has remained relatively stable since March [7]. ![image2](image2) shows the exact percentage of Democrats and Republicans rating the performance of "Public health officials such as those at the CDC," with Democrats at 72% [image2].

In contrast, Republicans' positive ratings of public health officials have sharply declined [1]. Only about half of Republicans (53%) give positive ratings to CDC officials and other public health officials, marking a 31-point decrease since late March [7]. This decline is visually represented in ![image5](image5), which charts the trend of positive ratings from March to August, highlighting the significant drop among Republicans [image5]. Another graph, ![image1](image1), shows the historical trends, with the Republican line (red) displaying a noticeable dip in recent times, while the Democrat line (blue) remains relatively level[image1].

The overall public assessment is less positive, with the decrease largely attributed to the changing views among Republicans [4].

In summary, Democrats generally have a positive view of public health officials' COVID-19 response, while Republicans' views have become significantly less positive over time.

Analyzing the provided data, we can determine the percentage of respondents in the "General Merchandise & Specialty" segment with revenue over $1 billion.

First, let's look at the segment breakdown:
![Respondents by segment and revenue.](image3)

The left pie chart shows that 63% of respondents are in the "General Merchandise & Specialty" segment [3]. The right pie chart indicates that 51% of respondents have revenue over $1 billion. To find the intersection of these two categories, We are looking for the portion of respondents that fall under *both* "General Merchandise & Specialty" and "Over $1 Billion".

Since the charts provide independent breakdowns by segment and revenue, with all segments adding to 100%, and all revenue categories adding to 100% we determine this by multiplying the percentage of "General Merchandise & Specialty" respondents by the percentage of respondents with "Over $1 Billion" revenue:  0.63 * 0.51 = 0.3213.

32.13% of respondents belong to the 'General Merchandise & Specialty' segment and have revenue over $1 billion.

Technology adoption rates differ significantly between adults aged 65+ and the general adult population. Seniors generally lag behind younger Americans in adopting new technologies [10].

A substantial majority of seniors (77%) own cell phones, though this is less than the national average (91%) [3, 5].
![Cell phone, internet, and broadband adoption rates for adults 65+ vs all adults](image3)

However, smartphone adoption is much lower among seniors (18%) compared to all adults (55%) [1, 6]. Smartphone ownership also decreases substantially for seniors in their mid-70s and becomes nearly non-existent among those in their 80s and beyond [2].
![Comparison of smartphone and tablet/e-reader adoption rates between all adults and those aged 65+](image1)

Many seniors remain unattached to online and mobile life, with 41% not using the internet at all, and 23% not using cell phones[10].
![Online and SNS usage among adults 65+](image4)

In summary, technology adoption rates, especially for smartphones and internet usage, are significantly lower among adults aged 65+ compared to the general adult population.

Caltrain's peak hour train car needs vary significantly depending on the implemented improvements. Currently, Caltrain operates with 5 trains per hour, each having 5 cars, totaling 25 cars during peak hours [10].

Different scenarios affect this number:

*   **Metrolink Used Cars:** If Caltrain uses cars, the peak service increases to 6 trains per hour with 5 cars each, requiring 30 train cars.
*    **Electrification:** Electrification allows for 6 trains per hour with 6 cars each, resulting in a need for 36 train cars.
*    **Longer Platforms:** by using Longer platforms, the peak hour train cars will be 48.
*   **Increased Frequency (with High-Speed Rail - HSR):** This scenario sees a significant jump to 8 trains per hour with 8 cars each, requiring 64 train cars.
![Peak hour train cars under different improvement scenarios](image5)

The image depicts the peak service and peak hour train cars increase with the implementation of different scenarios.

In conclusion, the number of peak hour train cars ranges from 25 to 64 in different scenarios.

The ethical standards ratings of Trump administration officials are significantly lower than those of previous administrations. Only 39% of the public rate the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 59% rate them as not good or poor [6, 9]. These ratings are consistent with record lows compared to previous administrations dating back to the 1980s [5].

The data indicates a substantial partisan divide in these perceptions [4]. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican leaners (76%) believe the ethical standards of top administration officials are excellent or good, though only 16% rate them as "excellent" [4]. In stark contrast, 90% of Democrats and Democratic leaners rate the ethical standards as not good or poor, with 67% saying they are "poor" [4].

![Percentage who say ethical standards of top administration officials are excellent/good](image5)

Further illustrating the negative public view, about half (47%) believe Trump will be an unsuccessful president in the long run [3]. This is higher than the percentage who thought Bill Clinton would be unsuccessful (34%) in February 1995 [3].

![How successful of a president do you think [survey respondent] will be?](image1)

In January 2019, a large percentage of the public viewed the Trump administration negatively.
![How much, if at all, do you think Donald Trump cares about the needs and problems of people like you?](image2)

Overall, views of Trump administration officials' ethics are lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations [2].

A minority of Americans are already being impacted by workforce automation in their own jobs and careers [1].  2% of Americans report that they have ever personally lost a job because their employers replaced their positions with a machine or computer program, and another 5% report that they have ever had their pay or hours reduced for the same reason [1].

The age group most impacted is 18-24 year olds.
![image1](image1)

Specifically, 6% of 18-24 year-olds have lost a job entirely due to automation, while 11% have had their pay or hours reduced [9]. In total, 13% of Americans in this age group have been impacted by automation in one or both of these ways [9].

In conclusion, the 18-24 age group is the most impacted by workforce automation, with a total of 13% having experienced job loss or reduced pay/hours.

A substantial share of workers indicate that technologies such as email or social media (60%) have had a positive impact on their own careers [6].

The public's view of the U.S. military campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria has remained relatively stable [3, 5]. A majority (64%) continues to approve of the campaign, while 28% disapprove, figures that have been steady throughout 2015 [10].

From August 2014 to December 2015, approval ratings increased while disapproval ratings decreased.
![image5](image5)
Specifically, approval ratings rose from 54% in August 2014 to 64% in December 2015, and disapproval ratings fell from 31% to 28% in the same period.

In summary, from August 2014 to December 2015, approval ratings for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS increased, and disapproval ratings decreased.

Americans' views of China have become increasingly negative in recent years [1]. A Pew Research Center survey shows a significant decrease in favorable views of China among the American public between 2005 and 2020 [1, 7].

The proportion of favorable views decreased:
![The proportion of favorable views of China decreased from 43% in 2005 to 22% in 2020](image5)

Americans' views on whether the U.S. is the world's leading economic power have fluctuated over time. While a majority still see the U.S. as the leading economic power, that number has decreased since March 2020 [2].

![image1](image1) shows the trend from 2008 to 2020. The percentage of Americans who believe the U.S. is the world's leading economic power peaked at 59% in March 2020, before declining to 52% [2].

There are notable differences between political affiliations. Democrats have become significantly less likely to see the U.S. as the leading global economy since March 2020 [7, 9].

![image5](image5) shows the breakdown by political affiliation (Republican/Lean Republican vs. Democrat/Lean Democrat). In 2020, 64% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believed the U.S. was the leading economic power, compared to 44% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [9].

In summary, Americans' perception of the U.S. as the world's leading economic power has declined since March 2020, with a significant drop among Democrats, leading to a widening gap between political affiliations on this issue.

Americans and Germans have markedly different views on which country is the world's leading economic power [1]. Half of Americans believe the U.S. is the leading economic power, while about a third (32%) think it is China [1]. In contrast, a majority of Germans (53%) identify China as the leading economic power, with only 24% naming the U.S. [1].

This difference is visually represented in a bar chart:
![The chart shows that 50% of Americans believe the U.S. is the world's leading economic power, compared to 24% of Germans.](image3)

Few in either country consider Japan or the countries of the European Union as the leading economic power, although 14% in Germany name the EU, about twice as many as in the U.S. [1].

In summary, Americans are more likely to see the U.S. as the world's leading economic power, whereas Germans are more likely to identify China as the leading economic power.

The number of farms in Hamilton County, U.S., changed significantly between 1880 and 1950. In 1880, there were 1,597 farms. That number increased to a peak of 2,049 farms in 1900 [1].

![Table showing the number of farms in Hamilton County from 1850 to 1950.](image3)

From that point, the number of farms steadily declined, and by 1950, there were nearly 1,453 farm units[1]. Mechanization and increased costs were the primary reasons that the small farms consolidated into bigger ones [1].

In summary, the number of farms increased from 1880 to 1900 and decreased from 1900 to 1950.

Perceptions of ethical standards vary significantly across educational levels and political affiliations. Smartphone ownership among older adults is relatively low, with only 18% of seniors owning one [1, 6]. In contrast, the combined ownership of tablets and e-readers is higher [5].

![Smartphone vs. Tablet or e-reader ownership among all adults and those 65+](image5)

Specifically, 18% of seniors own a tablet, and the same percentage own an e-book reader [10]. Taken together, 27% of older adults own either a tablet, an e-book reader, or both [5, 10]. This indicates that a larger proportion of seniors own tablets or e-readers than smartphones [5]. Additionally, tablet ownership levels among seniors are around half the national average, while e-book reader ownership is slightly lower than the national average [4].

In conclusion, among seniors, the combined ownership of tablets and e-readers is more common than smartphone ownership.

Americans express several reservations about companies using automated personal finance scores. The top concern is privacy violation. [9, 10]

![image5](image5) shows that 68% find it unacceptable, with 26% of those citing privacy violations.

Another key concern is the accuracy of these scores. Some people believe that someone's online data does not accurately represent them as a person [8, 10]. Concerns about the fairness and potential for discrimination are also present [8].

![image2](image2) shows that a combined 66% of respondents found automated personal finance scores "not fair at all" or "not very fair".

These concerns reflect broader anxieties about automated decision-making, including data privacy, the potential for bias, and a lack of nuance in capturing complex individual situations [1, 2, 4, 6].

In summary, the main concerns of U.S. adults regarding automated personal finance scores are privacy violations, inaccurate representation, and potential unfairness or discrimination.

The survey data indicates a significant increase in concern about obesity among Arab youth between 2013 and 2014 [3, 9]. Internet and broadband usage among seniors decreases significantly around the age of 75 [1, 5].

A breakdown of usage by age group reveals the following:
*   **65-69 years old:** 74% go online, and 65% have broadband at home [10].
*   **70-74 years old:** 68% go online, and 55% have broadband.
*    **75-79 years old:** 47% go online, and 34% have broadband.
*   **80+ years old:** Only 37% go online, and a mere 21% have broadband [8].

![Internet and broadband use by age group](image4)

The data indicates a considerable decline in both internet and broadband adoption as seniors age, with a marked drop after 75 [7].

The changes of internet and broadband usage among seniors reduces with the increase of age.

Asians are overrepresented in STEM occupations compared to their representation in all employment categories [1]. Specifically, Asians constitute 13% of STEM jobs, while they make up only 6% of the total workforce [7, 8]. This overrepresentation is particularly noticeable among college-educated workers, where 17% of STEM workers are Asian, compared to 10% of all college-educated workers [4, 5].

The breakdown of racial and ethnic groups in STEM versus all employment is visually represented as follows:

![Racial and ethnic distribution in STEM jobs compared to all jobs.](image1)

Asians have a higher share in STEM jobs than all jobs [7, 8], especially within computer and life sciences occupations [7]. The share of Asians in STEM jobs also varies considerably by occupational group [6].

In summary, the racial/ethnic group most represented in STEM jobs compared to their representation in all employment categories is Asians.

The survey employed a significant number of fieldwork personnel across the different waves. Specifically, for Wave I, there were 52 fieldwork personnel and for Wave II and 50 fieldwork personnel. ![Wave I had 52 fieldwork personnel, Wave II had 50, and Wave III had 72.](image1)

Political affiliations have significantly different views on the necessity of government regulation to protect the public interest. Democrats generally believe that government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, while Republicans generally believe that government regulation does more harm than good [4].

Specifically, 65% of Democrats believe that government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, while only 29% believe it does more harm than good. In contrast, 61% of Republicans think that government regulation of business does more harm than good, and only 33% believe it is necessary to protect the public interest ![The chart shows the percentage of different political affiliations who say government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest or that government regulation of business does more harm than good.](image4). Independents are more divided, with 48% believing government regulation is necessary and 43% believing it does more harm than good [4]. Those who lean Democratic are similar to Democrats, with 69% believing government regulation is necessary, those who lean Republican is similar to Republican, with 33% believing government regulation is necessary [4].

In conclusion, political affiliations differ significantly in their views on the necessity of government regulation, with Democrats generally favoring it and Republicans generally opposing it.

Black individuals follow the 2018 midterms most closely.

Latino Republicans and Democrats have significantly different views on the statement "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos' votes."

A substantial share of Latino Republicans (40%) believe this statement describes their views very well [1].
![A survey shows that 40% of Latino Republicans believe that Republicans work hard to earn Latinos' votes.](image2)
In contrast, only 13% of Latino Democrats say the statement describes their views well [7]. A majority of Latino Democrats, both liberals (70%) and conservatives/moderates (61%), believe the statement does *not* describe their views well [1].
About one-third of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (35%) say “the Republican Party works hard to earn Latinos’ votes” describes their views at least somewhat well[4].

In summary, Latino Republicans are much more likely than Latino Democrats to believe that the Republican Party works hard to earn Latino votes.

Voters experienced a mix of emotions regarding Donald Trump's election. While 51% reported feeling hopeful, a slightly larger percentage, 53%, felt uneasy [10, 8]. Other prevalent emotions included sadness (41%) and fear (41%), while 36% felt proud and 31% felt angry [8].

The reactions were strongly divided along partisan lines. Among Trump voters, 96% felt hopeful, and 74% felt proud [4].
![image4](image4)
In stark contrast, Clinton voters predominantly experienced negative emotions: 90% felt uneasy, 77% sad, and 76% scared [4, 6].
![image5](image5)

In summary, the primary emotions voters felt about Trump's election were hopefulness and unease, with significant partisan differences in the emotional responses.

The approval ratings for public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have significantly declined from March to August, with a notable difference between political groups [8, 9].

The decline in positive assessments of public health officials has primarily occurred among Republicans [4]. In March, 84% of Republicans rated public health officials positively, but this dropped to 53% by August, a 31-point decrease [1, 2]. Democrats' views remained relatively stable, with 74% giving positive ratings in March and 72% in August [1, 2].
![image3](image3)
The widening partisan gap is further illustrated by the overall approval ratings [6].
![image4](image4)

In conclusion, approval ratings for public health officials decreased significantly among Republicans from March to August, while remaining largely unchanged among Democrats.

Hispanics have consistently been more optimistic about their financial future than the general public [10]. From 2004 to 2015, the percentage of Hispanics expecting their finances to improve increased significantly, while the general public's expectations showed a smaller rise [2].

![Financial expectations of Hispanics and the general public from 2004-2015.](image2)

In 2008, 67% of Hispanics expected their family finances to improve, compared to 56% of the general public [1]. By 2015, this gap had widened, with 81% of Hispanics anticipating improvement, compared to 61% of the general public [1]. This 20-percentage-point difference is the largest since the Pew Research Center's National Survey of Latinos began tracking this data in 2004 [10].

![Change in expectations of financial improvement from 2008-2015](image1)

In summary, from 2004 to 2015, Hispanics consistently had higher financial expectations than the general public, and the gap between the two groups widened over this period.

Older adults who use the internet and those who do not have differing views regarding the disadvantages of lacking internet access. A majority, 79%, of older adult internet users agree that people without internet access are at a disadvantage, with 47% strongly agreeing [6]. ![79% of older adults internet users agree that people without internet access are at a real disadvantage](image3)

In contrast, older adults who do not use the internet are more divided on this issue. While 48% agree that lacking internet access is a disadvantage, a significant portion (35%) disagree with this assessment [7, 10]. ![48% of older adults non-internet users agree that people without internet access are at a real disadvantage](image3)

In summary, internet users largely believe that lacking internet access is a disadvantage, while non-users are more split in their opinions.

Americans have varied perceptions of China's influence in world affairs after the coronavirus pandemic, with a significant portion believing its influence will decrease.

Half of Americans believe that China will emerge from the crisis with less influence in world affairs [9]. The survey indicates that 50% of Americans say China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [3]. This coincides with a rise in negative attitudes toward China [3].
![Chart showing 50% of Americans believe China will have less influence post-pandemic](image4)

There's a partisan divide on this issue, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to predict a decline in China's international clout [1].
![Disagreement trend from 2013 to 2020](image2)
Age also plays a role, with older Americans more likely to anticipate a decrease in China's global influence [1].

The survey was conducted by the Pew Research Center from April 29 to May 5, 2020, among 10,957 U.S. adults [10].

In conclusion, half of Americans surveyed believe China will have less influence in world affairs after the coronavirus pandemic.

Trump and Clinton voters held starkly contrasting views on how Trump's election would impact race relations.

  Half of Trump voters (50%) expected race relations to improve, with 38% believing his election would have no impact, and only 9% anticipating a negative effect [1]. ![Partisan relations expectations for Trump voters and Clinton voters in 2016, and Obama voters and McCain voters in 2008.](image1)

A majority of U.S. adults (74%) believe that content posted on social media does not accurately represent society's views on important issues [3, 7]. Only a small portion, 25%, believe social media provides an accurate picture, with certain demographics like Black and Hispanic individuals, and younger adults, being more likely to hold this view [3].

The survey data indicates a widespread sentiment that social media is not reflective of broader societal opinions [7, 8]. This is further confirmed by the pie chart, which visually represents the proportion of people holding this view:

![A pie chart showing that 74% of U.S. adults do not think social media accurately represents society's views.](image2)

European venture capital (VC) outperforms the US in terms of median multiple of cash invested. While the median exit valuation is lower in Europe ($173 million) compared to the US ($236 million) [3], the median multiple of cash invested is significantly higher in Europe.

![image3](image3)

Specifically, the median multiple of cash invested in Europe is 7.2, compared to 4.5 in the USA [3]. This higher multiple in Europe is attributed to factors such as lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency, which more than compensate for the smaller average exit values [4, 9]. Additionally, a greater percentage of European exits achieve a multiple of cash invested of 5x or greater (57.26% in Europe vs. 47.27% in the US) [3].

In conclusion, the median multiple of cash invested is higher in Europe (7.2) than in the USA (4.5).

Republicans' views on government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat have become increasingly negative over time.

At the beginning of 2015, a majority of Republicans (63%) said the government was doing very or fairly well in reducing the terrorist threat [4]. However, this number has drastically decreased, with only 27% of Republicans now holding that view [4]. This represents a 36-point drop in positive assessment within the year [4]. The shift has been more pronounced among Republicans [3].
![Graph showing how well the government is doing reducing the threat of terrorism, by political party.](image1)
The data reveals that the positive ratings of Republicans have plummeted, especially in the Obama administration.

Furthermore, a growing number of Republicans believe that the government's anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country [3]. Currently, 71% of Republicans express this concern, a significant increase from 57% in January and 38% in July 2013 [3].
![The graph shows changing opinions on whether anti-terrorism policies go far enough to protect the country or restrict civil liberties.](image2)
In addition, conservative Republicans’ view, in particular, have turned sharply critical with only 18% said the government was doing very well or fairly well [2].

In summary, Republicans' views on government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat have changed significantly over time, characterized by a sharp decrease in positive assessments and a growing belief that current policies are insufficient.

The share of Americans feeling "cold" toward China (0-49 on a feeling thermometer) rose from 46% in 2018 to 67% in 2021 [4, 6].

![image4](image4)

In 2018, "very cold" feelings were at 23%, and increased to 47% by 2021. The increase is present among both Republicans and Democrats [1, 5].
![image5](image5)

In summary, negative views of China have increased substantially among Americans of all political affiliations from 2018 to 2021, with Republicans expressing significantly more negative feelings than Democrats.

The survey data reveals varying opinions on the acceptability of automated systems within the criminal justice system. A significant portion of respondents expressed reservations. Concerns include a lack of individual focus and the potential for overlooking people's capacity for change [1].

However, some respondents believe that automated risk scores could be a valuable tool. Some think using data, alongside human judgment, is better than relying solely on human decisions, which can be biased [10]. Another respondent mentioned a preference for objective criteria, suggesting it could lead to fairer outcomes, potentially benefiting those currently incarcerated due to subjective biases [10].

![Acceptability of Automated Criminal Risk Scores](image5)

The survey specifically addressed the acceptability of automated criminal risk scores. It found that 42% of U.S. adults find their use acceptable within the criminal justice system, citing reasons such as effectiveness and increased fairness [8].

In conclusion, 42% of US adults believe it is acceptable for the criminal justice system to use automated criminal risk scores.

The survey conducted from April 25 to May 1, 2018, asked adults to rate the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials [9]. The results showed a clear division in opinions [7].

The public's assessment highlights a significant concern regarding the ethical standards of the Trump administration, 36% adults rated Trump's government ethical standards as poor.

Women in STEM, particularly those in computer-related positions, often encounter significant gender disparities in the workplace [2, 4]. A Pew Research Center survey highlights these disparities, especially for women in majority-male workplaces and those with advanced degrees [3, 10].

Key findings from the survey and related analysis reveal:

*   **Gender Discrimination:** A substantial 74% of women in computer occupations report experiencing gender discrimination at work, a stark contrast to the 16% of men in the same field [8].
*    **Workplace Dynamics**: Women, overall more likely to face the unfair treatment, are to report pay inequities. [6].
*   **Subtle Differences**: Qualitative interviews reveal that women in STEM often feel treated differently in subtle ways [9].
* **Experiences of Discrimination**:
    ![Experiences of gender discrimination at work among women in STEM jobs.](image1)
*   **Gender-Related Discrimination**: The gap in experiencing gender-related discrimination is notably wide between men and women in computer jobs.

    ![Gender discrimination in computer jobs.](image5)

The data and analysis indicate that women in computer jobs within STEM fields face the most significant gender gap and related challenges, including a high prevalence of gender discrimination.

In conclusion, computer jobs have the most gender gap in employment consistent of women in STEM jobs.

Social media companies possess vast quantities of data about their users. The comfort level with this behavior is context-dependent. [3]

Perceptions of online behavior differ between men and women in a few key areas:

*   **Bullying and Kindness**: Men are more likely than women to report seeing mean or bullying behavior on social media platforms (29% vs. 19%). [8]
*    **Deception vs. Correction**: Men are about twice as likely as women to say they more often see people trying to be deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%). [5]
     ![{conclusion}](image2)
*   However, the data suggests that the largest proportion of both genders report seeing a balanced mix. [8]

The most common types of content encountered on social media, regardless of gender, include:

*   **Overly Dramatic or Exaggerated Posts:** 58% of users say they frequently see this type of content. [10]
*    **Accusations/Arguments Without Facts:** 59% of users see this frequently. [10]
     ![{conclusion}](image5)
*   It's worth noting that along with these negative types of content, users report more positive experiences. [4]
*   Users are asked about the emotions that social media platforms inspire and also about how often they encounter certain types of behaviors and content. [7]
     ![{conclusion}](image3)

In summary, men are more likely to report seeing negative behaviors like bullying and deception, while both genders most commonly encounter overly dramatic content and arguments without facts on social media.

The perception that news organizations wielded "too much" influence on presidential elections has fluctuated over time, reaching a high point in 2016.

In 2016, a majority of voters (57%) believed that news organizations had too much influence on the outcome of the presidential election [7, 9]. This sentiment was shared by both Trump voters (62%) and Clinton voters (50%) [3, 5, 10]. This was the highest it has been since 2000 [9].
![image1](image1)

The data indicates a significant increase in this perception in 2016 compared to previous elections. For instance, while 57% of all voters in 2016 felt the press had too much influence, only 48% felt that way in 2012 [9, image1]. After George W. Bush’s reelection in 2004, just 45% of Bush voters said news organizations had had too much influence [2]. Similarly, the share of Clinton voters who believed the press had too much influence in 2016 (50%) was nearly double the share of Obama voters who felt the same in 2012 (29%) or 2008 (18%) [10].

In conclusion, the perception of news organizations having "too much" influence on presidential elections has generally increased over time, peaking in the 2016 election.

The perception of Trump's economic policies became significantly more polarized between October 2017 and January 2019.

In January 2019, 79% of Republicans and Republican leaners believed that Trump's economic policies had made economic conditions better, compared to 63% in October 2017 [8]. ![Perception of Trump's economic policies from Oct 2017 to Jan 2019](image4)
Conversely, the percentage of Democrats and Democratic leaners who said his policies had made conditions worse increased from 28% in October 2017 to 46% in January 2019 [8].

Overall, public opinion shifted from 29% saying Trump's policies made things better, 49% saying they had no effect, and 18% saying they made things worse in 2017, to 40%, 29%, and 28% respectively in 2019 [4].

In conclusion, From October 2017 to January 2019, Republicans became more positive and Democrats more negative about Trump's economic policies.

Partisan divides are evident in how different political affiliations perceive the impact of U.S. involvement in solving global problems [3].

Majorities of both Republicans (62%) and Democrats (56%) believe that global issues would worsen without U.S. intervention [8]. This sentiment is visualized in the following chart:

![A majority of Republicans (62%) and Democrats (56%) believe world problems would be worse without U.S. involvement.](image5)

However, there's a nuanced difference within the Democratic Party. While a majority of conservative and moderate Democrats believe in the necessity of U.S. involvement, liberal Democrats are almost evenly split. Among liberal Democrats, 45% believe U.S. efforts often exacerbate problems, while 50% think the world would be worse off without U.S. involvement [2].

Independents are more divided, with 50% believing problems would be worse without U.S. involvement, and 43% stating U.S. efforts usually make things worse [![A majority of Republicans (62%) and Democrats (56%) believe world problems would be worse without U.S. involvement.](image5)]. Overall, 55% of all respondents believe the world would be worse off without U.S. involvement, while 38% think U.S. actions worsen the situation [10].

In conclusion, while majorities of Republicans and Democrats believe in the necessity of U.S. involvement in global issues, liberal Democrats and independents show significant reservations about the effectiveness of U.S. efforts.

The overall energy efficiency from source to wheel, often referred to as "well-to-wheel" efficiency, varies significantly between electric vehicles (EVs) and internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs).

For electric vehicles, the well-to-wheel efficiency can be broken down into two main stages:

1.  **Well-to-Tank (Production and Transport)**: This stage involves electricity generation and transmission.
2.  **Tank-to-Wheels**: This encompasses the efficiency of the electric motor and drivetrain in converting electrical energy into motion.

![Well-to-wheel efficiency of an electric vehicle is 23%, while for an internal combustion engine vehicle it is 13%.](image4)

The image shows a "Well-to-Tank" efficiency for EVs of approximately 31% (33% generation efficiency x 94% transmission efficiency) and a "Tank-to-Wheels" efficiency of 76%. Multiplying these gives an overall well-to-wheel efficiency of around 23% (31% x 76% = 23%).

For ICEVs, a similar breakdown applies, but with lower efficiencies in both stages. The image shows about 13%.
[7] states that ICE technologies are the most popular and fully commercialized.

The well-to-wheel efficiency of an electric car is 23%, compared to 13% of an internal combustion car.

A significant disparity exists in the experiences of gender-related discrimination between men and women in computer jobs. Additionally, fewer women in computer jobs believe they are treated fairly in opportunities for promotion and advancement (43%) compared to men (77%) [7, 10].

The image data clearly demonstrates a significant difference (+58%) between the percentage of women and men who have ever experienced gender-related discrimination at work [image2].

In conclusion, the difference in gender-related discrimination experiences between men and women in computer jobs is stark, with women reporting significantly higher rates of discrimination than men.

In summary, the importance of abortion as a voting issue rose 15 percentage points among Latino registered voters from March to August 2022.

Latino Democrats and Republicans have significantly different views on which party works hard to earn Latino votes.

Many Latino Republicans and leaners believe the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes [5].
![image1](image1)
In contrast, a smaller percentage of Latino Democrats and leaners believe the Republican Party works hard to earn Latino votes [5]. Specifically, 56% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners say the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes, while only 35% of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners say the same about the Republican Party [5].

Furthermore, 40% of Latino Republicans believe that the statement "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos' votes" describes their views very or extremely well, compared to only 13% of Latino Democrats [10]. Among independents and those who do not identify as partisans, the same percentage (13%) of Democratic leaners agree, while Republican-leaning independents have distinct views [10]. A substantial share of Latino Republican and Republican-leaning conservatives (40%) say "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos’ votes" describes their views at least very well [7].

Majorities of liberal (70%) and conservative/moderate (61%) Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners say that the statement "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos’ votes" does *not* describe their views well [7].

In summary, Latino Republicans are more likely to believe that the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes, whereas Latino Democrats are less likely to believe the same of the Republican Party.

Women's representation in STEM jobs varies significantly by education level and specific field. Women make up half (50%) of all U.S. workers in STEM occupations [5]. However, their presence varies widely across occupational clusters and educational levels [5].

Specifically, the share of women in different STEM occupations changes with educational attainment:

*   **Overall STEM Occupations**: Women constitute 50% of the total STEM workforce [5].
*    **Advanced Degrees**: Women's representation is lower among those with advanced degrees in STEM. For instance, among STEM workers with a professional or doctoral degree, about 41% are women, compared to 59% of STEM workers with less education [9].

![Women's representation in STEM jobs relative to all employed, broken down by education level.](image3)

*   **Occupational Subgroups**:
  *   Engineering has the lowest share of women at 14% [6].
  *    Computer occupations have women comprising 25% of the workforce [6].
  *    Women are underrepresented among physical scientists (39%), but their representation is closer to their overall workforce share in life sciences (47%) and math (46%)[6].
*    **Educational Background**: Among college-educated workers, 81% of those who majored in health professions are women, while only 16% of engineering majors are women [7].
* **Median annual earnings of full-time, year round workers ages 25 and older**:
![Median annual earnings by education](image1)

In summary, women's representation in STEM is 50% overall but drops to 41% among those with professional or doctoral degrees, and varies significantly across different STEM fields.

Female representation varies significantly across different STEM job clusters [2, 4]. Women are a majority in health-related occupations, constituting 75% of healthcare practitioners and technicians [3, 9].
![The share of women in different STEM job clusters, with health-related jobs having the highest representation at 75% and engineering jobs the lowest at 14%.](image3)
However, they are underrepresented in other STEM fields, particularly in computer jobs and engineering [4]. Engineering occupations have the lowest share of women, at just 14% [8, 9]. In computer occupations, women make up 25% of the workforce [8]. The share of women in other STEM occupational clusters, such as physical scientists (39%), life scientists (47%), and math workers (46%), varies but more closely aligns with women's overall workforce representation (47%) [8].

In conclusion, female representation in STEM varies widely by occupation, with high representation in health-related jobs and low representation in engineering and computer jobs.

Hamilton County's population experienced significant changes between 1870 and 2000. The population saw a massive increase in the late 19th century. [1]

![image3](image3)

The population increased from 130 in 1870 to 8,267 in 1880, and peaked at 14,096 in 1890 [1]. After this peak, the county's population slowly declined. While the overall county population decreased after 1890, some individual towns within the county, such as Aurora, saw population growth, with Aurora reaching 4,225 citizens by 2000, steadily increasing since 1940 [3, 4].

![image2](image2)

From 1870 to 2000, the population of Hamilton County peaked in 1890 and then declined, although some towns within the county experienced individual growth.

There is a significant difference in the level of support for automatic voter registration between Democrats and Republicans. Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals are far more supportive of automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [9]. A sizable majority (82%) of Democrats favor automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [2]. This support has remained relatively stable and even ticked up slightly since 2018 [6].

In contrast, the share of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents who support automatic voter registration is much lower and has declined since 2018 [3].
![Republican support for automatic voter registration has declined since 2018.](image3)
Currently, only 38% of Republicans support this measure, down from 49% in 2018 [6].
![Disparity between Republicans and Democrats on automatic voter registration.](image4)
The graphic shows that 82% of Democrats and 38% of Republicans support to automatically register all eligible citizens to vote.

In conclusion, Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to support automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, with a difference of 44 percentage points.

Experiences of discrimination and perceptions of fairness in STEM jobs differ significantly between racial and ethnic groups, especially when comparing black and white workers [1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8].

Black STEM workers report experiencing discrimination at work due to their race at a much higher rate (62%) than white STEM workers (13%) [4]. Asians (44%) and Hispanics (42%) also report higher rates of discrimination than whites [4].
![Experiences of discrimination in STEM jobs by race/ethnicity](image4)
Blacks in STEM are more likely than whites to say their race has made it harder to succeed [2]. Specifically, 40% of black STEM workers report this, compared to only 5% of white STEM workers [2]. Furthermore, black STEM employees are less convinced than their white counterparts that black employees are treated fairly in hiring and promotions [3]. Only 43% of black STEM workers believe blacks are treated fairly during recruitment, and 37% believe this in promotion and advancement, compared to 78% and 75% of white STEM workers, respectively [3].

Black workers are less likely to view treatment in their workplace as fair when it comes to advancement [8, 9].
Blacks working in STEM jobs report experiences of workplace discrimination due to race more than blacks in non-STEM jobs(62% vs. 50%) [10].

In conclusion, black STEM workers report significantly higher rates of racial discrimination and lower perceptions of fairness in hiring and promotion compared to white STEM workers.

Pre-training word embeddings in source and/or target languages generally improves BLEU scores in machine translation tasks [6]. The degree of improvement varies depending on factors such as the baseline system's performance, the similarity between the languages, and the frequency of words in the training corpus [1, 4, 8, 9].

For higher-resource languages, pre-training provides consistent gains of about 3 BLEU points [1].
![BLEU scores with aligned and unaligned embeddings](image1)
In cases of extremely low-resource languages like ${\mathrm{GL}}\to{\mathrm{EN}}$, pre-training can lead to very large gains, up to 11 BLEU points, and helps capture rarer vocabulary and generate more grammatically well-formed sentences [1, 2].
![BLEU score improvements with varying training set sizes](image2)
Interestingly, the gain is most significant when there's a moderately effective baseline system (with a BLEU score of 3-4) before pre-training [4].
![BLEU score improvements based on language family](image3)
Pre-training is particularly helpful for low-frequency words, it improves the accuracy of translation for the entire vocabulary [8].
![BLEU scores with different pre-training settings](image4)
The improvements are more significant when using pre-trained source language embeddings, which suggests better encoding of the source sentence [6]. In multilingual translation systems, aligning word embeddings further enhances BLEU scores, particularly for language pairs with high similarity such as GL/PT [10].
![Dataset sizes for different language pairs](image5)

In summary, pre-training generally improves BLEU scores, with the magnitude of improvement depending on language similarity, baseline system effectiveness, and word frequency.

The inclusion of reference translations significantly improves the performance of the COMET-RANK metric, as evidenced by the comparison between COMET-RANK (ref. only) and COMET-RANK. [9] states that "we trained two versions of our DA RR Ranker model: one that uses only the reference, and another that uses both reference and source."

The impact varies across different language pairs. For example:

*   **en-de**: The increase in Δτ is 0.035.
*   **en-fi**: The increase in Δτ is 0.041.
*    **cs-en**: The increase in Δτ is more substantial at 0.107.
*   **de-en:** The increase in delta tau is 0.155.
*   **fi-en:** The increase in delta tau is 0.119.

Human evaluation was used to assess Chameleon's performance because using only static, public benchmarks could be limited [7]. In relative evaluations, Chameleon was directly compared with baseline models by presenting responses to the same prompt in random order and asking human annotators which response they preferred [2].

The levels of agreement among annotators when comparing Chameleon with other models in relative evaluations are detailed as follows [9]:
*   **All three annotators agree**: Ranging from approximately 28% to 35% across different model comparisons.
*   **Two of three annotators agree**: Occurring in about 55% to 60% of the comparisons.
*   **No agreement**: Found in slightly over 10% of the cases for each model pair.

![Annotator Agreement Levels in Relative Evaluations](image2)

This distribution of agreement levels suggests that in many instances, Chameleon performs comparably to other baseline models, making the relative evaluation a challenging task [9]. The fact that there is unanimous agreement among all three annotators in about 28% to 35% of cases indicates a substantial level of inter-annotator reliability, especially in cases where Chameleon's performance is distinctly different from that of the compared models [9]. The higher percentage of cases where two out of three annotators agree (55% to 60%) further supports the notion of considerable, though not perfect, reliability [9]. The cases with no agreement, accounting for just over 10%, suggest some variability in perception or criteria among annotators, which is expected in human evaluations, but is still a relatively small proportion [9].

Annotator agreement varied from about 28% to 35% for unanimous agreement, 55% to 60% for two annotators agreeing, and around 10% for no agreement, suggesting good inter-annotator reliability, although relative evaluation is challenging.

The number of demonstration samples has a positive, but eventually limited, effect on the Micro-F1 performance.

Here's a breakdown of the observations:

*   **General Trend**: Increasing the number of demonstration samples initially improves the Micro-F1 score. [10]
*   **Point of Diminishing Returns**: The improvement in performance is significant when increasing demonstrations from 1 to 5, but the gains are limited with further increases (e.g., ≥10). [10]
*    **With vs. Without Logical Constraints**:
    *   Adding logical constraints to the LLM instructions consistently improves performance, especially with more demonstrations.
    *   The performance of incorporating logical constraints with fewer demonstrations can surpass that of prompts with only a larger number of demonstrations. For example, using 5 demonstrations on MAVEN-ERE with logical constraints (25.7%) outperforms using 10 demonstrations without logical constraints (24.5%).

*   **Visual Data Support**:
    *  The left side of image4, shows the Micro-F1 scores for the MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets, both with and without logical constraints (lc), across different numbers of demonstration samples (1, 5, 10, and 20).
    ![Micro-F1 scores for MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets with and without logical constraints](image4)

In summary, increasing demonstration samples improves Micro-F1 performance up to a point, after which the gains diminish, and logical constraints provide a performance boost, particularly valuable when demonstrations are limited.

The main error types identified in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are Reasoning Error, RAG, Scoring Error, and StepBack [2, 6, 8].

Here's a breakdown of the error analysis:

*   **Reasoning Error and RAG are the Dominating Error Sources**: A significant portion of errors, over 90%, occur during the reasoning step [6, 9].
*   **Reasoning Error**: This is a major source of errors, indicating that even when the model correctly identifies underlying principles or retrieves relevant information, it struggles with the subsequent reasoning steps to arrive at the correct answer [4, 9].
*    **RAG Failures**: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) errors, where the system fails to retrieve the relevant information, are also a significant contributor [6]. This accounts for 45% of errors [6].
*    **Scoring Error:** is one of the minor error, this means the judge model made a mistake [2].
* **StepBack Error:** Step-back errors are relatively rare,meaning the step-back question is not helping in solving the questions [2].
*   **Error Distribution**:
    ![Error distribution on TimeQA](image3)

In summary, the main error types on TimeQA are Reasoning and RAG errors, with Reasoning errors being the most prevalent and RAG errors contributing significantly.

The paper proposes an anchor re-weighting method to improve ICL performance. [1, 3, 5, 6]

The anchor re-weighting method improves In-Context Learning (ICL) accuracy by employing a learnable vector to adjust the significance of different label words in demonstrations. [6] The proposed anchor re-weighting significantly enhances ICL performance. [8]
Anchor Re-weighting (1-shot per class) method is compared with two baselines: (1) Vanilla ICL with the same demonstration (1-shot per class) (2) Vanilla ICL, where the auxiliary training set is included as demonstrations (5-shot per class) for a fair comparison. [2]

![Table showing performance comparison of Anchor Re-weighting method and Vanilla In-Context Learning methods.](image3)

As the image shows, the anchor re-weighting method achieves an average accuracy of 68.64, while vanilla ICL achieves 51.90 (1-shot per class) and 46.87 (5-shot per class). [2, ![(image3)]]

The results indicate an average accuracy boost of 16.7% compared to the standard ICL baseline (1-shot per class). [6]

The Anchor Re-weighting method improves the performance of vanilla ICL by 16.7% on average.

The paper categorizes correction methodologies based on *when* the correction occurs: training-time, generation-time, and post-hoc [3].

*   **Training-time Correction:** This strategy rectifies model behavior during the training phase [4]. It ideally corrects flawed models before deployment [7]. Human feedback is typically used, as with RLHF [7].
*    **Generation-time Correction:** This approach uses automated feedback to correct errors *during* generation [6]. It's necessary when dealing with large, inaccessible LLMs [2]. Two main strategies exist: Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding [2].
     ![The two typical strategies of generation-time correction are Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding.](image3)

*   **Post-hoc Correction:** This method refines the model output *after* generation, without updating model parameters [8]. It allows for diverse natural language feedback, making the process more transparent [1].
    ![Post-hoc correction includes Self-Correction, Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate.](image2)

    The post-hoc correction could involve self-refine from language model, external feedback, and model debate.
![Post-hoc correction methods, feedback sources, model refinement strategies, learning types, iteration details, and applications.](image1)

Based on the given information, the post-hoc correction has the most representative papers.

The RAR (Retrieving And Ranking) pipeline integrates a multimodal retriever with Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) to enhance performance in few-shot and zero-shot perception tasks [2, 6]. Here's a breakdown of the main components and their functions:

1.  **Multimodal Retriever:**
    *   **Function:** This component is responsible for querying a large multimodal external memory to find information relevant to the input [8]. It creates and stores multimodal embeddings for visual images and text descriptions [1].
    *   **Process:** It encodes and stores a large volume of image/text embeddings. It optimizes retrieval speed through index construction techniques, specifically using the HNSW (Hierarchical Navigable Small World) algorithm for dimensionality reduction [7, 8].
    *    The retriever is depicted as processing input images through an image encoder, creating embeddings, and storing them in a database with a feature index and labels, with capability of Image-Image and Image-Text K-NN `![Multimodal Retriever and Retrieving & Ranking Process](image3)`.

2.  **Memory Construction:**
    *   **Function:** A multimodal memory is constructed using the multimodal retriever [6]. This memory stores embeddings and associated category information.
    *   **Process:** The retriever creates and stores explicit memory for different categories that extend beyond the immediate context window [9].

3. **Retrieval Process**
   *   The retrieval process utilizes a large multi-modal external memory or database.  The input is the given image at the inference stage, that the approach retrieves the top-  $k$ class names most similar to the image [1].
      * To speed up the the retrieval, the usage of HNSW(Hierarchical Navigable Small World) algorithm reduces the vector dimension from    $d$   into  $\frac{d}{9}$ [7].
4.  **Ranking by MLLMs:**
    *   **Function:** After retrieval, MLLMs rank the retrieved candidate results to make the final prediction [1, 4].
    *   **Process:** Retrieved category labels and image embeddings are integrated and sent to the MLLMs. The MLLMs use their internal knowledge and the retrieved information to rank the candidates [4].
    *   **Prompting:** Prompts are used to merge the input image with the retrieved category information, guiding the MLLMs to rank the candidates based on similarity [5]. A ranking prompt example illustrates how an image of a Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedan is processed, with the MLLM ranking potential matches and identifying the correct category: `![Ranking Prompt Example](image4)`.

5. **Pre-processing for Object Detection Datasets:**
   *   For object detection, images are processed distinctly, enhancing MLLM's understanding of the objects [3]. The method includes *cropping* bounding box regions to a fixed size and *blurring* non-target areas to focus on relevant objects [3].

    *   An illustration shows the object detection process, extracting image embeddings by cropping and blurring: `![Object Detection with Cropping and Blurring](image5)`.
6. The pipeline includes retrieving the top-k similar results and ranking them using MLLM. [9].

The main components of the RAR pipeline for multimodal retrieval are the multimodal retriever, which creates and stores multimodal embeddings, and the MLLMs, which rank the retrieved results to make final predictions.

The authors divided the multi-step reasoning process of causal inference into preparation steps and formal solution steps [1]. The preparation steps involve identifying the causal graph structure, determining the query type, formulating the query, and extracting relevant data [1]. The solution steps are deducing the estimand and evaluating the estimand to answer the question [1].
To be specific:
1.  **Preparation Phase**: This includes identifying the causal graph, determining the query type, formulating the query symbolically, and extracting relevant data from the prompt [1].
    *   Causal graph extraction [4].
    *   Correct query type interpretation[4].
     *   Symbolic formalization of the query [4].
    *    Semantic parsing to compile the available data[4].
2.  **Solution Phase**: This involves deducing the estimand using causal inference techniques and then evaluating the estimand [1].
 *  Estimand derivation [4].
  *   Arithmetic calculation to solve the estimand [4].

![image5](image5) shows these steps.

In summary, causal inference is divided into six key steps.

The study examines two methods for controlling dialogue agent attributes: conditional training and weighted decoding [7]. Weighted decoding involves adjusting weights during the decoding process to influence specific attributes of the generated text [3, 8].

In the provided example, we can analyze how different weights impact the generated response:

![Weighted Decoding Response table for the input 'Yes, I'm studying law at the moment'](image5)

*   **Wt (Weight):** This column shows the different weight values applied during decoding.
*   **NIDF:** Measures the specificity of the response. Higher values indicate rarer, more specific words.
*   **Weighted Decoding Response:** The text generated by the model with the corresponding weight.

Here's how the weight affects the response:

*   **Wt -5.0 (NIDF 0.6%):** "Oh................." - A very generic and non-committal response, likely due to the negative weight suppressing typical responses.
*   **Wt 0.0 (NIDF 17.1%):** "That sounds like a lot of fun!"- This is the baseline response, a common, somewhat generic statement.
*    **Wt 3.0(NIDF 18.3%):** "That sounds like a lot of fun. How long have you been studying?"- The response is to add follow-up question.
*   **Wt 7.0 (NIDF 38.5%):** "I majored in practising my spiritual full time philosophy test" - A much more specific and unusual response, reflecting the model's attempt to use rarer words due to the high weight.
*    **Wt 10.0(NIDF71.9%):** "Oh wow! Merna jean isa paino yi hao hui bu acara sya gila [...]"- The model goes off the distribution, and generated some non-sense words.

As the weight increases, the response shifts from generic to specific, and even starts including some nonsensical and unrelated words. The increasing NIDF values clearly shows that increasing weight, using rarer words, can make the generated output go off-distribution[9].

In the Weighted Decoding Response table, increasing the weight leads to more specific responses, as indicated by the rising NIDF, but extreme weights can result in nonsensical output.

The Translation Ranking model, depicted in Figure 2, utilizes the triplet margin loss to optimize the embedding space [10]. The model receives four segments: the source, the reference, a "better" hypothesis, and a "worse" one [10]. These segments are encoded, and a pooling layer is applied [10].  The purpose is to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the "anchors" (source and reference) [2, 10].

The architecture is shown as:
![The architecture receives four segments: the source, the reference, a better hypothesis, and a worse one. These segments are independently encoded using a pretrained cross-lingual encoder and a pooling layer on top. Finally, using the triplet margin loss the resulting embedding space is optimized to minimize the distance between the “better” hypothesis and the “anchors” (source and reference).](image3)

In essence, the triplet margin loss function encourages the model to learn embeddings where better hypotheses are closer to both the source and reference translations than worse hypotheses.

The purpose of the triplet margin loss in the Translation Ranking Model is to minimize the distance between the embeddings of a "better" hypothesis and the source and reference, while maximizing the distance between the "worse" hypothesis and the anchors.

"Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback" enhances output refinement through an iterative process. It starts with generating an output from a Language Model. This output is then evaluated by a separate Critic Model, which provides feedback. The feedback can come from various sources, including knowledge bases, trained models, code interpreters, search engines, and other tools [6, 1]. This external feedback is then used by a Refine Model to improve the output [1, 5].

The diagram illustrates this process, showing the flow from the initial output to the Critic Model, which leverages external sources for feedback, and finally to the Refine Model.

![Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback involves a Language Model generating outputs, a Critic Model providing feedback from external sources, and a Refine Model improving the output based on this feedback.](image1)

In summary, 'Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback' enhances the refinement of outputs by using a critic model to evaluate the generated output and then providing feedback to refine model to iterative improve the output.

The "filter-then-rerank" paradigm is utilized to integrate both Small Language Models (SLMs) and Large Language Models (LLMs) within the same system [5]. This paradigm uses SLMs as filters to select the top-N candidate labels, then LLMs rerank them to make final decisions [5].

In the filter-then-rerank paradigm, templates are employed to convert candidate labels into question options [4].

For the label 'Contact.Meet', the template is described as follows:

The prompt template used for label 'Contact.Meet' in the filter-then-rerank method is "The word {evt} triggers a MEET event: two or more entities come together at a single location and interact with one another face-to-face.".

RAPTOR utilizes two querying mechanisms: Tree Traversal and Collapsed Tree.

The **Tree Traversal** method navigates the tree layer by layer. It starts by selecting the most relevant nodes at the root level and then progressively selects relevant child nodes at each subsequent level until it reaches the leaf nodes. [7, 9] This method offers control over the specificity and breadth of information retrieved by adjusting the depth and number of nodes selected at each layer. [9]
The process of Tree Traversal Retrieval can be visualized as.
![Tree Traversal Retrieval](image2)

In contrast, the **Collapsed Tree** approach simplifies the search by flattening the multi-layered tree into a single layer, evaluating all nodes simultaneously. [3] This method offers greater flexibility, allowing the retrieval of information at the correct level of granularity for a given question. [1]
The process of Collapsed Tree Retrieval can be visualized as.
![Collapsed Tree Retrieval](image2)

The difference between Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval lies in their search strategy: Tree Traversal goes layer by layer, while Collapsed Tree considers all nodes simultaneously.

The combination (comb) layers in Figure 2 serve to integrate the outputs from the forward and backward towers of the model.

The model utilizes a two-tower architecture, with one tower processing the input sequence in a forward direction and the other in a backward direction [5]. Each tower consists of multiple blocks that perform self-attention and feed-forward operations [7].

![Two tower architecture](image1)

During pre-training, the states containing information about the target word are masked in the final self-attention block [8]. However, during fine-tuning, this masking is disabled to allow the model to access the full context, including the token itself, which is beneficial for downstream tasks, especially token-level tasks like Named Entity Recognition (NER) [4, 8].
The outputs of final layer of forward and backward tower are input of combination layer.
![Two tower architecture with comb layer](image2)

The "comb" layer, therefore do not use masking [4].

The purpose of the combination (comb) layers is to integrate the contextual information captured by both the forward and backward processing towers.

The analysis of GPT-4V's errors involves a meticulous examination of 150 randomly sampled instances, categorized by expert annotators to identify the root causes of mispredictions [1]. The distribution of these errors is visually represented in a pie chart, which provides a clear breakdown of the error types ![image5](image5).

The pie chart shows various categories, but one stands out due to its size, representing the largest portion of the errors. According to it, Perceptual Errors account for 35% of the total errors [2]. Perceptual errors are further divided into two types: basic perceptual errors and domain-specific perceptual errors. The former occurs when the model fails in elementary visual interpretation, and the later occurs due to lack of knowledge [2]. For example, in a medical diagnosis, the model might incorrectly identify a bone in an image, leading to a flawed diagnosis [3]. Similarly, it may struggle with domain-specific interpretations, like those seen marketing-related error case, which stems from a perceptual error concerning market research data [7, 9].

The prevalence of perceptual errors is significant. It reflects challenges that even humans might face but which are particularly acute for AI models that rely on visual data interpretation [6].

In summary, the most common type of error in GPT-4V's analysis, according to the provided error distribution, is perceptual error.

The Chameleon model utilizes a supervised fine-tuning (SFT) strategy that is crucial for its inference capabilities. The SFT dataset is categorized into several types: Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Text/Image Generation, and Safety [7]. Each category contributes to the model's ability to handle various tasks.

The statistics of the dataset, detailed in the provided image, reveal the scale and distribution of the data used:

![A table detailing the dataset statistics for Chameleon-SFT, listing categories like Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Generation, and Safety, alongside the number of samples, tokens, and images for each.](image5)

For example, "Text" has 1.6 million samples and 940 million tokens, "Code" has 14.1 thousand samples and 1.1 million tokens, and "Image Generation" contains 64.3 thousand samples with 64.3 thousand images [7, ![{A table detailing the dataset statistics for Chameleon-SFT, listing categories like Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Generation, and Safety, alongside the number of samples, tokens, and images for each.}](image5)].
"Visual Chat" consists of 15.6 thousand samples with 16.7 thousand images, "Interleaved Generation" uses 16.9K samples and 30.7 thousand images. "Safety" has 95.3K samples with1.6K images. [7, ![{A table detailing the dataset statistics for Chameleon-SFT, listing categories like Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Generation, and Safety, alongside the number of samples, tokens, and images for each.}](image5)].

These datasets expose the model to a variety of data types, allowing it to improve safety and handle mixed-modal inputs and outputs [3]. The balancing of modalities within the SFT stage is emphasized as important for high-quality alignment, preventing the model from developing an unconditional prior that could exaggerate or mute the generation of a single modality [5].

The fine-tuning incorporates a cosine learning rate schedule with specific parameters to optimize performance [1]. The model is evaluated on tasks that require text generation conditioned on an image, such as image captioning and visual question-answering [10].

The SFT dataset's diverse categories and balanced approach directly inform the Chameleon model's inference, enabling it to perform competitively in tasks involving text and image generation, including mixed-modal scenarios.
